Authors: Czerwinski A., Katcki J., Ratajczak J., Simoen E., Poyai A., Claeys C., Ohyama H.
Title: Impact of fast-neutron irradiation on the silicon p-n junction leakage and role of the diffusion reverse current
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research, Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms
Affiliations: Institute of Electron Technology, Aleja Lotnikow 32/46, 02-668 Warsaw, Poland; IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; KU Leuven, Electr. Eng. Dept., B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; KNTC, 2659-2 Nishigoshi Kumamoto 861-1102, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Czerwinski, A., Institute of Electron Technology, Aleja Lotnikow 32/46, 02-668 Warsaw, Poland; Katcki, J., Institute of Electron Technology, Aleja Lotnikow 32/46, 02-668 Warsaw, Poland; Ratajczak, J., Institute of Electron Technology, Aleja Lotnikow 32/46, 02-668 Warsaw, Poland; Simoen, E., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Poyai, A., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium, KU Leuven, Electr. Eng. Dept., B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Claeys, C., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium, KU Leuven, Electr. Eng. Dept., B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Ohyama, H., KNTC, 2659-2 Nishigoshi Kumamoto 861-1102, Japan
Abstract: The p-n junction leakage (IR) at reverse voltage, which sets the leakage and power consumption of state of the art integrated circuits (ICs) and the DRAM retention time, is mostly related to the peripheral leakage (IR,p), which is poorly controlled by the defect engineering techniques, opposite to the planar regions. These ICs from their processing till applications cope with irradiation damages, which are side effects of the ICs manufacturing, due to the plasma, e-beam, X-ray and implantation processing, etc. On the other hand, ICs may be submitted to a significant natural radiation level, as e.g. in applications for space satellites and airplane equipment. Therefore, a proper analysis of the IR,p degradation by high-energy irradiation in silicon technology is proposed. It is found that IR,p increases slower for low fluences of neutron irradiation as compared to the leakage of the p-n junction planar regions, so that the IR,p contribution to the total IR decreases. However IR,p still dominates in irradiated small-size junctions. Moreover, for higher fluences the IR,p again strongly increases its contribution to the overall leakage. Deep insight into the underlying physics is obtained by an analysis of the gated diodes current. This method saves test-chip area and testing-time and omits the assumption of the same parasitic leakage for all junctions. Results are reported for n+p gated diodes and p-n junctions in Czochralski, epitaxial and float zone silicon, exposed to 1 MeV fast neutrons with fluences in the range 5 × 1011-5 × 1013 n/cm2. © 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Irradiated p-n junction leakage; Junction shape; Neutron irradiations; Si junction diodes
Index Keywords: Dynamic random access storage; Electron beams; Epitaxial growth; Integrated circuit manufacture; Leakage currents; Radiation damage; Semiconductor junctions; X rays; Reverse voltage; Silicon p-n junction leakage; Neutron irradiation

Authors: Clay J., Harris M.E.
Title: Risk-based corrective action of hydrocarbon contamination at a former major urban petroleum storage site in the U.K.
Affiliations: URS Dames and Moore, Blackfriars House, St. Mary's Parsonage, Manchester, M3 2JA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Clay, J., URS Dames and Moore, Blackfriars House, St. Mary's Parsonage, Manchester, M3 2JA, United Kingdom; Harris, M.E., URS Dames and Moore, Blackfriars House, St. Mary's Parsonage, Manchester, M3 2JA, United Kingdom
Abstract: The former site of a major petroleum storage facility adjacent to a major urban watercourse was found to have potentially significant concentrations of hydrocarbons in soil and groundwater that needed to be addressed prior to redevelopment. A series of intrusive investigations were undertaken to collect physical and chemical data for a Quantitative Risk Assessment (QRA) of potential impacts on human health and the wider environment, in order to derive a remedial strategy for redevelopment of the site for light industrial use. A site-specific QRA methodology was developed using both U.K. and U.S. guidance to produce Risk-Based Clean-up Levels (RBCLs) for benzene, and other petroleum hydrocarbons. The U.K. has no nationally based guidance on risk assessment and studies are designed by the consultant for submission to the U.K. Environment Agency (EA) for their approval. It is the EA's role to determine whether the work has been undertaken satisfactorily. To achieve these RBCLs, ex situ bioremediation was identified as the best practicable remedial option. This was carried out in windrows using mechanical aeration (to achieve oxygenation with ammonia nitrate granule and woodchip addition) for a total of approximately 5291 m3 of soil. The bioremediation process was successful in achieving the site specific RBCLs for benzene and for other hydrocarbons within an average of 5 to 6 weeks. This article describes the successful implementation of Risk-Based Corrective Action (RBCA) at this petroleum release site as a demonstration of how risk-based remedial standards for contaminated sites can be achieved with regulatory approval. © 2002 by AEHS.
Author Keywords: Bioremediation; Petroleum soil and groundwater contamination; Risk based corrective action
Index Keywords: Aromatic hydrocarbons; Bioremediation; Crude petroleum; Energy storage; Groundwater; Risk assessment; Soils; Petroleum soil and groundwater contamination; Risk based corrective action (RBCA); Toxic materials

Authors: Brown K.C.
Title: A remote area power supply using wind power and cold thermal storage
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Fluids Engineering Division (Publication) FED
Affiliations: The Univ. of Melbourne, Dept. of Mechanical and Mfg., Eng., Melbourne, Vic. 3010, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Brown, K.C., The Univ. of Melbourne, Dept. of Mechanical and Mfg., Eng., Melbourne, Vic. 3010, Australia
Abstract: A remote area power supply using cold thermal storage and wind as the energy source is proposed. The primary objective is to provide a renewable energy remote area power supply with cheaper and more robust storage than lead-acid batteries. The proposal amalgamates a vapour compression refrigeration system with a Rankine cycle engine, both using the same working fluid. A tank of freezing brine acts as the condenser in the Rankine cycle and as the evaporator in the refrigeration cycle but also provides the "energy storage". Analysis of the system indicates that it is practical and that its performance is comparable with existing battery based systems.

Abstract: C 6+ ions with energy 200 MeV/nucleon have been accumulated in the chamber of the ring magnet of the U-10 proton synchrotron used as a storage ring in the TWAC setup. A C 4+ ion beam from the laser source was first accelerated in the 1-3 injector up to 1.3 MeV/nucleon and in the UK booster synchrotron up to final energy with periodicity 3.5 sec. Ions have been accumulated in U-10 using the multiple charge-exchange injection scheme C 4+ → C 6+. An increase in the ion intensity in the accumulator has been observed during several injection cycles. Experimental data on the attained parameters of the accumulated beam are presented, and the status of the optimization of the accumulation regime is discussed.
Index Keywords: Ceramic vacuum chambers; Charge exchange; Electronic cooling; Magnetic pulses; Accelerator magnets; Electric potential; Heavy ions; High energy physics; Ion beams; Optimization; Particle beam injection; Proton beams; Synchrotrons; Storage rings

Authors: Domiinguez-Dominguez J., González-Valadez M., Muñoz-Hernández G.
Title: A STRATEGY to OPTIMIZE the MECHANICAL DENSIFICATION PROCESS of AGRICULTURAL CROP RESIDUES and BY-PRODUCTS [UNA ESTRATEGIA PARA OPTIMIZAR EL PROCESO de DENSIFICACIÓN MECÁNICA de RESIDUOS AGRÍCOLAS y AGROINDUSTRIALES]
Affiliations: Centre de Investigación en Matemáticas. CIMAT, A. C. Callejón de Jalisco s/n, 36240. Guanajuato, Mexico; Centro de Investigación y Asistencia Técnica Del Estado de Querétaro, CIATEQ, A. C. Avenida Manantiales 23A, 76246. Querétaro, Qro, Mexico

Guanajuato, Mexico; Muñoz-Hernández, G., Centro de Investigación y Asistencia Técnica Del Estado de Querétaro, CIATEQ, A. C. Avenida Manantiales 23A, 76246. Querétaro, Qro, Mexico
Abstract: The process of mechanical densification offers the possibility of using agricultural crop residues to produce livestock feed. Densification provides advantages for the handling, storage and transport of the fibrous agricultural residues. In order to find the significant factors and determine the best operating conditions for the densification process, two experiments were carried out. In both cases, the responses measured or monitored were: density, durability and energy consumption. In the first experiment a fractional factorial design with six factors (2 6-1) was used, in which four factors were significant. With this information a second experiment was undertaken: a central composite design with seven center points. Afterwards each response was modeled and the optimum point was determined by applying a graphical method. This paper presents the statistical analysis of the experiments and the method used to optimize simultaneously the three responses. Since the response models showed inconsistencies with respect to the classical assumption of homoscedasticity in the statistical analysis, these were fitted again using weighted least squares. This procedure allowed for greater precision in the calculation of the optimum point.
Author Keywords: Densification; Fibrous agricultural material; Optimization; Overall optimum

Abstract: Activated graphitizing carbons, mesophase carbons prepared by alkaline activation for electrochemical Capacitors (Electric double-layer capacitors; EDLCs) with organic liquid electrolytes showed larger specific capacitance per unit volume (F/cm 3) than those of conventional activated carbon materials. The physical characteristic is lower specific surface area, compared with a conventional activated carbon. It has been supposed that the electric double-layer interfaces of alkaline activated mesophase carbon which have high density per unit volume were dominated by the edge plane of hexagonal lattice, compared with those of conventional activated carbon material.

Authors: Hardman M., Denisov E., Makarov A.
Title: Ion fragmentation and storage in an asymmetric trapping quadrupole coupled to the orbitrap mass analyser
Source title: Proceedings 50th ASMS Conference on Mass Spectrometry and Allied Topics

Abstract: RF-only collisional multipole that allowed the extraction of ions in much shorter bunches was developed. The same multipole was used as a collision cell for collision-induced dissociation and subsequent cooling and storage of the fragments produced. The detection electrodes were kept at virtual ground and only the voltage on the central electrode was monotonously changed down to -3kV by a purpose built high-voltage amplifier. It was found that the axial potential well across the axis of the trapping quadrupole results in both high and low-mass cut-offs.

Authors: Smith G.
Title: Nanoparticle physics for energy, lighting and environmental control technologies
Affiliations: Institute of Nanotechnology, Department of Applied Physics, University of Technology, Sydney, PO Box 123, Broadway, NSW 2007, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Smith, G., Institute of Nanotechnology, Department of Applied Physics, University of Technology, Sydney, PO Box 123, Broadway, NSW 2007, Australia
Abstract: Performance of everyday systems such as windows, skylights, painted car panels, roofs and walls and lighting installations, can be improved markedly using nanoparticles, nanocoated micro-particles and nanocomposites. Additional functionality such as self cleaning and power generation is also possible. Properties and applications using polymer and conductor nano- and micro-particles, metal coated particles and nano-voids in metals are covered. Engineering of novel optical and thermal properties based on surface plasmons and surface plasmon polaritons is outlined. The diversity of responses and technical opportunities demands modelling. Empirical exploration by itself is time consuming and risky. Representing an inhomogeneous nanocomposite optically by an "effective" homogeneous medium is shown to be useful when correctly applied, but is seen to be prone to misuse. The current controversy about negative refractive index nanostructures is a recent example. Opportunities in solar cells, thermal-to-electric conversion and refrigeration, separation, energy storage and power management systems are outlined, along with new decorative and display options.
Index Keywords: Environmental controls; Nanoparticles; Power management systems; Surface plasmon polaritons; Energy efficiency; Energy storage; Particles (particulate matter); Pollution control; Refractive index; Solar cells; Solar refrigeration; Surface plasmon resonance; Thermodynamic properties; Thermoelectric energy conversion; Nanostructured materials

Abstract: Wide-bandgap group-III nitride lasers, which emit from near-ultraviolet to pure-blue, are reviewed. Characteristics of 405 nm wavelength laser diodes (LDs) are discussed. Reducing threading dislocation can increase the lifetime of nitride LDs. Using epitaxial lateral overgrowth technique, the dislocation density of the order of 105 cm-2 has been obtained. The relation between the lifetime of nitride LDs and the density of dislocation are discussed. Some optical and electrical properties are very important for optical disk system such as digital versatile disk (DVD) system. In use of the DVD system, important properties of nitride LDs are discussed. Furthermore, near-ultraviolet LDs and pure-blue LDs are described. The near-ultraviolet LDs uses GaN or AlInGaN active layer instead of InGaN.
Author Keywords: Dislocation; GaN; InGaN; Laser; Lifetime; Quantum well; Ultraviolet

Authors: Lue J.-L., Lee J., Luo J.-S.
Title: New Techniques to Improve the Efficiency of TEM Sample Preparation
Source title: Conference Proceedings from the International Symposium for Testing and Failure Analysis
Affiliations: ProMOS Technologies Inc., Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lue, J.-L., ProMOS Technologies Inc., Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lee, J., ProMOS Technologies Inc., Hsinchu, Taiwan; Luo, J.-S., ProMOS Technologies Inc., Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: Three techniques have been developed for TEM sample preparation to improve efficiency in terms of time reduction and success rate. The first technique is to closely control the thickness of a sample for a specific area to less than 10μm by mechanical polishing before undergoing FIB thinning. The second one is to repair cracks produced during mechanical polishing before further milling in the ion miller. The last one is to provide an in-FIB remedy for face-to-face cross-sectional samples, which peel from each other during mechanical polishing. These new techniques will substantially enhance the success rate and turnaround time for TEM sample preparation.
Index Keywords: Cracks; Dynamic random access storage; Ion beams; Laser applications; Milling (machining); Polishing; Transmission electron microscopy; X rays; Energy dispersive spectroscope (EDS); Focused ion beam (FIB) systems; Mechanical polishing; Integrated circuits

Authors: EI-Saady G., Hemeida A.M.
Title: Superconducting magnetic energy storage unit for the wind -driven induction generator
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Electrical Engineering Department, High Institute of Energy, Aswan, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: EI-Saady, G., Electrical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Hemeida, A.M., Electrical Engineering Department, High Institute of Energy, Aswan, Egypt
Abstract: The present paper introduces a novel application of Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage SMES unit for voltage regulation of windturbine self-excitation standalone induction generation. The main feature of SMES is that it has the ability to store energy and return this again to supply. The approach is based on absorbing/injecting active power energy via SMES to the induction generator terminal bus when the terminal voltage is more/less than normal voltage. The dynamic model of self-excited induction generator SEIG in synchronously reference frame is established. Also dynamic model of SMES is present. The Proportional-Integral PI controller is designed to control the absorbed and injected active power using the pole assignment approach. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed PI controlled SMES, the SEIG is subjected to different disturbances such as wind speed, load changes, and reference terminal voltage. Moreover, a comparison between the SEIG responses after application a varieties of excursions when the PI controlled SMES or PI controlled Static Var Compensator SVC is connected at SEIG terminal. The digital Simulation results prove the superiority and power of SMES above SVC in terms of fast response over a wide range of operating conditions.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric potential; Lyapunov methods; Magnetization; Proportional control systems; Superconducting magnets; Wind power; Wind turbines; Magnetic energy; Power modulation; Electric generators

Authors: Di Perna C., Izzo N., Varilone P., Verde P.
Title: Reversible AC/DC power electronic prototype for fuel-cell units
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Dipto. di Ingegneria Industriale, Università di Cassino, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Di Perna, C., Dipto. di Ingegneria Industriale, Università di Cassino, Italy; Izzo, N., Dipto. di Ingegneria Industriale, Università di Cassino, Italy; Varilone, P., Dipto. di Ingegneria Industriale, Università di Cassino, Italy; Verde, P., Dipto. di Ingegneria Industriale, Università di Cassino, Italy
Abstract: The paper describes the results of research activities that allowed to realise a 1 kW Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) fuel cell system. The system is conceived to operate both as generating unit connectable to ac grid and as power source on board of hybrid vehicles. The large flexibility of the system is guaranteed by its structure and by the digital DSP based control. In the paper the structure of the multiconverter system is presented and the control strategy able to manage the power flow is discussed with reference to the case in which the system is on board of a hybrid vehicle. The system has been modelled both by Power System Blockset and Matlab Simulink to verify the features of the control to be implemented on DS1103 PPC Controller board. The shown results of the simulations confirm the ability to control the whole system managing the energy flow.
Index Keywords: Proton exchange membranes (PEM); Storage system (SS); Capacitors; Computer simulation; Digital signal processing; Electric converters; Electric insulation; Electric loads; Electric motors; Electric power systems; Fuel cells; Protons; Power electronics

Authors: Bhatt M., Hurley W.G., Wolfle W.
Title: Battery charge control for emergency back-up systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Power Electronics Research Centre, National University of Ireland, Galway, Ireland; Convertec Ltd., Wexford, Ireland; Power Electronics Research Centre, Dept. of Electronics Engineering, National University of Ireland, Galway, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Bhatt, M., Power Electronics Research Centre, National University of Ireland, Galway, Ireland, Power Electronics Research Centre, Dept. of Electronics Engineering, National University of Ireland, Galway, Ireland; Hurley, W.G., Power Electronics Research Centre, National University of Ireland, Galway, Ireland; Wolfle, W., Convertec Ltd., Wexford, Ireland
Abstract: For many years, intensive research has been undertaken to increase the life of batteries. Overcharging results in excessive temperature in the battery, which degrades the chemical composition of the electrolyte. During charging, when the battery reaches end-of-charge, the energy being supplied to the battery is no longer consumed in the charge reaction and this additional energy starts dissipating as heat within the battery. At this point, the oxygen cycle accelerates, which leads to temperature rise inside the battery. State-of-the-art control technology is required to control the charging of the battery and prevent the battery going into thermal runaway. The paper contrasts and compares Valve Regulated Lead Acid (VRLA) and NiCd batteries. A sophisticated microprocessor-based battery charge control system is described.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Automotive industry; Electric batteries; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electrolytes; Microprocessor chips; Threshold voltage; Pulse mode charging (PMC); Charging (batteries)

Authors: Vereschagin N.M., Bochkov V.D., Kruglov S.A.
Title: A Pseudospark Gap in the Inductive-Energy-Storage Circuit
Affiliations: Ryazan State Radio Eng. Academy, ul. Gagarina 59/1, Ryazan 391000, Russian Federation; OOO Impul'snye Tekhnologii, Ryazan, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Vereschagin, N.M., Ryazan State Radio Eng. Academy, ul. Gagarina 59/1, Ryazan 391000, Russian Federation; Bochkov, V.D., OOO Impul'snye Tekhnologii, Ryazan, Russian Federation; Kruglov, S.A., Ryazan State Radio Eng. Academy, ul. Gagarina 59/1, Ryazan 391000, Russian Federation
Abstract: A pseudospark gap is described that is capable of interrupting a current of up to 1 kA and shaping voltage pulses with an amplitude of up to 110 kV and rise time of ∼100 ns. Analytical expressions for calculating the energy released in the device at the switching-off stage and the efficiency of the generator with an inductive energy storage system are obtained. The characteristics of the pseudospark gap and of a similar-design thyratron connected in the same circuit are compared. It is found that the turn-off time of the pseudospark gap is shorter than that of the thyratron by a factor of 2.5.

Authors: Mexmain J.M., Rubin De Cervens D., Marret J.P., Roos V., Cassany B., Eyl P., Pere P., Havre S.S., Fauvel J., Mathieu P., Benin P., Callu G., Vincent C., Michalczyk P.
Title: Pulsed power conditioning system for the Megajoule Laser
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, Ile de France, BP 12, 92680 Bruyeres le Chatel, France; Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, CESTA, BP2, 33114 Le Barp, France; THALES Systemes Aeroportes, La Clef de Saint-Pierre-1, 78852 Elancourt, France; TPC, Avue du Colonel Prat, 21850 St Apollinaire, France

Abstract: The CEA is responsible for the Megajoule Laser (LMJ) facility. This facility is a large Flashlamp pump laser (1.8 MJ optical output). CEA entered into a contract with THALES to carry out the pulsed power conditioning system for the Megajoule Laser. The pulsed power conditioning system has a modular design which makes the facility more flexible and safer. This complete primary storage is a 450 MJ energy capacitor bank composed of 270 modules of 1.6 MJ energy. Each module is a stand-alone capacitor bank equipped with twelve 100 kJ capacitors and its embedded control/monitor and diagnostic system which is connected by an optical Ethernet link to the Command Control Supervisor of the facility. In the first step of the LMJ program, called « Line Integration Laser »(LIL), one laser chain will be built. The capacitor bank used to drive the LIL is comprised of 10 modules. This paper describes the design of the modules and the results of testing. The overall electrical performance meets the requirements.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Command and control systems; Electric commutation; Optical design; Stimulated emission; Amplifier stimulated emission; Line integration laser; Megajoule laser; Pulsed power conditioning system; Pulsed laser applications

Authors: Bailey K., Phillips A., Blankenship J., Jankovic M., Cikanek S.
Title: Hybrid operating strategy and energy management for a hybrid electric vehicle
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Dynamic Systems and Control Division (Publication) DSC
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, K.; Phillips, A.; Blankenship, J.; Jankovic, M.; Cikanek, S.
Abstract: This paper describes the development of the Low Storage Requirement (LSR) Hybrid Electric Vehicle (HEV) Vehicle System Controller (VSC). It defines the LSR configuration and discusses the advantages of this particular configuration. The main focus of this paper is the hybrid operating strategy for this vehicle and the details of the hybrid operating modes. This hybrid vehicle was developed as a part of the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) Hybrid Propulsion Systems Development Program that was conducted under a cost-shared subcontract funded equally by Ford and DOE through the Midwest Research Institute which manages and operates DOE's National Renewable Energy Laboratory in Golden, CO.
Index Keywords: Control equipment; Electric batteries; Electric motors; Energy management; Low storage requirements; Electric vehicles

Authors: Sarimveis H., Angelou A., Retsina T.
Title: Mill-wide optimization based on mathematical programming techniques
Affiliations: Natl. Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Sarimveis, H., Natl. Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Angelou, A.; Retsina, T.
Abstract: In this work we present a methodology, which can help the mill managers to make successful decisions towards the best possible operation of the mill. The objective is the maximization of profit through optimal management of inventories and selection of production rates. In order to use this methodology, a mill wide detailed model is first developed, taking into account the mass and energy balances, system constraints, storage capacities etc. MILP (Mixed Integer Linear Programming) optimization techniques are then utilized so as to minimize the economical impact of the scheduled shutdowns and the daily disturbances, which are due to machine breakdowns, real time pricing of utilities and changing production demands.
Index Keywords: Integer programming; Inventory control; Linear programming; Production control; Mixed integer linear programming (MILP); Paper and pulp mills; Inventory Control; Linear Programing; Paper Mills; Production Control

Authors: Sakasai K., Katagiri M., Toh K., Takahashi H., Nakazawa M., Kondo Y.

Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium and Medical Imaging Conference

Research Institute, Ibaraki 319-1195, Japan; Institute for Material Research, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8577, Japan; Department of Quantum Engineering, University of Tokyo, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan; Department of Applied Physics, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8579, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sakasai, K., Japan Atom. Ener. Research Institute, Ibaraki 319-1195, Japan; Katagiri, M., Japan Atom. Ener. Abstract: Characteristics of a SrBPO5:Eu2+material have been investigated as a neutron storage phosphor. The authors found this phosphor shows photostimulated luminescence by illumination with 635 nm laser light after neutron irradiation. The neutron sensitivity was proportional to E -0.5, where E is neutron energy. The Sγ/S n ratio of the phosphor using enriched boron was better than that of a commercially available imaging plate, where Sγ and S n are the gamma and neutron sensitivities, respectively. A collimated neutron beam image was clearly obtained with the phosphor sample by scanning focused laser light on it.
Index Keywords: Gamma rays; Laser beams; Neutrons; Neutron storage phosphors; Phosphors

Authors: Stöhlker Th., Banas D., Beyer H.J., Gumberidze A., Tachenov S., Sierpowski D., Krings T., Kozhuharov C., Spillmann U., Ma X., Protic D.
Title: X-Ray Spectroscopy of Highly Charged Ions: Application of Position Sensitive Germanium Detectors
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium and Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH, Institut für Kernphysik, 52428 Jülich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Stöhlker, Th., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Banas, D., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Beyer, H.J., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Gumberidze, A., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Tachenov, S., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Sierpowski, D., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Krings, T., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Kozhuharov, C., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Spillmann, U., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Ma, X., GSI-Darmstadt, Planckstraße 1, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Protic, D., Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH, Institut für Kernphysik, 52428 Jülich, Germany
Abstract: Segmented and position sensitive germanium detector systems play an important role for future x-ray spectroscopy experiments with highly charged heavy ions. The unique properties of such systems are millimeter to sub-millimeter spatial resolution as well as a good time and energy resolution for the hard x-ray regime above 15 keV. When dealing with fast moving heavy ions at accelerators or storage rings, this spatial resolution guarantees for a suppression of Doppler broadening without a loss of detection efficiency. Another example is the combination with a focusing crystal spectrometer, where a position-segmented detector permits the measurement of an energy spectrum wide enough to investigate the interesting energy regime simultaneously. In addition, the good energy resolution enables discrimination against background events of the recorded spectra arising from various sources. Very recently such a micro-strip detector system, developed at the Forschungszentrum Jülich, with a position resolution of close to 200 μm has become available An additional important feature of such detector systems is their sensitivity to the photon polarization at energies above 50 keV. By means of such detection devices, the polarization of atomic transitions in highly charged heavy ions can be addressed experimentally with high accuracy.
Index Keywords: Doppler effect; Ions; Photons; Storage rings; X ray spectroscopy; Energy resolution; Radiation detectors

Authors: Shirai Y., Nitta T.
Title: On-line grasp of dynamic stability of power system by use of superconducting magnet energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Affiliations: Graduate School of Energy Science, Dept. of Ener. Sci. and Technology, Kyoto University, Yoshida-Honmachi, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8501, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1, Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shirai, Y., Graduate School of Energy Science, Dept. of Ener. Sci. and Technology, Kyoto University, Yoshida-Honmachi, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8501, Japan; Nitta, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Tokyo, 7-3-1, Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 113-8656, Japan
Abstract: In recent years, the deregulation in power industries is in progress, IPPs and distributed generators are introduced to power systems. It should be important to grasp the power system operating conditions from on-line data. We have proposed to estimate the operating conditions by use of SMES. In this paper, on-line evaluation of the dynamic stability of power systems by use of SMES was discussed. Basic experiments in one-machine connected to an infinite bus system were carried out by use of a small generator, artificial transmission lines and a small SMES. The synchronizing and damping coefficients of the power system for various generator output powers were measured with several excitation controls, such as a constant field current and with AVR function of different parameters. The effects of the excitation control on the dynamic stability of the system were evaluated from the on-line measured synchronizing and damping coefficients by use of SMES.
Author Keywords: Damping coefficient; Dynamic Stability; Excitation control; Superconducting Magnet Energy Storage; Synchronizing coefficient
Index Keywords: Magnetic storage; Superconducting magnets; Synchronization; Voltage control; Dynamic stability; Electric power systems

Affiliations: International Business Nucleonic, Kurchatov sq. 1, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Eremeev, I.P., International Business Nucleonic, Kurchatov sq. 1, 123182 Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: A method is proposed to produce intense monochromatic polarized γ-rays and neutrons by a synchronized interaction of electron bunches in a storage ring with a pulsed laser beam oscillating in a cavity. Infrared cavities could be used as 'laser undulators' to apply the method with the best advantage. The spectral and integral characteristics of γ-rays and photoneutrons have been estimated for beam parameters of modern electron-storage rings with an energy of 1-3 GeV and pulsed infrared lasers.

Authors: Yamashita K., Watanabe M., Okino A., Hotta E., Shimizu N., Iida K.
Title: High rep-rate inductive-energy-storage pulsed power modulator using high voltage static induction thyristor
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Power Modulator Symposium
Affiliations: Department of Energy Sciences, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama 226-8502, Japan; Corporate Technical Center, NGK Insulators Ltd., Suda-cho, Mizuho-ku, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamashita, K., Department of Energy Sciences, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama 226-8502, Japan; Watanabe, M., Department of Energy Sciences, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama 226-8502, Japan; Okino, A., Department of Energy Sciences, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama 226-8502, Japan; Hotta, E., Department of Energy Sciences, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama 226-8502, Japan; Shimizu, N., Corporate Technical Center, NGK Insulators Ltd., Suda-cho, Mizuho-ku, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan; Iida, K., Corporate Technical Center, NGK Insulators Ltd., Suda-cho, Mizuho-ku, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan
Abstract: A high voltage static induction thyristor (SI Thy) has two significant features. One is that carriers can be quickly pulled out of gate region without applying a high voltage to the gate. The other is that its ON-state voltage is very low. These features make the SI Thy especially suitable for a switch of high rep-rate inductive-energy-storage pulsed power modulators, since the switch can interrupt a current rapidly and energy loss by the switch in a conduction phase can be remarkably reduced. In this research, a high rep-rate inductive-energy-storage pulsed power modulator, which uses a high voltage Si Thy as an opening switch, has been designed and constructed for application to an induction synchroton. The maximum operating frequency of the modulator is expected to be 1 MHz. The induction synchroton accelerates bunched charged particle beams using induced electric fields, which is proportional to the time derivative of magnetic flux in a toroidal core. In order to prevent a magnetic flux of the core from saturating, it is necessary to reset the toroidal core after each acceleration pulse. Therefore, a reset circuit independent of an acceleration circuit is needed in general. However, the proposed modulator can supply both the acceleration and the reset pulses without any additional circuit and is especially suitable for an induction synchrotron accelerator.
Index Keywords: Electric potential; Energy dissipation; Inductance; Thyristors; Induction synchrotron; Pulsed power modulator; Modulators

Title: A new approach to measuring the sensitive volume using a pulsed laser system
Source title: Proceedings of the European Conference on Radiation and its Effects on Components and Systems, RADECS

Abstract: Recent work has shown that ions can be used to measure the depth and thickness of the sensitive volume in memory devices and that laser pulsing at a range of wavelengths also yields an estimate of the charge collection depth. In this paper it is shown that the laser technique can be extended to provide a detailed measurement of the sensitivity profile of a memory cell with respect to charge collection from an ionisation track. It is also shown, through analysis of pulsed laser SEU threshold measurements made at two wavelengths, that the charge collection depth for the 1Mbit SRAM's appears to be significantly greater than the depth of the active region.

Authors: Segura Meccia E.C., Perazzo R.P.J.
Title: Biologically plausible associative memory: Continuous unit response + stochastic dynamics
Affiliations: Sch. of Computing, Info. Syst. Math., South Bank University, 103 Borough Road, London SE1 0AA, United Kingdom; Departamento de Fisica, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Ciudad Universitaria, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Segura Meccia, E.C., Sch. of Computing, Info. Syst. Math., South Bank University, 103 Borough Road, London SE1 0AA, United Kingdom; Perazzo, R.P.J., Departamento de Fisica, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Ciudad Universitaria, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina
Abstract: A neural network model of associative memory is presented which unifies the two historically more relevant enhancements to the basic Little-Hopfield discrete model: the graded response units approach and the stochastic, Glauber-inspired model with a random field representing thermal fluctuations. This is done by casting the retrieval process of the model with graded response neurons, into the framework of a diffusive process governed by the Fokker-Plank equation, which leads to a Langevin system describing the process at a microscopic level, while the time evolution of the probability density function is governed by a multivariate Fokker Planck equation operating over the space of all possible activation patterns. The present unified approach has two notable features: (i) greater biological plausibility and (ii) ability to escape local minima of energy (associated with spurious memories), which makes it a potential tool for those complex optimization problems for which the previous models failed.
Author Keywords: Associative memory; Fokker-Planck equation; Graded response; Hopfield model; Stochastic dynamics
Index Keywords: Asymptotic stability; Computer simulation; Neural networks; Numerical methods; Probability density function; Probability distributions; Random processes; Biologically plausible associative memory; Continuous unit response; Fokker-Planck equation; Graded response; Hopfield model; Stochastic dynamics; Associative storage

Authors: Bräuning H., Diehl A., Diemar K.V., Theiß A., Trassl R., Salzborn E., Hofmann I.
Title: Charge-changing ion-ion collisions in heavy ion fusion
Affiliations: Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Gesell. Schwerionenforsch.-Darmstadt, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, Leihgesterner Weg 217, D-35392 Giessen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bräuning, H., Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Diehl, A., Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Diemar, K.V., Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Theiß, A., Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Trassl, R., Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Salzborn, E., Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, D-35392 Giessen, Germany, Institut für Kernphysik, Justus-Liebig Universität, Leihgesterner Weg 217, D-35392 Giessen, Germany; Hofmann, I., Gesell. Schwerionenforsch.-Darmstadt, D-64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: In heavy ion fusion, the compression of the DT pellet requires high intensity beams of ions in the gigaelectron volt energy range. Charge-changing collisions due to intrabeam scattering can have a high impact on the design of adequate accelerator and storage rings. Not only do intensity losses have to be taken into account, but also the deposition of energy on the beam lines after bending magnets, for example, may be nonnegligible. The center-of-mass energy for these intrabeam collisions is typically in the kiloelectron volt range for beam energies in the order of several gigaelectron volts. In this article, we present experimental cross sections for charge transfer and ionization in homonuclear collisions of Ar4+, Kr4+, and Xe4+, and for charge transfer only in homonuclear collisions of Pb4+ and Bi4+. Using a hypothetical 100-Tm synchrotron as an example, expected particle losses are calculated based on the experimental data. The results are compared with expectations for singly charged Bi+ ions, which are usually considered for heavy ion fusion.
Author Keywords: Charge transfer; Heavy ion fusion; Ionization
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Charge transfer; Energy dissipation; Ion beam assisted deposition; Ion beams; Ionization; Scattering; Storage rings; Synchrotrons; Heavy ion fusion; Heavy ions

Authors: Dasgupta C.
Title: Glassy behavior in neural network models of associative memory
Source title: Physica A: Statistical Mechanics and its Applications
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Centre for Condensed Matter Theory, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India
Authors with affiliations: Dasgupta, C., Department of Physics, Centre for Condensed Matter Theory, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India
Abstract: Neural network models of associative memory exhibit a large number of spurious attractors of the network dynamics which are not correlated with any memory state. These spurious attractors, analogous to "glassy" local minima of the energy or free energy of a system of particles, degrade the performance of the network by trapping trajectories starting from states that are not close to one of the memory states. Different methods for reducing the adverse effects of spurious attractors are examined with emphasis on the role of synaptic asymmetry. © 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Konosu S., Tahara T., Kobayashi H.
Title: Japanese code for assessment procedure for crack-like flaws in pressure equipment
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ibaraki University, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Konosu, S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ibaraki University, Ibaraki, Japan; Tahara, T., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ibaraki University, Ibaraki, Japan; Kobayashi, H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ibaraki University, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: There are numerous instances in which in-service flaws due to various kinds of damage and deterioration are found in equipment as a result of in-service inspections. The proper evaluation of such flaws is extremely important. Fitness-for-Service (FFS) codes, such as ASME B & PV Code Sec. XI and JSME S NA1 for nuclear power generation facilities and BS 7910 and API-RP579 for general industrial facilities, are available. In light of such circumstances, the High Pressure Institute of Japan (HPI) has prescribed its code "Assessment procedure for crack-like flaws in pressure equipment" for conducting quantitative safety evaluations of flaws detected in common industrial pressure components such as pressure vessels, piping, storage tanks, and so on designed and fabricated in accordance with Japanese codes and regulations such as JIS B8265 and High Pressure Gas Safety Law. The FFS code consists of Level 1 assessment (whereby assessment can be conducted without extensive knowledge of fracture mechanics) and Level 2 assessment (which enables more detailed fracture mechanics analyses and is currently being studied). The allowable flaw size is specified in accordance with the plate thickness. The required impact absorbed energies based on material strength, whether or not PWHT has been done and the orientation of the flaw in relation to the weld seam, are also specified. An approximated equation of stress intensity factor for an embedded flaw near the surface has been derived. The re-characterization procedure for assessing an embedded flaw has been clarified. The flaw can be judged to be acceptable if its size is less than that of an allowable flaw and the equipment is to be used at temperatures exceeding the temperature (MAT) at which the material absorbed energy meets the required impact absorbed energy.
Index Keywords: Pressure equipments; Fracture mechanics; Nuclear energy; Pressure vessels; Stress intensity factors; Cracks

Authors: Mashange K.
Title: The turbulent liquid fuel industry in Zimbabwe: Options for resolving the crisis and improving supply to the poor
Affiliations: Department of Energy, Private Bag 7758, Causeway, Harare, Zimbabwe; African Energy Research Policy Network (AFREPREN/FWD), Elgeyo Marakwet Close, P.O. Box 30979, Nairobi GPO, Kenya
Authors with affiliations: Mashange, K., Department of Energy, Private Bag 7758, Causeway, Harare, Zimbabwe, African Energy Research Policy Network (AFREPREN/FWD), Elgeyo Marakwet Close, P.O. Box 30979, Nairobi GPO, Kenya
Abstract: Towards the end of the last decade, supplies in petroleum fuel have been erratic to the extent that Zimbabwe has at times operated with as low as 40% of normal supplies. These shortages were attributed mainly to foreign exchange shortages and alleged mismanagement and corruption at the National Oil Company of Zimbabwe (NOCZIM). As shortages intensified, problems of product shortage began to unfold, which adversely impacted on the urban poor. The public began to question the industry's policies on the sustainability of the liquid fuel sector policies in Zimbabwe. Of particular concern was policies regarding regulatory mechanisms, pricing, distribution, utilisation of storage facilities, supply routes and NOCZIM management. This paper evaluates the challenges facing the Zimbabwean petroleum sector and presents recommendations that could assist in ensuring a robust and functional national fuel sector. © 2002 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Liquid fuels; Prices; Reforms; Zimbabwe
Index Keywords: Crude petroleum; Fuel storage; Management; Robustness (control systems); Shortages; Liquid fuels; energy policy; oil supply; petroleum; poverty; Zimbabwe

Authors: Zheng W., Zhao L., Wang R., Xu Y.
Title: Study on growth and properties of a new holographic storage material-Ce:Pr:LiNO3 crystal
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: School of Material Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150001, China; Electric-optics Information Center, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150001, China
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, W., School of Material Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150001, China; Zhao, L., School of Material Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150001, China; Wang, R., Electric-optics Information Center, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150001, China; Xu, Y., Electric-optics Information Center, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, 150001, China
Abstract: Pr:LiNbO3 crystal can be used in two-color gated storage process for its special energy-level structure. Compared with other crystals used as volume holographic storage media, it has a great merit that an image recording does not erase the recorded one in multiplex storage process. But its photorefractive effect appears weaker than other crystals in the same conditions. We doped photorefractive sensitizing element Ce into Pr:LibNO3 to get Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 crystal with Czochralski method. The structure of crystals has been determined by X-ray powder diffraction method. The results indicate Pr:LiNbO3 and Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 keep the same structural characteristics as pure lithium niobate. In the absorption spectra of Pr:LiNbO3 and Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 samples with non-polarized light in wavelength of 300-900nm, the absorption edge of Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 shifts to the red compared with that of Pr:LiNbO3.The diffraction efficiency, writing time and especially erasing time of Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 have been measured. We find that maximum diffraction efficiency of Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 has increased without at cost of decreasing the erasing time. The effect of doping ions on the optical properties of Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 crystal as holographic recording media has been studied systematically. © 2002 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Ce:Pr:LiNbO3 crystal; Erasing; Holographic storage; Photorefractive

Authors: Akor A.J., Zibokere D.S.
Title: Design and development of a universal dryer
Source title: AMA, Agricultural Mechanization in Asia, Africa and Latin America
Affiliations: Dept. of Agricultural Egineeering, Rivers State Univ. of Sci./Technol., P.M.B. 5080, Port Harcourt, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Akor, A.J., Dept. of Agricultural Egineeering, Rivers State Univ. of Sci./Technol., P.M.B. 5080, Port Harcourt, Nigeria; Zibokere, D.S., Dept. of Agricultural Egineeering, Rivers State Univ. of Sci./Technol., P.M.B. 5080, Port Harcourt, Nigeria
Abstract: A passive universal dryer was designed and tested in Port Harcourt, Nigeria with the aim of providing an acceptable low to intermediate drying technology for the humid region. This paper presents the design considerations, equipment components and test results for the dryer. The equipment performed satisfactorily with the various fuels used and the variety of products tested. The dryer reduced the moisture content of fresh maize to the safe storage level of 12% (wb) within 12 hours resulting in 98% viability of dried maize. Yam chips required the same time to loose 29.62% of moisture, bringing it to the safe storage moisture level of 14.21%. Cassava chips required 20 hours of drying to attain the safe moisture level while sliced ginger required 18 hours. A 98% viability was recorded in maize dried with the universal dryer. The sensory evaluation of dried product shows a more acceptable, neat and spore less food materials when compared with the sun-dried ones. By controlling the temperature and environmental air condition of the drying chamber, it was possible to retain a good proportion of the natural taste, odor, flavor and color of the dried product. It was also demonstrated that the dryer could use four different sources of energy: kerosene stove, wood, solar energy and electrical heater, to operate economically and efficiently.
Index Keywords: Agricultural machinery; Heat exchangers; Heat losses; Heat transfer; Moisture; Solar collectors; Solar energy; Temperature control; Universal dryers; Agriculture; Agriculture; Heat Exchangers; Heat Loss; Heat Transfer; Moisture; Temperature Control; Bacteria (microorganisms); Dioscorea alata; Manihot esculenta; Zea mays; Zingiber officinale

Authors: Tomizawa M., Takeshita K., Tsuri K., Amano Y., Akiba M., Hashizume T.
Title: Modeling of the main component of the bottoming stage in an advanced co-generation system on the operational planning
Source title: JSME International Journal, Series B: Fluids and Thermal Engineering
Affiliations: Fuji Research Institute Corporation, Waseda University, Japan; Waseda University, Japan; Yamatake Corporation, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tomizawa, M., Fuji Research Institute Corporation, Waseda University, Japan; Takeshita, K., Waseda University, Japan; Tsuri, K., Yamatake Corporation, Japan; Amano, Y., Waseda University, Japan; Akiba, M., Waseda University, Japan; Hashizume, T., Waseda University, Japan
Abstract: The advanced co-generation system (ACGS) was built at Waseda University in 1999. The ACGS consists of a gas turbine, a steam turbine, an ammonia-water mixture turbine, an ammonia absorption refrigerator and an ice storage system. These turbine systems have a cascade relation upon the utilization of energy. Meanwhile, the ammonia-water mixture turbine and the ammonia absorption refrigerator located in the bottoming stage of the ACGS to utilize the lower temperature steam. In this paper, a mathematical model of the bottoming stage of the ACGS is established according to the experimental data. And, the operational planning of the bottoming stage with three cases of the cooling demand during the nighttime is also discussed.

Title: Can Brazil learn from California?
Affiliations: Mercados de Energia, Power Systems Research Inc., Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Barroso, L.A.N., Mercados de Energia, Power Systems Research Inc., Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Pereira, M.V.F., Mercados de Energia, Power Systems Research Inc., Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Kelman, R., Mercados de Energia, Power Systems Research Inc., Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Lino, P., Mercados de Energia, Power Systems Research Inc., Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Rosenblatt, J., Mercados de Energia, Power Systems Research Inc., Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Abstract: In assessing impact of design of the Californian power market on the present crisis, the issue is whether design flaws have made a serious situation unmanageable. The Brazilian reform, while conceptually different in some aspects to that in California, also faced a strong rise of energy demand that could not be matched immediately by its hydro reserves or new supply. When addressing the possibility of a more decentralized market in Brazil, one of the difficulties in the spot market scheme for hydrothermal systems was the pricing distortion when there were hydro plants in cascade.

Authors: Mustonen A.-M., Nieminen P., Hyvärinen H.
Title: Effects of low-dose leptin and gender on the physiology of the mouse (Mus musculus)
Source title: Journal of Animal Physiology and Animal Nutrition
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of Joensuu, Finland Anne-Mari Mustonen, PO Box 111, FIN-80101 Joensuu, Finland; Department of Biology, University of Joensuu, PO Box 111, FIN-80101 Joensuu, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Mustonen, A.-M., Department of Biology, University of Joensuu, Finland Anne-Mari Mustonen, PO Box 111, FIN-80101 Joensuu, Finland, Department of Biology, University of Joensuu, PO Box 111, FIN-80101 Joensuu, Finland; Nieminen, P., Department of Biology, University of Joensuu, Finland Anne-Mari Mustonen, PO Box 111, FIN-80101 Joensuu, Finland; Hyvärinen, H., Department of Biology, University of Joensuu, Finland Anne-Mari Mustonen, PO Box 111, FIN-80101 Joensuu, Finland
Abstract: Exogenous leptin was given intraperitoneally to five male and five female mice at 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day for 3 days. The plasma glucose and thyroxine concentrations as well as the hepatic and kidney enzyme activities were determined. The hepatic glycogen phosphorylase activity was suppressed by leptin treatment in the male mice. The other parameters were not significantly influenced by exogenous leptin, but there was a trend towards increased gluconeogenesis and glycogen storage due to leptin treatment. Enzyme activities of glucose and fat metabolism as well as the responses to leptin administration were sexually dimorphic. Discriminant analysis separated the control and the leptin-injected males and females to four distinct groups. Leptin seems to have minor but widespread effects on the energy metabolism of a nonmutant rodent. In nature, one function of leptin could be carbohydrate preservation.

Authors: Alvarado C.S., Cone R.S., Wagner J.V.
Title: Next generation FPSO: Combining production and gas utilisation
Authors with affiliations: Alvarado, C.S.; Cone, R.S.; Wagner, J.V.
Abstract: Several gas utilization options, including, liquefied natural gas (LNG), compressed natural gas (CNG), gas to liquids (GTL), and gas to wire (GTW), on a combined oil/gas production Floating Production Storage Offloading (FPSO) were evaluated. In addition to technical aspects, project execution issues for this new generation FPSO were also examined. Based on this work, the conditions that need to be addressed by the next generation FPSO were emphasized.

Authors: Lee S.G., Lee H.W., Lee J.W.
Title: Performance of underground rock storage system for heating and cooling of greenhouse
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural Engineering, Kyungpook National University, 1370 Sankyuk-Dong, Puk-Ku, Taegu 702-701, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, S.G., Department of Agricultural Engineering, Kyungpook National University, 1370 Sankyuk-Dong, Puk-Ku, Taegu 702-701, South Korea; Lee, H.W., Department of Agricultural Engineering, Kyungpook National University, 1370 Sankyuk-Dong, Puk-Ku, Taegu 702-701, South Korea; Lee, J.W., Department of Agricultural Engineering, Kyungpook National University, 1370 Sankyuk-Dong, Puk-Ku, Taegu 702-701, South Korea
Abstract: The development of technology to be able to reduce the energy cost is highly required in order to manage greenhouse profitably in South Korea. We have developed the underground rock storage system. The objective of this study was to evaluate the performance of this system for heating and cooling of greenhouse, respectively during winter and summer seasons. It was found that the average daytime temperature in the solar-heated greenhouse was the maximum 2°C lower than in the non-solar-heated greenhouse in cooling season while the nighttime temperature was the maximum 5°C high er in heating season. The humidity in the solar-heated greenhouse was always higher than the non-solar-heated greenhouse in both seasons. It was concluded that the underground rock storage system could reduce the energy expense for greenhouse cropping in summer and winter seasons.
Author Keywords: Air circulation fan; Airflow rate; Energy saving; Humidity; Temperature

Authors: Desprez Ph., Barrailh G., Moreau L., Pichon B., Jehoulet C.
Title: Ultracapacitors: A power buffer in satellites

Authors with affiliations: Desprez, Ph., SAFT Direction de la Recherche, 111,113 bvd Alfred Daney, F - 33074 Bordeaux Cedex, France; Barrailh, G., SAFT Direction de la Recherche, 111,113 bvd Alfred Daney, F - 33074 Bordeaux Cedex, France; Moreau, L., SAFT Direction de la Recherche, 111,113 bvd Alfred Daney, F - 33074 Bordeaux Cedex, France; Pichon, B., SAFT Direction de la Recherche, 111,113 bvd Alfred Daney, F - 33074 Bordeaux Cedex, France; Jehoulet, C., SAFT Direction de la Recherche, 111,113 bvd Alfred Daney, F - 33074 Bordeaux Cedex, France
Abstract: In satellites, energy and power requirements can lead to oversize the energy source to fit the power demand and ensure cycle life requirements. Association of a new generation of ultracapacitors (UC), components of high specific power, and batteries is an attractive alternative to downsize the energy source. SAFT has developed 3500 Farad ultracapacitors characterised by specific power and energy at 2.5 V of 3 kW/kg and 4.7 Wh/kg respectively. The efficiency of an association between batteries and UC to lower the weight of the energy storage system has been evaluated for a given LEO satellite mission profile. The work has been realised under a CNES [1] contract.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Electric batteries; Electric potential; Electric resistance; Satellites; Power buffer; Ultracapacitors; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Rempke H., Noack E.
Title: Columbus power architecture and power bus stability
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: ASTRIUM GmbH, Space Infrastructure Division, Huenefeldstr. 1-5, 28199 Bremen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rempke, H., ASTRIUM GmbH, Space Infrastructure Division, Huenefeldstr. 1-5, 28199 Bremen, Germany; Noack, E., ASTRIUM GmbH, Space Infrastructure Division, Huenefeldstr. 1-5, 28199 Bremen, Germany
Abstract: The evolution of the Space Station power system resulted in a pre-regulated 160 Vdc primary power system and a fine-regulated 120 Vdc secondary power distribution. The secondary voltage is derived through transformer isolating and redundant pairs of DC-to-DC converter units (DDCU) suppling the various space station elements and so also the European APM. The decision for a 120 V power distribution has initiated the development of solid state power controllers (SSPC) in Europe and has also required intensive evaluation of protection realization and fault current investigation to maintain sufficient failure tolerance in the protection of the harness. The aspect of power bus stability was introduced through establishment of additional power quality requirements by NASA. ASTRIUM has developed a model of the APM power network on the basis of equipment level data and validation by tests on the integrated system. The model is used to demonstrate power bus stability.
Index Keywords: Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric power systems; Mathematical models; Space stations; Columbus power architecture; DC to DC converter units; Flywheel energy storage system; International space station; Power bus stability; Solid state power controller; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Barde H., Urruty C., Jaumes J.
Title: Evolutions of the Ariane 5 electrical power system
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Astrium S.A.S., 31 Avenues des Cosmonautes, 31402 Toulouse Cedex 4, France
Authors with affiliations: Barde, H., Astrium S.A.S., 31 Avenues des Cosmonautes, 31402 Toulouse Cedex 4, France; Urruty, C., Astrium S.A.S., 31 Avenues des Cosmonautes, 31402 Toulouse Cedex 4, France; Jaumes, J., Astrium S.A.S., 31 Avenues des Cosmonautes, 31402 Toulouse Cedex 4, France
Abstract: The future versions of the Ariane 5 European heavy launcher will require an evolution of its Electrical Power System (EPS) in order to cope with increased requirements in energy and power, associated with mission duration extension and equipment power demand. Since the initial design of the EPS, lithium based technologies have matured and are now considered as a replacement of the current Silver-Zinc (Ag-Zn) batteries, with expected benefits in terms of mass, cost and operational constraints. Candidate electrochemical couples are primary Li-SOCl2 and LiMnO2 cells, as well as secondary Li-ion. A compromise is to be found between energy and power, the primary cells being more energy capable, but limited in terms of peak power. Among the possible architectures, some are incorporating supercapacitors. This new family of components, intermediate between batteries and conventional capacitors, can greatly improve the overall EPS performance by allowing a primary lithium based architecture to achieve both high energy and power capability.
Author Keywords: Ariane 5; Battery; Electrical power system; Launcher; Lithium; Storage
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric potential; Electrochemistry; Lithium batteries; Electrical power systems; Silver-zinc batteries; Supercapacitors; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Gerlitz T.G.M., Gerlitz A.
Title: Effects of monovalent cations on phosphate accumulation and storage of the ectomycorrhizal fungus Suillus bovinus
Affiliations: University of Bremen, Fachbereich Biologie/Chemie, Martin-Ecks-Strasse 30, 28357 Bremen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gerlitz, T.G.M., University of Bremen, Fachbereich Biologie/Chemie, Martin-Ecks-Strasse 30, 28357 Bremen, Germany; Gerlitz, A., University of Bremen, Fachbereich Biologie/Chemie, Martin-Ecks-Strasse 30, 28357 Bremen, Germany
Abstract: Comparative in vivo 31P-NMR studies of the fungus Suillus bovinus (L.: Fr.) O. Kuntze in pure culture have produced interesting new data. To investigate the response of phosphate metabolism to a change in external monovalent cations, samples were exposed to a Hoagland solution containing different monovalent cations Li+, Na+, K+, or Rb+ at 10 mM concentration. A method of nutrient cycling during analysis where the cation was changed and the phosphate kept constant allowed us to determine the kinetics of phosphate accumulation, storage and incorporation into polyphosphate following exposure to the range of test cations. Different external monovalent cations had different effects upon changes in the content of both phosphate and polyphosphate. Treatment with Li+, Na+, or Rb+ resulted in a change in phosphate accumulation to 60, 73, and 107% and in content of the intracellular mobile polyphosphate (polyP) to 119, 112, and 94%, respectively, compared with the control taken as 100%. The effect of each cation is related to its position in the periodic table. Reversing this process, i.e., exchanging with K+, returned phosphate metabolism to normal. Although, the increase in depolarization of the cell membrane should affect the internal pH, fungal metabolism using energy requiring mechanisms appeared necessary to maintain the intracellular pH, Thus, increasing contents of mobile polyp were the consequence of an increasing energy demand. On the other hand, the increasing depolarization of the cell membrane following the sequence Rb+ < K+ < Na+ < Li+ inhibited the net Pi accumulation. Furthermore, it is postulated that the Pi accumulation was also regulated by the intra-cellular content in poly P.
Author Keywords: Ectomycorrhizal fungus; Monovalent cations; NMR; Phosphate accumulation; Polyphosphate; Suillus bovinus

Abstract: We grow epitaxial Tb (0 0 0 1) nanoparticles on Nb (1 1 0) surfaces under UHV conditions in a Stranski-Krastanov mode. After performing in situ chemical and structural characterization, we protect the particles with a Nb over-layer to perform ex situ SQUID hysteresis loop measurements. The saturation magnetization and the basal coercivity in the Tb particles are modified in comparison to bulk properties. © 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Metting F.B., Jacobs G.K., Amthor J.S., Dahlman R.
Title: Terrestrial Carbon Sequestration Potential
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Authors with affiliations: Metting, F.B.; Jacobs, G.K.; Amthor, J.S.; Dahlman, R.
Abstract: Fossil fuel and land use change have increased the atmospheric content of CO2 and other greenhouse gases that may be impacting climatic change. Storage of C in soils and plants has the potential to offset CO2 emissions to the atmosphere in the coming decades while new "clean" energy production and CO2 sequestration technologies are developed and deployed. Because they are economically important, have a rich history of directed research, and can be most easily managed, forests and croplands are best suited for application of existing and new technology to enhance terrestrial C sequestration in the near term. Estimates of the potential for enhanced C storage, even in the US, vary more than two-fold. In addition to proven management approaches, new management, chemical and biological technology have the potential to impact C storage. The need for basic research to improve fundamental understanding of natural phenomena controlling soil C sequestration and basic and applied R&D to bring new management and technology to the challenge was highlighted.

Authors: Qiu M., Lin L.Z., Zhang G.M., Wang Y.S., Xiao L.Y.
Title: Flux dynamic behavior inside HTS bulks under rotating magnetic field
Affiliations: Applied Superconductivity Division, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China; Department of Physics, Hebei University, Baoding 071002, Hebei Province, China
Authors with affiliations: Qiu, M., Applied Superconductivity Division, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China; Lin, L.Z., Applied Superconductivity Division, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China; Zhang, G.M., Applied Superconductivity Division, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China; Wang, Y.S., Applied Superconductivity Division, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China, Department of Physics, Hebei University, Baoding 071002, Hebei Province, China; Xiao, L.Y., Applied Superconductivity Division, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100080, China
Abstract: Melt texturing large-grain HTS materials has evolved in the last few years into a technology capable of producing large quantities of high-performance superconducting bulk materials. Such materials are used for developing novel engineering devices, such as high-speed bearing, flywheel system and motor. In these systems, however, it is very possible to generate rotating magnetic fields with the frequency higher than 50 Hz due to various inhomogeneities. Hence, the experimental investigation was presented on the change of the levitation force and the trapped-flux response of HTS bulks exposed to the rotating magnetic fields with different frequencies. Meanwhile, the experimental phenomena were qualitatively analyzed and discussed in this paper, based on HTS flux dynamics.
Author Keywords: Flux dynamics; HTS bulk; Rotating magnetic field

Authors: Hsiao F.Z., Hwang C.S., Chang C.H.
Title: Mechanical structure analysis of a compact superconducting wavelength shifter
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Ctr., Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Hsiao, F.Z., Synchrotron Radiation Research Ctr., Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan; Hwang, C.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Ctr., Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan; Chang, C.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Ctr., Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan
Abstract: A three-pole superconducting wavelength shifter (SWLS) cooled by a 1.5 W @ 4.2 K Gifford-McMahon cryocooler will be installed in SRRC's storage ring in the year 2002 to provide the synchrotron radiation light source with critical energy at 9 keV. This article shows the mechanical structure design of the cryogen-free SWLS. The three pairs of coils are supported in an aluminum-reinforced block and bonded by two iron return yokes. The poles are fixed to the return yoke and will move with the yoke. The finite element method is used to evaluate the stresses caused from the thermal contraction of materials and the coil's Lorentz force. The simulation result shows that the thermal stress of coil from 293 K to 4.2 K is too large and will cause the failure of the coil if the poles, the coils, and the aluminum support are all fixed together. The stress level is not reduced even the soft material is placed among the interfaces of these different parts. The reduction of the stress level is achieved by leaving a suitable clearance among these interfaces and allowing relative sliding motion between the return yoke and the coil, and between the coil and the aluminum support. Analysis results show that such a design will reduce the stress to a level of two to three times less.
Author Keywords: Mechanical design; Stress; Superconducting magnet; Thermal contraction
Index Keywords: Aluminum alloys; Computer simulation; Design; Finite element method; Heat conduction; Iron; Light sources; Storage rings; Stresses; Synchrotron radiation; Thermal stress; Thermodynamic properties; Mechanical design; Superconducting coil; Superconducting wavelength shifter; Thermal contraction; Superconducting magnets

Authors: Kim H.J., Seong K.C., Cho J.W., Lee E.Y., Kim S.W., Kwon Y.K., Ryu K.S., Ryu K.
Title: Fabrication and test of the model coil for a SMES
Affiliations: Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Department of Electrical Engineering, Chonnam National University, Kwangju, 500-757, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, H.J., Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Seong, K.C., Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Cho, J.W., Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Lee, E.Y., Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Kim, S.W., Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Kwon, Y.K., Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Ryu, K.S., Korea Electrotechnology Research Institute, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Ryu, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Chonnam National University, Kwangju, 500-757, South Korea
Abstract: For the development of a small-sized superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system we designed, fabricated and tested a model coil consisting of five coils with different features, e.g., winding tensions, bore diameters and materials, cooling channels. The results show that even in the highly prestressed small coil, about 70% of the coil's critical current is degraded. The quench currents of the coils with narrow cooling channels are two times as high as that of the coil without spacers. The test results also indicate that the usual training effect depends on the winding tensions of the coils but the quench characteristic does not change according to materials of the bobbin.
