Authors: Schwarz R., Louro P., Vygranenko Yu., Fernandes M., Vieira M., Schubert M.
Title: Memory effects in highly resistive p-i-n heterojunctions for optical applications
Affiliations: Electronics and Communications Department, ISEL, P-1949-014 Lisboa, Portugal; Departamento De Física, IST, P-1096 Lisboa, Portugal; Institut Für Physikalische Elektronik, IPE, Universität Stuttgart, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schwarz, R., Electronics and Communications Department, ISEL, P-1949-014 Lisboa, Portugal, Departamento De Física, IST, P-1096 Lisboa, Portugal; Louro, P., Electronics and Communications Department, ISEL, P-1949-014 Lisboa, Portugal; Vygranenko, Yu., Electronics and Communications Department, ISEL, P-1949-014 Lisboa, Portugal; Fernandes, M., Electronics and Communications Department, ISEL, P-1949-014 Lisboa, Portugal; Vieira, M., Electronics and Communications Department, ISEL, P-1949-014 Lisboa, Portugal; Schubert, M., Institut Für Physikalische Elektronik, IPE, Universität Stuttgart, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: Large area p-i-n diode structures based on amorphous hydrogenated silicon can be used as single element image sensors where the information is read out by a scanning laser beam. A high sensitivity is reached with silicon-carbon alloy contact layers. The higher defect density in the large band gap material is usually a problem for efficient carrier collection in solar cell applications. When used as an image sensor, however, the charge stored in deep defects represents an easy way to realize short-term image storage. In the case of a p-(Si:H)/i-(Si:H)/n-(SixC1-x:H) sensor structure we have measured a memory effect of approximately 1% after several minutes of image projection. Metastable sensor degradation is observed in accordance with the Staebler-Wronski effect. Fast degradation of sensor performance - corresponding to 90% erasable image storage capability - was studied in an unalloyed structure using a Nd:YAG laser system. The response can be modeled by a stretched exponential decay with parameters depending on the laser pulse energy. © 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Amorphous hydrogenated silicon; Diode structures; Scanning laser beam
Index Keywords: Amorphous silicon; Annealing; Charge carriers; Degradation; Electric conductivity; Energy gap; Image sensors; Laser beam effects; Laser pulses; Neodymium lasers; Optical image storage; Semiconductor device structures; Semiconductor diodes; Sensitivity analysis; Silanes; Solar cells; Memory effects; Heterojunctions

Authors: Wendel G.R.
Title: Hydraulic system configurations for improved efficiency
Affiliations: Southwest Research Institute
Authors with affiliations: Wendel, G.R., Southwest Research Institute
Abstract: The design and selection of a hydraulic system for a particular machine is based upon a variety of factors which include: functionality, performance, safety, cost, reliability, duty cycle, component availability, and efficiency. With higher fuel costs and requirements to reduce engine exhaust emissions, new hydraulic system configurations should be considered. Traditional hydraulic systems conssume an excessive amount of energy due to metering losses. A single pump usually supplies flow to multiple functions, with differing flow and pressure requirements resulting in excessive metering losses. The energy of mass and inertial loads is usually dissipated by metering losses. Opportunities exist for reducing metering losses by the use of multiple pumps and by using hydrostatic control of individual functions. Hydrostatic control also allows for energy recovery when used in conjunction with an energy storage system. These alternative configurations have the potential of reducing engine size and reducing emissions by reduced transients and lower overall power requirement. This paper will discuss the source of hydraulic system losses and recommend alternative configurations that can result in dramatic reductions in energy requirements. A dynamic simulation of an example machine will be presented with an improved hydraulic system, illustrating the potential for reduced losses and the ability to accomplish the same functionality and control performance. The benefits of the alternative configuration will be analyzed in comparison to the costs. Copyright © 2002 SAE International and NFPA.
Index Keywords: Costs; Exhaust systems (engine); Hydraulic machinery; Hydraulics; Alternative configurations; Control performance; Energy requirements; Energy storage systems; Exhaust emission; Multiple function; Power requirement; Reducing emissions; Hydraulic equipment

Authors: Guyonvarch G., Haller R., Lepetit L.
Title: The specific issues of climate control in stop&go vehicles
Affiliations: Valeo Climate Control, 8, rue Louis Lormand, 78321 LA VERRIERE cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Guyonvarch, G., Valeo Climate Control, 8, rue Louis Lormand, 78321 LA VERRIERE cedex, France; Haller, R., Valeo Climate Control, 8, rue Louis Lormand, 78321 LA VERRIERE cedex, France; Lepetit, L., Valeo Climate Control, 8, rue Louis Lormand, 78321 LA VERRIERE cedex, France
Abstract: The arising "Stop&Go" function contributes to the reduction of new cars fuel consumption. However, as the engine shuts off when the car stops, cabin heating and air conditioning cut off because they are belt driven. This paper first describes the cabin temperature evolution when it occurs. It shows that solutions must be found in order to guarantee passenger comfort maintaining. Different concepts are presented, built on fuel, electrical or thermal energy storage. A comparison is provided, showing that the latter should be preferred. The biggest remaining issue for long stops is storage itself. Copyright © 2002 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Automobile bodies; Heat storage; Passenger comfort; Temperature evolution; Fuel storage

Authors: Skov T., Borgos H.G., Halvorsen K.Å., Randen T., Sønneland L.
Title: Monitoring and characterization of a CO 2 storage site
Affiliations: Schlumberger Stavanger Research, Rob Arts, Netherlands Institute of Applied Geoscience TNO, National Geological Survey, Andy Chadwick, British Geological Survey, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Skov, T., Schlumberger Stavanger Research, Rob Arts, Netherlands Institute of Applied Geoscience TNO, National Geological Survey, Andy Chadwick, British Geological Survey, Norway; Borgos, H.G., Schlumberger Stavanger Research, Rob Arts, Netherlands Institute of Applied Geoscience TNO, National Geological Survey, Andy Chadwick, British Geological Survey, Norway; Halvorsen, K.Å., Schlumberger Stavanger Research, Rob Arts, Netherlands Institute of Applied Geoscience TNO, National Geological Survey, Andy Chadwick, British Geological Survey, Norway; Randen, T., Schlumberger Stavanger Research, Rob Arts, Netherlands Institute of Applied Geoscience TNO, National Geological Survey, Andy Chadwick, British Geological Survey, Norway; Sønneland, L., Schlumberger Stavanger Research, Rob Arts, Netherlands Institute of Applied Geoscience TNO, National Geological Survey, Andy Chadwick, British Geological Survey, Norway
Abstract: Since 1996 CO 2 has been injected into the Utsira Sand, a saline aquifer at a depth of approx. 1000m. The CO 2 , sealed by several thin shale layers, has modified the impedance contrast and thereby created visible time-lapse effects on the seismic. These thin CO 2 “clouds” are mapped in detail from the time-lapse seismic data (1994, 1999 and 2001) using Spectral Energy Difference (SED) attributes. From these attributes, linear structures interpreted as flow boundaries become apparent inside some of the clouds. Observations of old (non-injected) gas accumulations in the overburden where mapped by an attribute classification. Motivated by positions of potentially deformed zones above highly compacted mud volcanoes, possible gas leakage paths from the deeper Sleipner Field was investigated. Leakage paths through the thick shale layers in the overburden are important regarding the future distribution of CO 2 . No obvious leakage correlation was found. Instead, old gas in the overburden seems to be trapped in glacial related sediments and structures. © 2002 SEG Annual Meeting. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Yoshida A.
Title: Capacitors and micropower systems
Affiliations: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., 3-1-1 Yagumonakamachi, Moriguchi-shi, Osaka  570-0005, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshida, A., Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., Ltd., 3-1-1 Yagumonakamachi, Moriguchi-shi, Osaka  570-0005, Japan
Abstract: An electric double-layer capacitor (EDLC) is an energy storage device, in which an electric charge is stored in the electric double layer formed at the interface between carbon materials and electrolytic solutions when dc voltage is applied. The capacitor has a pair of polarizable electrodes with collector electrodes, a separator, and an electrolytic solution. The capacitor is charged and the electrical energy stored in the capacitor is discharged at loads. Since we started to produce EDLCs in 1978, they have been widely used as memory back-up devices in many electrical appliances, for example, VCRs, cameras, etc. Many studies on the capacitors have been carried out in correlation with physical and chemical properties of carbon electrode materials. © 2002 by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Bharadwaja S.S.N., Victor P., Venkateswarulu P., Krupanidhi S.B.
Title: Ac transport studies of la-modified antiferroelectric lead zirconate thin films
Source title: Physical Review B - Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
Affiliations: Materials Research Center, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India; EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Bharadwaja, S.S.N., Materials Research Center, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India, EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland; Victor, P., Materials Research Center, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India; Venkateswarulu, P., Materials Research Center, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India; Krupanidhi, S.B., Materials Research Center, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India
Abstract: In recent times antiferroelectric thin-film material compositions have been identified as one of the most significant thin films for development of devices such as high charge storage, charge couplers/decouplers, and high strain microelectromechanical systems. Thus, understanding the dielectric and electrical properties under an ac signal drive in these antiferroelectric thin-film compositions, such as lead zirconate thin films, and the effect of donor doping on them is very necessary. For this purpose, thin films of antiferroelectric lead zirconate and La-modified lead zirconate thin films with mole % concentrations of 0, 3, 5, and 9 have been deposited by pulsed excimer laser ablation. The dielectric and hysteresis properties have confirmed that with a gradual increase of the La content, the room-temperature antiferroelectric lead zirconate thin films can be modified into ferroelectric and paraelectric phases. ac electrical studies revealed that the polaronic related hopping conduction is responsible for the charge transport phenomenon in these films. With a La content of 3 mole % in pure lead zirconate, the conductivity of the films has been reduced and followed by an increase of its conductivity for a 3% addition of La to lead zirconate thin films. The polaronic activation energies are also found to follow a similar trend as that of the conductivity. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Hamrle J., Ferré J., Nývlt M.
Title: In-depth resolution of the magneto-optical Kerr effect in ferromagnetic multilayers
Source title: Physical Review B - Condensed Matter and Materials Physics
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physique des Solides, UMR CNRS 8502, Université Paris-XI, Orsay, F-91405, France; Institute of Physics, Charles University, Ke Karlovu 3, CZ-121 16, Praha 2, Czech Republic; Laboratoire de Physique des Solides, UMR CNRS 8502, Université Paris-XI, Orsay, F-91405, France; Institute of Physics, Charles University, Ke Karlovu 3, Praha 2, CZ-121 16, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Hamrle, J., Laboratoire de Physique des Solides, UMR CNRS 8502, Université Paris-XI, Orsay, F-91405, France, Institute of Physics, Charles University, Ke Karlovu 3, CZ-121 16, Praha 2, Czech Republic; Ferré, J., Laboratoire de Physique des Solides, UMR CNRS 8502, Université Paris-XI, Orsay, F-91405, France; Nývlt, M., Institute of Physics, Charles University, Ke Karlovu 3, Praha 2, CZ-121 16, Czech Republic
Abstract: How does one determine the magnetization state and hysteresis loop corresponding to one of the ferromagnetic (FM) layers located at a given depth in a stack of FM/non-FM layers by means of the magneto-optical Kerr effect? For this purpose the representation of the Kerr effect in the complex rotation-ellipticity plane is introduced. A depth sensitivity function controlling the Kerr effect is defined and its dependence on the photon energy and angle of incidence is studied. A general way to determine the in-depth location of the FM layer, from which the Kerr signal originates, is proposed. In the case of a FM bilayer structure, previous proposed solutions are discussed within a unified formalism. For a system with three or more FM layers two approaches are proposed to extract selectively the magneto-optical signals originating at individual FM layers: the parallel Kerr vector and cascade numerical projection methods. These methods are successively checked experimentally on simple multilayer structures. Finally, on the basis of the developed approaches a readout solution for multivalued magneto-optical recording in a four-storage-layer structure is proposed. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics

Abstract: The vibrational relaxation of [Formula Presented] molecules from a conventional plasma ion source is studied performing Coulomb explosion imaging on the ions extracted from a storage ring after variable times of storage. Storage for 2 s is found sufficient for radiative relaxation of the breathing excitation and the fragment velocity distribution in the breathing coordinate then agrees well with simulations based on the calculated ground-state wave function. The radiative decay of the two lowest pure breathing levels [Formula Presented] and [Formula Presented] is seen to be considerably faster than expected from rotationless calculations. Assuming a high rotational excitation of the [Formula Presented] ions, as suggested already in earlier experiments, the theoretical transition probabilities of the University College London line list for [Formula Presented] [L. Neale, S. Miller, and J. Tennyson, Astrophys. J. 464, 516 (1996)] can explain the increase of the vibrational cooling rates and reproduce the observed decay curve for the lowest breathing-excited level, confirming the absolute transition probabilities of these line tables. The observations give evidence for a quasistable population of high-lying rotational levels in the stored ion beam, relevant for the interpretation of storage ring measurements on the rate coefficients for dissociative recombination of [Formula Presented] ions with low-energy electrons. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Fujita R., Nakamura H., Kawada C., Kondo N.
Title: Development of pyro-metallurgical process for end crops of magnox spent fuel
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: Power and Industrial Systems Research and Center, Toshiba Corporation, 4-1 Ukishimacho, Kawasaki-ku, 210-0862, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Fujita, R., Power and Industrial Systems Research and Center, Toshiba Corporation, 4-1 Ukishimacho, Kawasaki-ku, 210-0862, Japan; Nakamura, H., Power and Industrial Systems Research and Center, Toshiba Corporation, 4-1 Ukishimacho, Kawasaki-ku, 210-0862, Japan; Kawada, C., Power and Industrial Systems Research and Center, Toshiba Corporation, 4-1 Ukishimacho, Kawasaki-ku, 210-0862, Japan; Kondo, N., Power and Industrial Systems Research and Center, Toshiba Corporation, 4-1 Ukishimacho, Kawasaki-ku, 210-0862, Japan
Abstract: At the Tokai-1 magnox nuclear power station, end fittings are cropped from irradiated magnox fuel elements. These end crops stored in alkaline water for several years prior to planned grating in cement within drums for further storage and eventual disposal. This study proposes a new pyro-metallurgical process to reduce the waste volume of transuranium elements(TRUs) of magnox end crops. The process combines melt separation and electro refining in molten salts. The feasibility of the new pyro-metallurgical process has been confirmed experimentally1). This paper outlines the study of the separation mechanism of magnox alloy from uranium by electrorefining in molten salts. The decontamination factor (DF) of magnox alloy from uranium in electrorefining in molten salts was estimated to be more than 104. The electrochemical behaviors of U and Mg in KCl-LiCl eutectic salt were analyzed using cyclic voltammetry. The redox potential difference between U and Mg was about 250mV, which is much larger than the 80mV value that was estimated from thermodynamic data for standard states. U was separated from Mg and selectively deposited on the solid cathode in molten salts. © 2002 Atomic Energy Society of Japan.
Author Keywords: Cyclic voltammogram; Magnox fuel; Pyro-metallurgical process; Transuranium element waste

Authors: Hudelot J.-P., Chabert C., Chauvin J.-P., Fougeras P., Perret G., Genin X., Leorier C., Moulinier J.-M.
Title: The OSMOSE experimental program in MINERVE for the qualification of the integral cross sections of actinides
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: CEA Cadamche, DEN/DER, Saint Paul lez Durance, 13108, France; CEA VALRHÔ — site de Marcoule, DEN/DRCP, BP171, Bagnols-sur-Cèze, 30207, France

Abstract: Conjointly to the long term or sub-surface storage studies, an important effort is made on plutonium management and waste incineration in existing or innovative systems. In support to these studies, specific neutron integral experiments have been defined and in particular in the critical MINERVE facility of the CEA Cadarache. The OSMOSE program will be performed between 2003 and 2009. It deals with qualifying the integral cross sections of actinides appearing in reactor and fuel cycle physics, especially for multi-recycling of plutonium. Reactivity worth of several samples containing separated actinides from 232Th to 245Cm will be measured by an oscillation technique related to the perturbation theory with an accuracy better than 3%. Experiments will cover a wide range of neutron spectra, from thermal spectrum to fast spectrum. © 2014 Atomic Energy Society of Japan.
Author Keywords: Actinides; Cross section; MINERVE facility; Oscillation; Reactivity worth

Authors: Maeda S., Aoyama T.
Title: Decay heat of fast reactor spent fuel
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: Experimental Reactor Division, Irradiation Center, Oarai Engineering Center Japan Nuclear Cycle Development Institute, 4002 Narita, Oarai, Ibaraki, 311-1393, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Maeda, S., Experimental Reactor Division, Irradiation Center, Oarai Engineering Center Japan Nuclear Cycle Development Institute, 4002 Narita, Oarai, Ibaraki, 311-1393, Japan; Aoyama, T., Experimental Reactor Division, Irradiation Center, Oarai Engineering Center Japan Nuclear Cycle Development Institute, 4002 Narita, Oarai, Ibaraki, 311-1393, Japan
Abstract: Decay heat from JOYO Mk-II spent fuel subassemblies was measured to obtain experimental data and to improve the accuracy of related calculations. The measurement was taken in the JOYO spent fuel storage pond. The fuel burn-up was approximately 66 GWd/t and the cooling time was between 40 and 385 days. The decay heat was calculated with the ORIGEN2 code using the JENDL-3.2 cross section library and the JNDC-V2 decay data and fission yield data library. The fuel power used as an input to ORIGEN2 was calculated by the MAGI core management code system. The ratios between calculated and experimental values were between 0.94 and 0.89 and decreased with a longer cooling time. This systematic discrepancy is not fully understood, but the change with cooling time appears to be due to the actinide decay heat uncertainty. This indicated that cross sections of actinides are important to evaluate decay heat accurately. © 2014 Atomic Energy Society of Japan.
Author Keywords: Decay Heat; Fast Reactor; JOYO; MOX; ORIGEN2; Spent Fuel

Authors: Renard E., Rogozkin B.
Title: About applicability of purex-technology to fast breeder reactor mixed (u-pu) monocarbide and mononitride fuels reprocessing
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: A.A.Bochvar All-Russian Scientific Research Institute ofInorganic Materials - VNIINM, POB 369, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation

Abstract: Using the fresh FBR mixed (U, Pu) dioxide, monocarbide and mononitride fuel pieces (pellets), the dissolution (HNO3), solution digestion (storage) and extractive plutonium recovery (TBP) operations were studied in high radiation conditions.lt was established, that well known nitric acid procedure of mixed U-Pu dioxide dissolution is applicable to advanced breeder fuels. The extractive procedure of the “classic” PUREX-technology (out of Pu(VI) build-up, extraction kinetics and equilibrium view-points) can be used for quantitative actinoids recovery from above mentioned fuel solutions. The possible problems as regards spent advanced fuel reprocessing are discussed as well. © 2002 Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All Rights Reserved.
Author Keywords: Carbide; Fast breeder reactor; Nitride; Plutonium; PUREX; Solvent extraction; Spent fuel; Uranium

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Network data storage
Abstract: The geographical information system (GIS), named EnerGISe, is web-based intranet mapping application which is being used in Brisbane-based energy firm Energex. The system is used to locate network assets for planning, design, construction, or operation and maintenance of the electricity networks. The EnerGISe system uses ESRI's ArcView Internet Map Server (AVIMS) product to link it to the electrical network data.

Authors: Liu W., Chu X., Jiang X.
Title: Design and analysis of CSAF based on SMES
Source title: PowerCon 2002 - 2002 International Conference on Power System Technology, Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, W., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Chu, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Jiang, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: A line interactive superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system with a current source converter designed for active current harmonic filtering is described. The system features an algorithm of current space vector modulation, which is suitable for implementing on microprocessors and digital signal processors (DSP). An active control method is proposed to damp oscillations with the LC filter. The performances of the system based on a 12-pulse IGBT current source converter were confirmed by simulations. It is shown that the system has good dynamic as well as static characteristics. Its response time is less than 5 milliseconds and the current after compensation is essentially sinusoidal with the total harmonic distortion (THD) of less than 1%. © 2002 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Current source active filter (CSAF); LC filter; SMES; space vector modulation

Authors: Cadenas O., Megson G.
Title: Improving mW/MHz ratio in FPGAs pipelined designs
Source title: Proceedings - Euromicro Symposium on Digital System Design: Architectures, Methods and Tools, DSD 2002
Affiliations: University of Reading, School of Computer Science, Cybernetics and Electronic Engineering, PO Box 225, Whiteknights, Reading, RG6 6AY, United Kingdom

Abstract: This paper presents a simple clocking technique to migrate classical synchronous pipelined designs to a synchronous functional-equivalent alternative system in the context of FPGAs. When the new pipelined design runs at the same throughput of the original design, around 30% better mW/MHz ratio was observed in Virtex-based FPGA circuits. The evaluation is done using a simple but representative and practical systolic design as an example. The technique in essence is a simple replacement of the clocking mechanism for the pipe-storage elements; however no extra design effort is needed. The results show that the proposed technique allows immediate power and area-time savings of existing designs rather than exploring potential benefits by a new logic design to the problem using the classic pipeline clocking mechanism. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Ho N.B., Meng C.S.
Title: The effect of postmortem freezing storage on the tensile properties of tendon
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Annual Northeast Bioengineering Conference, NEBEC
Affiliations: School of Mechanical and Prod. Eng., Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Ho, N.B., School of Mechanical and Prod. Eng., Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; Meng, C.S., School of Mechanical and Prod. Eng., Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: The objective of this study is to elucidate the influence of postmortem freezing storage on the tensile properties of tendons. Chicken Flexor Digitorum Profundus (FDP) tendons were stored at 0°C, -20°C and -40°C between 0 to 90 days. No statistically significant changes was found in the cross-sectional area following freezing storage. Tensile tests were performed every 5 days and the results showed that tensile properties of digital flexor tendon, as represented by stress-strain curves, Ultimate Tensile Strength, Strain at Maximum Stress, Elastic Modulus and Energy at Maximum Stress, were not affected during freezing storage at 0°C, -20°C and -40°C for up to 90 days. Comparison between groups of same duration showed no discernable differences in tensile properties after storage at 0°C, -20°C and -40°C. Therefore, we conclude that freezing storage at sub-zero temperature up to 90 days does not alter the tensile properties of digital flexor tendon.

Abstract: Electron-ion recombination spectra of the Li-like ion [Formula Presented] in the energy range [Formula Presented] from two different ion storage rings are presented, showing excellent agreement. The experimental results are compared with a calculated spectrum, obtained by combination of relativistic many-body methods and complex rotation, and the agreement is found to be very good. The recombination spectrum in the studied energy region is determined by the [Formula Presented] dielectronic recombination resonances. The lowest-energy resonances are found around 10 meV, and include one broad resonance overlapping the threshold. The recombination rate coefficients are, even in this region, very well accounted for by the calculation. It is further shown that the nonrelativistically allowed resonances contribute to less than 60% of the integrated rate coefficients in the specified energy range. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Teramoto Y., Urakami H., Kohno S., Shimomura N., Katsuki S., Akiyama H.
Title: Wire array z-pinch experiment on inductive energy storage generator ASO-X
Source title: BEAMS 2002 - 14th International Conference on High-Power Particle Beams
Affiliations: Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, 2-39-1 Kurokami, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan; Ariake National College of Technology, 150 Higashihagio-machi, Omuta, Fukuoka 836-8585, Japan; Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Tokushima, 2-1 Minamijosanjima, Tokushima 770-8506, Japan; Ushio Inc., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Teramoto, Y., Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, 2-39-1 Kurokami, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan, Ushio Inc., Japan; Urakami, H., Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, 2-39-1 Kurokami, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan; Kohno, S., Ariake National College of Technology, 150 Higashihagio-machi, Omuta, Fukuoka 836-8585, Japan; Shimomura, N., Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Tokushima, 2-1 Minamijosanjima, Tokushima 770-8506, Japan; Katsuki, S., Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, 2-39-1 Kurokami, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan; Akiyama, H., Graduate School of Science and Technology, Kumamoto University, 2-39-1 Kurokami, Kumamoto 860-8555, Japan
Abstract: Wire-array z-pinch experiment was carried out on ASO-X generator. ASO-X is a 3-stage inductive voltage adder, and works as the inductive energy storage system with the plasma opening switch. The array diameter was 3 cm, and had 36 tungsten wires of 20 μm in diameter and 1 cm long. Taking time-resolved pictures of imploding plasma and observing x-ray signals, it was investigated that how the wire-array implodes for the different current rise times. For the x-ray diagnostics, the X-ray diode (XRD) and the diamond detector were used. When the current rise time is slow, the peaks of XRD and diamond detector were observed at the different time. In the time-resolved picture, the implosion of precursor plasma was observed followed by the main implosion. The strong kink instability was observed when the pinched plasma was completely created. When the current rise time is fast, no kink instability was observed. However, the implosion did not fully cover between the electrodes. The diamond detector did not detect the x-ray, although the XRD detected. © 2002 AIP.
Index Keywords: Diamonds; Energy storage; Explosions; Particle beams; Pinch effect; Plasma diagnostics; Plasma stability; Wire; X ray diffraction; X rays; Current rise time; Diamond detectors; Inductive energy storage; Inductive voltage adders; Plasma opening switch; Precursor plasmas; Wire array Z-pinch; X-ray diagnostics; X ray detectors

Authors: Zhou X., Zhang H.
Title: The technology of external RF power supply for small caliber fuze
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Industrial Technology
Affiliations: Mechanical School, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, 210094, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, X., Mechanical School, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, 210094, China; Zhang, H., Mechanical School, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, 210094, China
Abstract: This paper presents the novel technology of external RF power supply for small caliber fuze. A storage capacitor of fuze is charged via a detachable inductive link, which of secondary coil would be implanted in fuze, primary coil would be placed on the launcher. The energy stored in the capacitor would power fuze circuits and detonating device. In order to improve both charge current and power transfer efficiency via a low coupling coefficient inductive link, class E power amplifier with the self inductance of the primary coil and compensation of the leakage inductance of secondary coil are proposed. The results of a prototype with experiment are presented and show this technologic scheme is feasible. © 2002 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Class E power amplifier; Detachable inductive link; Fuze
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Inductance; Robotics; Charge current; Class E power amplifiers; Fuze; Inductive link; Leakage inductance; Power transfer efficiency; Secondary coils; Storage capacitor; Power amplifiers

Authors: García O., Cobos J.A., Uceda J.
Title: High efficiency pfc converter to meet EN61000-3-2 and A14
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Industrial Electronics
Affiliations: Universidad Politécnica de Madrid, E.T.S.I.I., Div. de Ingeniería Electrónica, José Gutiérrez Abascal, 2, 28006 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: García, O., Universidad Politécnica de Madrid, E.T.S.I.I., Div. de Ingeniería Electrónica, José Gutiérrez Abascal, 2, 28006 Madrid, Spain; Cobos, J.A., Universidad Politécnica de Madrid, E.T.S.I.I., Div. de Ingeniería Electrónica, José Gutiérrez Abascal, 2, 28006 Madrid, Spain; Uceda, J., Universidad Politécnica de Madrid, E.T.S.I.I., Div. de Ingeniería Electrónica, José Gutiérrez Abascal, 2, 28006 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: The introduction of Regulation EN61000-3-2 few years ago has forced power supply engineers to design AC/DC converters that meet the limits imposed by it. As a consequence and considering that unity power factor is not required, many alternatives to the classical two-stage approach have been proposed reducing the cost of the power supply, especially in low power applications. The recent publication of the Amendment 14, that modifies the definition of the Class D of EN61000-3-2, may change the scope again. In this paper, a new AC/DC converter is proposed. This converter has been designed to improve the efficiency over the classical two-stage approach by improving the. energy management. Thus, output power is processed 1.2 times instead of twice. Moreover, the voltage on the storage capacitor is not very sensitive to input voltage variations making easy the optimisation of the converter. The line current has been analysed and a trade-off between efficiency and distortion has been found. © 2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Industrial electronics; Ac/dc converters; High-efficiency; Input voltages; Low power application; PFC converters; Storage capacitor; Two stage approach; Unity power factor; Rectifying circuits

Affiliations: Department of Speech, Music Hearing, KTH (Royal Institute of Technology), 100 44 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Kim, M.Y., Department of Speech, Music Hearing, KTH (Royal Institute of Technology), 100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Kleijn, W.B., Department of Speech, Music Hearing, KTH (Royal Institute of Technology), 100 44 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: If the signal statistics are given, direct vector quantization (DVQ) according to these statistics provides the highest coding efficiency, but requires unmanageable storage requirements. In code-excited linear predictive (CELP) coding, a single "compromise" codebook is trained in the prediction residual-domain and the space-filling and shape advantages of vector quantization (VQ) are utilized in a non-optimal, average sense. In this paper, we propose a Karhunen-Loève Transform (KLT)-based classified VQ (CVQ), where the space-filling advantage can be utilized since the Voronoi-region shape is not affected by the KLT. The memory and shape advantages can be also used, since each codebook is designed based on a narrow class of KLT-domain statistics. Our experiments show that the KLT-CVQ provides a higher SNR than CELP and (single-codebook) DVQ, and has a computational complexity similar to DVQ and much lower than CELP. Storage requirements are modest because of the energy concentration property of the KLT.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computational complexity; Mathematical transformations; Signal encoding; Signal to noise ratio; Speech coding; Speech synthesis; Statistical methods; Vector quantization; Analysis-by-synthesis; Code-excited linear predictive coding; Direct Vector Quantization; Karhunen-Loeve Transform; Linear predictive coding; Speech analysis

Authors: Asali K.
Title: Developing solar: PV solar system markets in Africa
Affiliations: Kyocera Fineceramics GmbH, Germany; Kyocera Fineceramics GmbH, Fritz-Mucller-Strassc 107, 73730 Esslingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Asali, K., Kyocera Fineceramics GmbH, Germany, Kyocera Fineceramics GmbH, Fritz-Mucller-Strassc 107, 73730 Esslingen, Germany
Abstract: The studies were conducted to asses the potential of the African market in renewable energy utilization. In many African countries, companies have developed partnerships with local companies to offer energy and alleviate quality of life in all parts of African continents. Excellent ambient conditions such as solar radiations in most regions lead many non-government organizations (NGO) as well as the government to focus on environment friendly technologies. It is recommended that besides local partner companies, a commercially developable infrastructure is necessary to achieve positive long-term effects.

Authors: Hassid S.
Title: The effusivity model for multi-layer walls
Affiliations: Environ./Water Rsrc. Eng. Technion, Israel Inst. of Technology, Haifa 32000, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Hassid, S., Environ./Water Rsrc. Eng. Technion, Israel Inst. of Technology, Haifa 32000, Israel
Abstract: The effusivity model for describing the time response of walls to changes in heat flux is extended to two-layer walls using an integral method. Based on a simple integral method, shown to obtain results close to the ones of the effusivity method for the one-layer case, a simple correction of the expressions for temperature variation due to a step change in the heat flux is obtained. The results are shown to be in good agreement with the exact solution. It is shown that, depending on the ratio of the effusivities of the two layers, significant deviations from the results obtained using the effusivity of the outer layer can be expected.
Author Keywords: Energy conservation; Energy storage; Passive solar buildings
Index Keywords: Heat flux; Integral equations; Temperature; Effusivity; Expression correction; Temperature variation; Walls (structural partitions); Energy efficiency; Heat flux; Heat transfer

Authors: Calle C.A., Luce A.
Title: CORA project - Vitrification of intermediate level liquid radioactive wastes in Saluggia ENEA Research Centre
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: ENEA CR Saluggia, Saluggia, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Calle, C.A., ENEA CR Saluggia, Saluggia, Italy; Luce, A., ENEA CR Saluggia, Saluggia, Italy
Abstract: The EUREX reprocessing pilot plant, at ENEA Research Centre, Saluggia (VC - Italy), stores 113 m3 of intermediate level liquid waste and 110 m3 of low level liquid waste, originating from the past reprocessing campaigns. Conditioning of the above wastes, for the purpose of final disposal, has been planned in a new installation for the solidification of both intermediate and low level wastes at Saluggia site. The installation, under design, has been named CORA Plant (COnditioning of RAdioactive wastes). Direct Vitrification process using cold crucible melter (CCM) developed by CEA of Marcoule, has been chosen as conditioning technology for a mix of most active wastes and cementation for secondary low level waste produced during vitrification. A boro-silicate glass matrix has been selected with a specific nominal chemical composition adapted to liquid waste matrix. Characterisation work of this specific glass is under progress. CORA has been presented to regulatory authority has a modification of a pilot reprocessing Eurex plant. Vitrification equipment and glass canister interim storage facility of CORA Plant will be housed inside the existing building of Eurex facility properly modified. Cementation unit inside a new building located in a near external yard. A description of the waste management scheme, as well as a brief description of adopted technologies, chemical glass composition and updated schedule of CORA project is presented in this paper.
Index Keywords: Borosilicate glass; Composition; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste vitrification; Concentration (process); Gamma rays; Pilot plants; Precipitation (chemical); Project management; Radioisotopes; Refractory materials; Solidification; Thermal effects; Cementation; Liquid radioactive wastes; Cementation units; Thermal energy; Radioactive wastes; Radioactive waste vitrification

Authors: Loiseaux J.-M.
Title: Primary energy needs and greenhouse effect increase: What can be done?
Source title: International Journal of Energy Technology and Policy
Affiliations: Inst. des Sciences Nucléaires, CNRS-IN2P3/Universite Joseph Fourier, 53 avenue des martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 38026, France
Authors with affiliations: Loiseaux, J.-M., Inst. des Sciences Nucléaires, CNRS-IN2P3/Universite Joseph Fourier, 53 avenue des martyrs, Grenoble Cedex 38026, France
Abstract: Primary energy needs are estimated to grow by a factor of 2.3 from now to 2050. At the same time, the necessary reduction of CO2 emissions may lead to a drastic cut in the use of fossil fuels. To avoid an energy shortage, a very large share of energy production has to be met by renewable energies or nuclear energy. These two kinds of energy have specific environmental impacts and constraints which are briefly discussed. A significant contribution of renewable energies implies that large land areas and a good energy storage technology are available while nuclear energy cannot be sufficiently extended using the present PWR reactor technology. Using an optimised new option for energy production, it is shown that nuclear energy can provide a significant share of energy needs. But we point out that it is no longer the time to discuss which energy has to be developed but to develop both at the appropriate significantly increased production level.
Author Keywords: CO2 emission; Energy; Energy shortage; Environmental impact; Fossil fuel; Greenhouse effect; Hydrogen technology; Nuclear energy; Primary energy needs; Renewable energy; Scenarios
Index Keywords: carbon emission; emission control; energy market; greenhouse effect

Authors: Wang W.-H., Lin M.-H., Lu T.-K., His W.-C., Huang M.-H., Tsai H.-F., Chuang J.-M., Wang S.-Y.
Title: Study of cyclability enhanced by nitrogen doping for digital versatile disk-random access memory media
Source title: Japanese Journal of Applied Physics, Part 1: Regular Papers and Short Notes and Review Papers
Authors with affiliations: Wang, W.-H.; Lin, M.-H.; Lu, T.-K.; His, W.-C.; Huang, M.-H.; Tsai, H.-F.; Chuang, J.-M.; Wang, S.-Y.
Abstract: A nitrogen-doping process is commonly applied to improve the cyclability of phase change optical disks, but it is still difficult to attain the required number of overwrite cycles of 106 for digital versatile disk-random access memory (DVD-RAM) disks. In this study, we used a nitrogen doping process to prepare 2.6 GB DVD-RAM disks and successfully achieved more than 106 overwrite cycles of solely using by a four layer structure. The cyclability was found to increase with increasing nitrogen content in the N2/Ar sputtering gas flow then decrease with a further increase in the nitrogen content. Nucleation theory is used to explain the phenomena.

Authors: Hayes D.
Title: Full of pumped potential
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Authors with affiliations: Hayes, D.
Abstract: At March 2001, Japan's hydro power stations, including pumped storage and conventional hydro schemes, totalled 44,800MW of installed capacity. However, hydroelectric generation has fallen as a proportion of total power generation over the past 20 years as the country has looked to nuclear power, LNG, gas and coal-fired generation to meet electricity demand. Nonetheless, pumped storage projects have grown rapidly since the 1970's, and will continue to do so as storage capacity is being developed to match the planned increase in nuclear and coal-fired generation. Power companies plan to construct new pumped storage schemes totalling 6400MW by 2010, and a further 7400MW will be built between 2011 and 2020.
Index Keywords: Dams; Gases; Liquefied natural gas; Nuclear energy; Pumped storage; Water power; hydroelectric power plant; pumped storage; resource assessment

Authors: Kumamoto Y., Noda Y.
Title: Measurements of effective doses of natural background level of neutrons with etched-track detectors
Affiliations: Division of Radiation Research, Natl. Inst. of Radiological Sciences, Anagawa 4-9-1, Inage-ku, Chiba, 263-8555, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kumamoto, Y., Division of Radiation Research, Natl. Inst. of Radiological Sciences, Anagawa 4-9-1, Inage-ku, Chiba, 263-8555, Japan; Noda, Y., Division of Radiation Research, Natl. Inst. of Radiological Sciences, Anagawa 4-9-1, Inage-ku, Chiba, 263-8555, Japan
Abstract: An etched-track method was applied for a measurement of the effective dose of natural background neutrons. Ten assemblies of polycarbonate film and 10B were placed at the center of a rem-counter type moderator. The assemblies were put in an air-tight container in order to avoid a continuous contribution from radon. Electrochemical etching was adopted. The sensitivity of the detector was 0.21 ± 0.02 μSv pit-1 cm2. After a period of storage of 4.3 y, the number of recorded artifact pits in the films corresponded to an effective dose rate of 0.8 ± 0.2 μSv y-1. The effective dose rate of natural background neutrons was 18.1 ± 3.6 μSv year-1 for the same period, with an artifact dose being subtracted. The total net number of etched-track pits of the present detector was 75 ± 15 when used for measuring an effective dose of natural background level neutrons for 1 mo, which gives enough counting statistics. The method can thus be applied for monitoring the effective dose of neutrons around nuclear sites and high-energy accelerator facilities.
Author Keywords: Detector, etched-track; Dose equivalent; Monitoring, environmental; Neutrons
Index Keywords: polycarbonate; radon; article; artifact; dose response; electrochemical analysis; energy; environmental monitoring; film; measurement; neutron; neutron dosimetry; priority journal; radiation detector; radioactive waste processing

Authors: Jellema J., Tchistiakov A.
Title: Implementation of ISO-14000 standards in routine environmental management of oil and gas fields by means of GIS and remote sensing
Authors with affiliations: Jellema, J.; Tchistiakov, A.
Abstract: All industrialized countries face the challenge to combine long term, low cost energy supply and continuous reduction of the environmental impact. Therefore the strategic target of the HSE standards is the sustainable and environmentally sound development of the Earth's energy resources. The main goal of our research is the development of a new environmental management methodology supported by software tools for implementation of the ISO-14000 standards in oil and gas operations. On one hand, this methodology has to be generic; on the other hand, the proposed methods of environmental impact assessment must be applicable for each specific situation. We have reinterpreted the ISO environmental monitoring model in terms of remote sensing survey and GIS models. Besides storage of the scalable earth surface and underground information, the methodology and suggested software tools allow for the modelling of the interaction between engineering objects and the environment during full life cycle of oil and gas fields starting from their exploration until their abandonment. The remote sensing methods reviewed in this article, as well as the suggested methodology, can be applied for a wide range of targets in different regions. Some examples are the monitoring of pipelines in the North Sea or Mexican Gulf, control of pipeline security or vegetation degradation in tropical countries, as well as monitoring of oil operations in remote Arctic locations.
Index Keywords: Computer aided software engineering; Environmental impact; Environmental protection; Geographic information systems; Life cycle; Natural gas fields; Offshore pipelines; Oil fields; Remote sensing; Standards; Sustainable development; Environmental management; Oil and gas fields; Petroleum industry

Authors: Kim Y.-J., Hong T.-W.
Title: Hydrogenation properties of partially remelted Mg-Ni alloys
Affiliations: Department of Adv. Materials Eng., Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon 440-746, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Y.-J., Department of Adv. Materials Eng., Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon 440-746, South Korea; Hong, T.-W., Department of Adv. Materials Eng., Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon 440-746, South Korea
Abstract: Thixotropic Mg alloys have been focused only on the aspect of semi liquid forming until now. In the present study, with the aim of improving hydrogen storage capacity, we kept an eye on the microstructural evolutions and chemical properties of thixotropic microstructure in Mg-(3, 6, 9, 12 mass%) Ni alloys by using a partial remelting process. According to the results of pressure-composition-isotherm (PCT) measurements and image analysis, Mg rich solid phases were regarded as the hydrogen absorbing phases and eutectic regions (quenched liquid phase) were considered as the catalyzer to improve hydrogenation kinetics. Especially, the hydrogenation properties depended on the properties of globules and liquid fractions.

Authors: Koike K., Li S., Komai H., Sasa S., Inoue M., Yano M.
Title: Charge-storage effect of vertically stacked InAs nanodots embedded in Al0.5Ga0.5As matrix
Source title: Japanese Journal of Applied Physics, Part 1: Regular Papers and Short Notes and Review Papers
Affiliations: Bio Venture Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan; New Materials Research Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Koike, K., Bio Venture Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan; Li, S., New Materials Research Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan; Komai, H., New Materials Research Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan; Sasa, S., Bio Venture Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan, New Materials Research Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan; Inoue, M., Bio Venture Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan, New Materials Research Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan; Yano, M., Bio Venture Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan, New Materials Research Center, Osaka Institute of Technology, Asahi-ku Ohmiya, Osaka 535-8585, Japan
Abstract: In this paper we describe the memory effect of vertically stacked InAs nanodots in the barrier layer of an Al0.5Ga0.5As/GaAs field-effect (FE) structure, by comparing this effect with that of single-layer InAs nanodots in the same FE structure. These FE structures are grown by molecular beam epitaxy, and Stranski-Krastanow islands are used for the InAs nanodots. The charge-storage effect of the nanodots is analyzed by capacitance-voltage (C-V) measurement and results in a hysteresis loop caused by stable electron trapping at nanodot potentials. The amount of "net" charge surviving at the stacked nanodots at 300 K is estimated to be ∼ 14 nC/cm2, whereas that at the single-layer nanodots is nearly zero. These C-V characteristics are in good agreement with photoluminescence properties.
Author Keywords: AlGaAs/GaAs FE diode; C-V; Charge-storage effect; InAs nanodots; PL; Vertical stacking

Authors: Zirngibl J.
Title: Integrated energy performance standard for heating systems
Affiliations: Energy Systems Division, Centre Sci. et Technique du Batiment, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Zirngibl, J., Energy Systems Division, Centre Sci. et Technique du Batiment, Paris, France
Abstract: The energy consumption can be reduced significantly if efficient heating systems are used and if the interaction between the building and the heating installation is optimized. National building codes will evaluate the quality of the building and the heating system in a system approach, taking into account the interaction. European standardization identified the need for a reliable method for calculation of the energy performance. The work concerning the heating system is done by CEN TC 228 (heating systems in buildings) WG4 (calculation methods). Standard prEN 14 335, Method for Calculation of System Energy Requirements and System Efficiencies, takes into account the losses of emission, distribution, storage, heat generation, and control. The energy requirements are converted to primary energy. The basis of the calculation of these losses is the building heat use determined according to prEN 13 790, Calculation of Energy Use for Heating. This integrated methodology could be the basis for energy performance standards adopted by the European Member States. If no European method is available, there is a risk that the specifications of national building codes will become new trading barriers for products throughout Europe.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Heat losses; Heat generation; Heating

Authors: Gómez-Romero P., Lira-Cantú M.
Title: From conducting polymers to electroactive hybrid materials
Affiliations: Materials Sci. Inst. of Barcelona, CSIC, Campus UAB, 08193 Bellaterra, Barcelona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Gómez-Romero, P., Materials Sci. Inst. of Barcelona, CSIC, Campus UAB, 08193 Bellaterra, Barcelona, Spain; Lira-Cantú, M., Materials Sci. Inst. of Barcelona, CSIC, Campus UAB, 08193 Bellaterra, Barcelona, Spain
Abstract: Electron or hole conductivity in conjugated polymers provided their initial thrust, but conductive polymers also display interesting electrochemical properties which constitute the base for their application in different types of electro-ionic devices. A further step in the development of functional materials based on conductive polymers is provided by the design of hybrid materials. In hybrid organic-inorganic materials based on conductive polymers, the electroactivity of molecular doping species or other inorganic components is added to that of the polymers themselves, leading to a whole new spectrum of hybrid materials that allow for the harnessing and control of the electrochemical properties of molecular species and put them to work in the development of all sorts of functional materials and devices, from sensors or catalysts to rechargeable lithium batteries, supercapacitors or photoelectrochemical devices. In this chapter we present several examples of this type of functional materials, their synthesis, properties and applications. We will present a general overview of this field and will discuss in some detail the design of insertion electrodes based on conducting polymers and hybrid organic-inorganic materials based on them, analyzing their peculiar ion-inserting mechanisms and their possible application in energy storage devices.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Catalysts; Doping (additives); Electrochemistry; Electrodes; Electrons; Energy storage; Lithium batteries; Secondary batteries; Sensors; Spectrum analysis; Electroactive hybrid materials; Polymers

Authors: Erickson T.G., Shankle W.E., Marotta S.A.
Title: Ultrahigh reliability US Army missiles and munitions
Authors with affiliations: Erickson, T.G.; Shankle, W.E.; Marotta, S.A.
Abstract: This paper provides an overview of U.S. Army requirements necessary for missiles and munitions to survive and operate in extreme environments with ultrahigh reliability. Long-term storage of assets, exposure to harsh environments, and requirements for high reliability with minimum field checks are significant concerns for Army missiles and munitions. These concerns warrant investigation into new and advanced techniques that provide health monitoring and prognostics capability, as well as robust design. In the past, missiles and munitions were commonly stored for long periods of time within the various military depot environments. In the present Army, however, missiles and munitions can expect deployment into a theater of operations and subsequent return to stocks for a potential future deployment. These deployments are expected to occur several times during an asset's life cycle, with extremes being experienced for each deployment due to handling, transportation, and theater storage. Therefore, the potential detrimental affects which a missile and/or munition will likely encounter must be understood and accounted for in its design and fielding so that its war fighting capability and readiness can be assured. Ultrahigh reliability of weapon systems is a critical requirement for the transformed Army to quickly enable a lethal and decisive battle force. This presentation will define ultra-reliability as it relates to missiles and munitions. Approaches to achieving ultra-reliability will be discussed, including joint efforts by the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy in modeling materials aging phenomena.
Author Keywords: Diagnostics; Missiles; Prognostics; Reliability; Soldering
Index Keywords: Ammunition; Computer simulation; Military applications; Missiles; Reliability; Systems analysis; Prognostics; Software Package PRISM; Ultrahigh reliability; Computer systems

Title: A hybrid single-switch power factor correction pre-regulator
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference

Astronautics, Nanjing, 210016, Jangsu Province, China
Abstract: Power Factor Correction Converters are widely used as the pre-regulator for the downstream dc-dc converter in order to comply with IEC 1000-3-2 specifications. However, for power supplies with hold-up time requirement, when the input drops out the energy stored in the capacitor of the pre-regulator can not be fully transferred to the next stage due to the limit of duty cycle in the downstream dc-dc converter. This paper proposes a new pre-regulator that can reduce the bulky capacitor and suppress the voltage across it below 450V. Basic operation of the converter is discussed and experimental results are provided for verification.

Authors: Sebastián J., Fernández A., Hernando M.M., Villarejo J.A., Rascón M.
Title: New implementations of single-stage power-factor-correctors with Voltage-Doubler line rectifier
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Universidad de Oviedo, DIEECS, Grupo de Electronica Industrial, Campus Universitario de Viesques, 33204 Gijon, Spain; Universidad Politecnica de Cartagena, Depto. de Tecnologia Electronica, Campus Muralla del Mar, 30202 Cartagena, Spain; ALCATEL. Technology Group, Av. Princesa Juana de Austria Km 8,7, 28021 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Sebastián, J., Universidad de Oviedo, DIEECS, Grupo de Electronica Industrial, Campus Universitario de Viesques, 33204 Gijon, Spain; Fernández, A., Universidad de Oviedo, DIEECS, Grupo de Electronica Industrial, Campus Universitario de Viesques, 33204 Gijon, Spain; Hernando, M.M., Universidad de Oviedo, DIEECS, Grupo de Electronica Industrial, Campus Universitario de Viesques, 33204 Gijon, Spain; Villarejo, J.A., Universidad Politecnica de Cartagena, Depto. de Tecnologia Electronica, Campus Muralla del Mar, 30202 Cartagena, Spain; Rascón, M., ALCATEL. Technology Group, Av. Princesa Juana de Austria Km 8,7, 28021 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: This paper deals with a new implementation of a Voltage-Doubler Single-Stage Power Factor Corrector (VD-S2PFC). This new VD-S2PFC provides a reduction (by half) of the total voltage drop due to diodes conducting at the same time from the line input to the energy-storage capacitors. Moreover, the size of the additional inductors used to shape the line current is dramatically reduced due to the fact that these inductors form part of an additional output of the main dc-to-dc converter, which is based on a full-wave rectifier and, therefore, these inductors are operating at twice the converter switching frequency and with a higher duty cycle than in the case of being based on a half-wave rectifier, as in some previous cases. The experimental results show that both inductors can be built into two E20 cores for a 100 W, 62 Vdc prototype. The voltage across the series connection of both energy-storage capacitors is lower than 500V and the total efficiency of this prototype is 92-90%.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Capacitor storage; Electric converters; Electric currents; Electric inductors; Electric potential; Electric rectifiers; Semiconductor diodes; Voltage control; Full wave rectifier; Single stage power factor corrector; Voltage drop; Electric power factor correction

Title: Growth of AIN films by hot-wall CVD and sublimation techniques: Effect of growth cell pressure
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Measurement Technology, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Kakanakova-Georgieva, A., Department of Physics and Measurement Technology, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden; Forsberg, U., Department of Physics and Measurement Technology, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden; Magnusson, B., Department of Physics and Measurement Technology, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden; Yakimova, R., Department of Physics and Measurement Technology, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden; Janzén, E., Department of Physics and Measurement Technology, Linköping University, Linköping, SE-581 83, Sweden
Abstract: Aluminum nitride (AIN) films were grown on off-axis, Si terminated 4H-SiC substrates by hot-wall CVD and sublimation tcchniqucs. The films were investigated by Infrared reflectance. Optical microscopy, Energy Dispersive X-ray analysis and Cathodoluminescence in a Scanning Electron Microscope with respect to their thickness, morphological, compositional and luminescence properties, in order to examine the influence of the growth cell pressure in either of the two deposition methods. Good quality thick AIN films were obtained by hot-wall CVD at temperature of 1200°C and reduced pressure of 100 mbar as reflected in the near stoichiometric N/Al ratio in these layers and in the appearance of the characteristic AIN near band edge emission. The AIN sublimation grown films at temperature of 2100°C suffered from island growth irrespective of the background pressure. The supcrsaturation conditions that affect strongly the growth mode became more favorable when the temperature was reduced to 1900°C. © (2002) Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.

Authors: Lee H., Lee T., Seo K., Jin Y., Kim J.
Title: A novel crowbar scheme for capacitive pulsed power systems
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Korea Elecrrorechnology Research Institute, Sungju-Dong 28-1, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, H., Korea Elecrrorechnology Research Institute, Sungju-Dong 28-1, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Lee, T., Korea Elecrrorechnology Research Institute, Sungju-Dong 28-1, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Seo, K., Korea Elecrrorechnology Research Institute, Sungju-Dong 28-1, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Jin, Y., Korea Elecrrorechnology Research Institute, Sungju-Dong 28-1, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea; Kim, J., Korea Elecrrorechnology Research Institute, Sungju-Dong 28-1, Changwon, 641-120, South Korea
Abstract: Capacitive pulsed power systems are based on the RLC circuits. According to the magnitude of the load resistance and the circuit characteristic impedance, the load current or capacitor voltage may swing or not. The current or voltage oscillation is often not allowed due to the load property or the voltage reversal limit of the energy storage capacitors. Crowbar circuits are inserted for the suppression of the oscillation in these cases. Usually diodes are used as a crowbar switch but when the system voltage and current become high it is not a practical system because the cost of the diodes goes up enormously. A novel crowbar scheme using a spark gap or vacuum gap switch which was triggered at a proper time after the current peak was proposed, implemented and tested. A Rogowski coil was used for sensing the current peak. Because the output of a Rogowski coil shows generally the time derivative of the current waveform, a diode inserted in parallel to the output signal can clamp the positive part of the induced voltage signal of the Rogowski coil. When the voltage arrives at a proper negative value, a square pulse voltage signal of 15V which triggers the trigger generator for the gap switch for crowbarring can be produced through an amplifier circuit. The implemented circuit shows successful crowbarring actions at a RLC circuit of 1236 uF, 160 uH, 100 mOhm with the capacitor charged up to 17 kV, the peak current of 34 kA and the capacitor voltage reversal of 1.8 kV.
Index Keywords: Amplifiers (electronic); Circuit oscillations; Diodes; Electric coils; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electric spark gaps; Electric waveforms; Equivalent circuits; Semiconductor switches; Crowbar circuit; Crowbar scheme; Rogowski coil; Vacuum gap; Capacitor storage

Authors: Bansal P.K., Cousins S.
Title: Impact of different parameters on the energy consumption of domestic refrigerators
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Bansal, P.K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; Cousins, S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand
Abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive research study on the energy efficiency test standards for household refrigerators and refrigerator-freezers. The standards studied include the Australian.New Zealand Standard (AS/NZS), the International Standard (ISO), the American National Standard (ANSI), the Japanese Industrial Standard (JIS), and the Chinese Taipei National Standard (CNS). The paper highlights the salient differences among these test standards and presents energy consumption data for some standards. In order to study the practicality and weaknesses of test standards, various refrigerator-freezers were tested under varying test conditions of AS/NZS and ISO to quantify the effect of different variables (e.g., ambient air temperature, relative humidity, cabinet internal air temperature, cabinet size and variance) on the energy consumption. The effect of relative humidity on energy consumption was found to be marginal, whereas the energy consumption increased significantly, as expected, with cabinet size, ambient air temperature, and door openings.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric humidity; Condensers (liquefiers); Electric heating; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Equipment testing; Evaporators; Food storage; Freezing; Heat convection; Ice; Refrigeration; Standards; Thermal insulation; Thermal load; Refrigerator-freezers; Refrigerators

Authors: Hansen B.F., Wojtaszewski J.F.P.

Authors: Liang G., Huot J., Schulz R.
Title: Mechanosynthesis of hydrogen storage alloys
Affiliations: Hydro-Québec Research Inst., 1790 Boul. Lionel-Boulet, Varennes, Que. J3X 1S1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Liang, G., Hydro-Québec Research Inst., 1790 Boul. Lionel-Boulet, Varennes, Que. J3X 1S1, Canada; Huot, J., Hydro-Québec Research Inst., 1790 Boul. Lionel-Boulet, Varennes, Que. J3X 1S1, Canada; Schulz, R., Hydro-Québec Research Inst., 1790 Boul. Lionel-Boulet, Varennes, Que. J3X 1S1, Canada
Abstract: In the last decade, the mechanical alloying and mechanical grinding techniques have been used extensively to synthesise or modify hydrogen storage materials in an attempt to improve their hydrogen sorption properties. Since hydrogen diffusion through grain boundaries is usually much faster than in the bulk and since calculations show that the H/M ratio in metallic clusters containing hydrogen can reach high values when the size of clusters is reduced to the nanometer scale, one was hoping that ball milled nanocrystalline metal hydrides could have better absorption/desorption kinetics as well as improved storage capacity. The kinetics and the activation are improved in most cases but we usually observe a loss in capacity in as-milled AB, AB5 and AB2 hydrogen storage systems. For Mg-based hydrides, however, the loss of capacity is negligible. The loss of storage capacity is usually attributed to structural disorder which could be topological or chemical in nature. For instance, the loss of capacity and the change in the equilibrium plateau pressure in ball-milled nanocrystalline FeTi was attributed to amorphous grain boundary phases. Fortunately, this loss of capacity can be recovered by thermal treatment at relatively low temperature. In this paper, we report and compare the hydrogen storage properties of mechanically treated low and high temperature metal hydride systems and discuss the influence of structural disorder, microstrain and grain size on properties.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen storage; Mechanical alloying MA; Metal hydrides; Nanocrystalline materials
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Alloys; Comminution; Grain boundaries; Grain size and shape; Hydrogen; Mechanical alloying; Nanostructured materials; Reaction kinetics; Sorption; Synthesis (chemical); Hydrogen storage alloys; Hydrogenation decrepitation; Mechanical grinding alloys; Mechanosynthesis; Structural disorder; Hydrides

Authors: Nakamura T., Marumori H., Takahashi M., Fujii Y.
Title: An MPEG-2 CODEC LSI with an audio accelerator for camcorders
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers - IEEE International Conference on Consumer Electronics
Affiliations: Digital Media Systems, R and D Division, Hitachi, Ltd., Hitachi-shi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakamura, T., Digital Media Systems, R and D Division, Hitachi, Ltd., Hitachi-shi, Japan; Marumori, H., Digital Media Systems, R and D Division, Hitachi, Ltd., Hitachi-shi, Japan; Takahashi, M., Digital Media Systems, R and D Division, Hitachi, Ltd., Hitachi-shi, Japan; Fujii, Y., Digital Media Systems, R and D Division, Hitachi, Ltd., Hitachi-shi, Japan
Abstract: A latest large scale integration (LSI) was developed which included audio accelerator for camcorders and various functional blocks. A low-power and compact MPEG-2 CODEC system was proposed. The reduction of power consumption and downsizing of the camcorder system was implemented and confirmed. A compressed audio stream was decoded by the audio CODEC and output via the D/A converter.
