Authors: Lovatt H.C., Dunlop J.B.
Title: Power transfer in hybrid electric vehicles with multiple energy storage units
Authors with affiliations: Lovatt, H.C.; Dunlop, J.B.
Abstract: With increasing urban pollution and increasing greenhouse gas pollution, there is much interest in reducing pollution from vehicles. One of the more promising technologies is Hybrid Electric Vehicles; unfortunately the cost of storing electrical energy is still high. A combination of batteries and super-capacitors is an economically viable storage option provided that the energy can be transferred without expensive DC/DC converters. This paper demonstrates a new power flow topology that doesn't use converters and discusses its application in two vehicles, the GM Holden ECOmmodore and the aXcessaustralia LEV.
Index Keywords: Electric converters; Electric network topology; Electricity; Power transmission; Energy storage units; Power transfer; Electric vehicles

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Market movement: Venezuela's production plummets
Abstract: Oil production by PDVSA decreased to 600,000 from 650,000 bpd, less than a third of its previous output, well into the second week of a general strike aimed at forcing Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez out of office. Venezuela's oil production normally is 3 million bpd but was down to 2.2 million bpd prior to the strike. Critics blame Chávez's left-leaning policies for deepening the country's economic crisis. Venezuela, the world's fifth largest oil exporter, normally provides 13% of daily US oil supplies. At this juncture, US refiners have reported few difficulties nominating spot barrels (and potentially withdrawing from Caribbean storage) to replace lost Venezuelan output, according to Matthew Warburton industry analyst with UBS Warburg LLC, NY. Meanwhile, according to government officials, Venezuela is losing $50 million/day due to the shutdown of refineries and ports serving PDVSA. Venezuela's total refinery output has been cut to 80,000 bpd from nearly 1 million bpd. Negotiations between the opposing factions appeared to be at an impasse during the second week of December 2002. However, according to Rafael Ramirez, Venezuela's minister of energy and mines, a complete restructuring of PDVSA has been ordered.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Market movement: OECD oil, petroleum product stocks fall
Abstract: Inventories in 26 OECD countries dropped by 13.5 million bbl in October 2002, compared with a normal draw of 4 million bbl. According to Michael Rothman, first vice-president and senior energy market specialist at Merril Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc, the estimated inventories stood 87 million bbl below normal on 11/1/2002 vs. a 93 million bbl surplus at the end of 2001-2002 winter. Declines in OECD storage indicate that overproduction by the 10 active members of the OPEC above their assigned quotas is not dumping a surplus of oil on markets. OECD storage in Europe decreased an estimated 8 million bbl during October 2002, compared with a normal build of 1 million bbl, leading to declines in gasoline and middle distillates. OECD North America inventories are estimated to drop 12 million bbl, which is > 2 million from the normal.

Authors: Gonzalez B.
Title: Development of the G16CM34 engine as a high efficiency engine for gas transmission, storage and withdrawal services
Source title: Proceedings of the International Pipeline Conference, IPC
Affiliations: Caterpillar Commercial Services Ltd., Calgary, Alta., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Gonzalez, B., Caterpillar Commercial Services Ltd., Calgary, Alta., Canada
Abstract: The development of the G16CM34 engine as a high efficiency engine for gas transmission, storage and withdrawal services is discussed. The mechanical efficiency of the engine is greater than 43%. The electronic control tightly regulates the combustion process, cylinder by cylinder, to optimize the efficiency. The microprocessors in the control system continuously monitor available engine power using the sensor data based on ambient and turbocharged-aftercooled air intake temperatures.
Index Keywords: Gas transmission; Bearings (machine parts); Control systems; Costs; Crankshafts; Energy efficiency; Gas cylinders; Gas emissions; Gas fuel storage; Gears; Nitrogen oxides; Optimization; Sensors; Thermal effects; Internal combustion engines

Authors: Buck B.S., Philo J.D.
Title: Utilization of vertiline wire conveyed smart tools in gas storage field pipeline applications
Source title: Proceedings of the International Pipeline Conference, IPC
Authors with affiliations: Buck, B.S.; Philo, J.D.
Abstract: Consumers Energy, which is the largest natural gas utility in the state of Michigan and fifth largest in the United States, operates thirteen natural gas storage fields in the state as part of its Gas Transmission and Storage system. These storage fields consist of a network of storage wells connected via a series of short pipeline laterals and headers. Typical field configuration consists of one or two main headers with several laterals branching off to the gas storage wells. Due to the shorter line lengths (2.5 miles or less) and other operational conflicts, it is difficult to utilize conventional online smart pigging methods to assess the integrity of these laterals and headers. Based on the type (welded steel), average age, and operating conditions of the pipelines in these storage fields, an internal inspection method was desired. Consumers Energy has teamed with Baker Atlas to utilize their Vertiline wire conveyed MFL (magnetic flux leakage) smart tools to assess the integrity of these gas storage field headers and laterals. The Vertiline technology was originally conceived for down hole well casing integrity analysis, however, the application was found to be ideal for short section, limited access, and otherwise unpiggable pipelines. The Baker Vertiline technology can currently be used on pipeline sizes up to 24" in diameter, and larger diameter tools are under development. This paper will explore the process that Consumers Energy undertook to utilize wire conveyed MFL smart tools in its gas storage field pipelines. Field preparation for tool runs, running the tool and gathering data, and data presentation will all be reviewed. The advantages and disadvantages, techniques, capabilities, and technology of the wire conveyed MFL smart tools themselves will also be discussed, along with other potential applications such as use in analysis of pipeline river crossings, pipelines lacking pig launching facilities, and offshore production lines.
Index Keywords: Natural gas storage fields; Gas fuel storage; Inspection; Natural gas pipelines; Natural gas wells; Welded steel structures; Gas pipelines

Authors: Parekh H., Sati V.C.
Title: Pipelines industry in India: Recent developments and future requirements
Source title: Proceedings of the International Pipeline Conference, IPC
Affiliations: Indian Oil Corporation Ltd., Western Region Pipelines, Rajkot, Gujarat, India
Authors with affiliations: Parekh, H., Indian Oil Corporation Ltd., Western Region Pipelines, Rajkot, Gujarat, India; Sati, V.C., Indian Oil Corporation Ltd., Western Region Pipelines, Rajkot, Gujarat, India
Abstract: The consumption of petroleum products in India has been growing at a high rate. In order to meet the growing demand for petroleum, additional refining capacity is planned to be created involving augmentation of some of the existing refineries and construction of new refineries. While the refineries will be in a position to meet the demand of petroleum products, the critical and vital issue will be to supply crude oil to the refineries and to reach the products to various consumption centers in an efficient, reliable and cost effective manner. In addition to the liquid petroleum, Natural Gas is emerging as the major source of energy/feedstock. Infrastructure for storage and transportation of Natural Gas are also required to be set up in a big way to meet the projected demand. This can best be done by constructing new pipelines which are recognized worldwide as the most reliable and cost effective mode of transportation of oil and gas. In addition to the requirement for new pipelines, there is a need for upgradation of technology in the existing cross-country pipelines, many of which are more than 20 years old. Moreover, Indian Government has, as part of the process of liberalisation of the economy through a series of measures focused on the infrastructural developments, technology upgradation, trade policies and financial reforms, has opened the core sector of Petroleum to private investment. Thus, considerable scope exists not only for consultants, equipment and material manufacturers/suppliers and contractors for providing their services but also for making investments in the Indian pipeline industry. This paper describes the prospects/opportunities in the Indian pipeline industry.
Index Keywords: Refineries; Crude petroleum; Energy utilization; Fuel storage; Industrial economics; Investments; Natural gas; Petroleum industry

Authors: Rimassa G.
Title: Wired-wireless integration: A middleware perspective
Affiliations: Parma University, Italy; FRAMETech S.r.l., Italy; Agent and Object Technology Lab., Parma University, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Rimassa, G., Parma University, Italy, FRAMETech S.r.l., Italy, Agent and Object Technology Lab., Parma University, Italy
Abstract: The various aspects of mobile devices are discussed. Middleware provides generic services such as communication, data access, and resource control to let systems on different platforms communicate. Conventional middleware targets the corporate environment with it abundant storage space, processing power, and energy, and fast and reliable networks. The FIPA wireless devices host a lighweight execution environment for resource-poor software components that still interperate with larger components.
Index Keywords: Corba system; Information systems; Java Server Pages (JSP); Software quality; Computer software; Data acquisition; Electronic mail; Information analysis; Interfaces (computer); Internet; Middleware; World Wide Web; Wireless telecommunication systems

Authors: Agapov N.N., Kovalenko A.D., Malakhov A.I.
Title: Nuclotron: Basic results and development plans
Affiliations: Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Agapov, N.N., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Kovalenko, A.D., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Russian Federation; Malakhov, A.I., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Russian Federation
Abstract: The results of the development and operation of the accelerator complex at the high-energy laboratory of the Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, a nuclotron - the first rapid-cycling superconducting synchrotron - being the main component, are described. The accelerator was developed on the basis of a unique technology for building superconducting magnets which are capable of operating with a cycle repetition frequency up to 1 Hz. Among the latest results, it is mentioned that the energy consumption for operation of the accelerator is substantially decreased and the duration of continuous operation is increased. The beam extraction system recently put into operation is described. For the first time, this system is based on components which operate at low temperature (about 4.5 K). Data on the upgrading of the ion sources are presented. Plans for further development of the accelerator complex are described: production of intense beams of polarized deuterons, application of superconducting magnets in the beam channels, and development of a superconducting nuclotron booster.
Index Keywords: Beam extraction systems; Deuterons; Nuclotrons; Rapid cycling synchrotrons; Accelerator magnets; Cryogenics; Cryostats; Electrostatics; High energy physics; Proton beams; Resonance; Storage rings; Superconducting magnets; Synchrotrons; Particle accelerators

Budker Inst. of Nucl. Physics, Siberian Br. the Russ. Acad. of Sci., Russian Federation
Abstract: An experiment, using the new detector Kedr, on the precise measurement of the τ-lepton mass is being readied on the VÉPP-4M. The resonance depolarization method is used for absolute calibration of the particle energy. The main difficulty in using a polarized beam at the τ-lepton production threshold (1777 MeV) is the closeness of an integral spin resonance (1763 MeV). Experiments observing the polarization of particles in VÉPP-4M after injection of the polarized beam from the VÉPP-3 storage booster with different detunings from resonance have been performed. For comparison, the depolarization time of a beam due to quantum fluctuations in the presence of characteristic disturbances of the guiding field is calculated. The temporal stability of the energy indications is studied.
Index Keywords: Cylindrical accelerators; Radiation polarization; Resonance-depolarization; Calibration; Electromagnetic wave polarization; Electron beams; High energy physics; Natural frequencies; Radiation; Resonance; Tuning; Particle accelerators

Authors: Bauer P., Rompelman O.
Title: The 'energy challenge' in electrical engineering education
Authors with affiliations: Bauer, P.; Rompelman, O.
Abstract: Traditionally, the education in electrical engineering is roughly divided into two areas, viz. electronics and telecommunication on the one hand and electrical energy on the other. Though the borders between these two areas have become vague, this division is still clearly observable, in particular when it comes down to the student's perception of these areas as potential fields of study. Electrical energy has an old-fashioned image. Furthermore, over the last decades there has been a shift from laboratory experiments to computer simulations. In this paper a new approach is introduced, which is aimed at raising first-year students' awareness of the potential attractiveness of electrical energy as an area of study. The approach is project-oriented and based on teamwork. Projects are carried out that are aimed at the design, implementation and verification of small total energy systems. The problems involved are related to energy production, system design, energy storage and consumption. © 2002, Copyright Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: Education; Engineering education; Electrical energy; Energy productions; First year students; Laboratory experiments; New approaches; Potential field; Project oriented; Total energy; Students

Authors: Johnsson R., Brodin S., Ekedahl P., Helmers L., Hogstrom J.
Title: Development of hydrogen and oxygen pump turbines for Vinci engine
Source title: 38th AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: Volvo Aero Corporation, Trollhattan, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Johnsson, R., Volvo Aero Corporation, Trollhattan, Sweden; Brodin, S., Volvo Aero Corporation, Trollhattan, Sweden; Ekedahl, P., Volvo Aero Corporation, Trollhattan, Sweden; Helmers, L., Volvo Aero Corporation, Trollhattan, Sweden; Hogstrom, J., Volvo Aero Corporation, Trollhattan, Sweden
Abstract: The development of a new cryogenic 180kN upper stage engine for the Ariane 5 launcher program started 1998. An expander cycle was chosen for the engine. The two turbines are arranged in series and the energy to drive the turbines is provided by the hydrogen that is cooling the combustion chamber wall. The engine will be qualified in 2005. Today the turbines have been accepted in concept reviews in 1999 and in the preliminary design review during 2001. With use of Vulcain experience and Volvo experience from other internal programs cost cutting production techniques were chosen. The reduction of development cost and lead-time lead to an increase concurrent work not only at Volvo but also together with costumers and suppliers compared with Vulcain experience. The requirements on very low production cost with full reliability gave the need to incorporate the lessons learned from Vulcain together with focus on the necessary new technologies. During the conceptual phase design-to-cost approach was used to have a good balance between performance and production cost. Similar basic concept choices are chosen for both LOX and LH2 turbines so maximum know how transfer is obtained. Material choices are made identical where it is possible. Cost optimized manufacturing methods are applied and turbines with radial milled unshrouded rotor blisk and radial milled stator with brazed shroud is the result. Inlet manifold is a casting, integrated with the pump, with a varying cross-sectional area to achieve a low tangential pressure variation at the stator inlet. On the hydrogen turbine, an exhaust duct without guide vanes is chosen, and for the oxygen turbine a mainfold is chosen due to geometrical restriction and also to take care of the outlet swirl. To support the concept choice a demonstration program was performed. Different turbine stage geometries were tested for performance in air. Shrouded and unshrouded rotor blades were tested with different tip clearances. Velocity mapping using Laser Doppler technique and a series of CFD analysis completed the test campaign Verification by material test in hydrogen was performed very early in the program in order to justify the choice of material. A modal test with damping measurements has been completed in rotor alone installation with the Vinci LH2 blisk. The mechanical design has been justified with FE analysis and design criteria according to Vulcain experience. The blisk high cycle fatigue resistance has been verified by a system of analyses and tests including unsteady flow analysis and FE analysis. Manufacturing technologies have been developed and evaluated early for the concept and manufacturing process choices. This and the early design-tocost approach required concurrent engineering with all design and manufacturing engineers working in the same office. A new CAD program made it also possible to have a master model with all manufacturing steps collected in a data base and from this drawings, manufacturing sheets, NC programs and analysis models are taken. © 2002 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Combustion chamber walls; Demonstration programs; Laser Doppler technique; Manufacturing engineers; Manufacturing methods; Manufacturing technologies; Preliminary design reviews; Unsteady flow analysis; Combustion chambers; Computational fluid dynamics; Computer aided design; Concurrent engineering; Costs; Digital storage; Doppler effect; Engines; Hydraulic turbines; Modal analysis; Propulsion; Pumped storage power plants; Rotors (windings); Software testing; Stators; Turbine components

Authors: Méndez A., López-Cortijo J., Lago F., Clarke S.C.
Title: GTL Offshore: The Marine Perspective
Affiliations: IZAR Fene Shipyard, Spain; Foster Wheeler Energy Limited, Reading, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Méndez, A., IZAR Fene Shipyard, Spain; López-Cortijo, J., IZAR Fene Shipyard, Spain; Lago, F., IZAR Fene Shipyard, Spain; Clarke, S.C., Foster Wheeler Energy Limited, Reading, United Kingdom
Abstract: A discussion on the challenges on the marine aspects of gas-to-liquids (GTL) floating production, storage, and offloading (FPSO) vessels, presented at the October 2000 Gastech Conference, held in Doha, Qatar, covers how the industry can benefit from the contribution of a shipyard as a marine specialist and technology integrator from the early stages of deepwater stranded and associated gas developments; gas utilization alternatives; potential applications of GTL FPSO; hull type alternatives; hull size; compactness of design; marine motion effects; safety issues; class approval; ultra large floating production systems; seakeeping aspects; the IZAR Fene shipyard; Foster Wheeler Energy Ltd; and SEAGAS JIP.

Authors: Moshnyaga V.G.
Title: Reducing energy dissipation of video memory by adaptive bit-width compression
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits, and Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electronics Engineering and Computer Science, Fukuoka University, 8-19-1 Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka 814-0180, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Moshnyaga, V.G., Department of Electronics Engineering and Computer Science, Fukuoka University, 8-19-1 Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka 814-0180, Japan
Abstract: A new architectural technique to reduce energy dissipation of video memory is proposed. Unlike existing approaches, the technique exploits the pixel correlation in video sequences, dynamically adjusting the memory bit-width to the number of bits changed per pixel. Instead of treating the data bits independently, we group the most significant bits together, activating the corresponding group of bit-lines adaptively to data variation. The method is not restricted to the specific bit-patterns nor depends on the storage phase. It works equally well on read and write accesses, as well as during precharging. Simulation results show that using this method we can reduce the total energy consumption of frame memory by 20% without affecting the picture quality. © 2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bit-Width; Bitlines; Data bits; Frame memory; Most significant bit; Picture quality; Simulation result; Total energy consumption; Video sequences; Electron energy loss spectroscopy; Energy dissipators; Energy utilization; Pixels; Video recording; Energy dissipation

Authors: Mishra S.
Title: Energetics of a Lencaena plantation on degraded lands in Central India
Source title: International Journal of Ecology and Environmental Sciences
Affiliations: Indian Grassland and Fodder Research Institute, Jhansi 284003, India
Authors with affiliations: Mishra, S., Indian Grassland and Fodder Research Institute, Jhansi 284003, India
Abstract: Energy storage in different plant parts over a three year growth of coppiced 5-year old plantations was investigated in five varieties of Leucaena. The aboveground parts stored more energy. Energy storage in selections S24 and S10 was more than in K8. Initially energy allocation was more in leaves than in branches. Ecological efficiency was maximum in the second year of coppice growth. Low efficiency in the third year is ascribed to low stand density and dry habitat. Compared with other ecosystems, coppiced plantations had higher capacity for energy storage. © International Scientific Publications, New Delhi.
Author Keywords: Ecological efficiency; Energy allocation; Energy flow models; Energy storage; Leucaena leucocephala

Authors: Minić D., Šušić M.V.
Title: Modern concepts of conversion and storage of energy by dispersed materials absorption
Affiliations: Physical Chemistry Faculty, University of Belgrade, Studentski Trg 12-16, Belgrade, Serbia; Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Knez-Mihailova 35, Belgrade, North Macedonia
Authors with affiliations: Minić, D., Physical Chemistry Faculty, University of Belgrade, Studentski Trg 12-16, Belgrade, Serbia; Šušić, M.V., Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Knez-Mihailova 35, Belgrade, North Macedonia
Abstract: Once hydrogen is generated, the question asked: How do we store hydrogen? Hydrogen can be stored in a variety of ways, each with specific advantages and disadvantages. The overall criteria for choosing a storage method should be safety and ease of use. Described in this paper and listed below are different storage methods available today (compressed hydrogen, liquid carrier storage, glass microsphere, chemically stored hydrogen) in addition to some techniques that are still in the research and development stage: power balls, metal hydride tanks and carbon clusters.
Author Keywords: Carbon nanotubes, graphite nanotubes; Conversion; Hydrogen; Metal hydrides; Storage

Authors: Lichołai L.
Title: Analysis of temperature distribution in double pane glazing system with air gap
Affiliations: Rzeszów University of Technology, Faculty of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Rzeszów, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Lichołai, L., Rzeszów University of Technology, Faculty of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Rzeszów, Poland
Abstract: Aspects discussed within this paper apply to determination of temperature distribution in a double pane glazing system with air gap. These considerations are the base for the determination of thermal influences of external-environment on the storage barrier in passive solar heating systems. Application of such systems is a noteworthy method for realization of energy-saving facilities, characterized by low consumption of heat energy.

Authors: Nawrowski R., Skowronek K.
Title: Operating conditions of a random constant voltage source in an electrical power system
Affiliations: Inst. of Indust. Elec. Engineering, Poznań Univ. of Technology, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Nawrowski, R., Inst. of Indust. Elec. Engineering, Poznań Univ. of Technology, Poland; Skowronek, K., Inst. of Indust. Elec. Engineering, Poznań Univ. of Technology, Poland
Abstract: The paper presents a mathematical model of a system for obtaining energy from a real constant voltage source with random characteristics of equivalent electromotive force variations. Basic reasons for random characteristics of electrical power sources are discussed. Based on statistical linearization the probabilistic parameters of the source current are determined. Examples of the analysis of operating conditions of a random voltage source are presented for a selected form of correlation function.

Authors: Pirch N., Baldus O., Waser R., Kreutz E.W.
Title: Numerical investigations of laser-induced crystallization and stress development in phase changes of electroceramic materials
Source title: 2002 International Conference on Modeling and Simulation of Microsystems - MSM 2002
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Inst. fur Lasertechnik, Aachen, Germany; Inst. fur Elektrokeramische W., Forschungszentrum J Lieh, Germany; Lehrstuhl fur Lasertechnik, RWTH Aachen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Pirch, N., Fraunhofer-Inst. fur Lasertechnik, Aachen, Germany; Baldus, O., Inst. fur Elektrokeramische W., Forschungszentrum J Lieh, Germany; Waser, R., Inst. fur Elektrokeramische W., Forschungszentrum J Lieh, Germany; Kreutz, E.W., Lehrstuhl fur Lasertechnik, RWTH Aachen, Germany
Abstract: Barium-Strontium-Titanate, BST, in the stoichiometry Ba 0.7Sr0.3TiO3 to Ba0.5Sr 0.5TiO3 is been considered as a promising candidate to enter into the DRAM manufacturing technology. The incompatibility between the temperatures required to crystallize the ferro/para-electric layer into the required Perovskite phase and the thermal budget of underlying active circuitry rules out the application of conventional, quasi-stationary heat treatment of these new materials when integrating into the circuit fabrication process. Therefore, the research focuses on heating amorphous ceramic thin films by laser radiation with pulse durations in the ns regime to induce changes in their structural and electronic properties in the heated region only. To establish initial operating parameters for the laser-induced crystallization and to study the amorphous to crystalline phase transformation including stress formation a simulation program is developed. The model includes heat transfer, crystallization and thermal respective phase transformation induced stress analysis.
Author Keywords: (Ba,Sr)TiO3; Laser crystallization/annealing; Stress analysis; Thin films
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Crystallization; Dynamic random access storage; Integration; Laser pulses; Parameter estimation; Stress analysis; (Ba,Sr)TiO3; Laser crystallization/annealing; Optical energy; Thermal budget; Ceramic materials

Authors: Sundar D.K., Garg S., Ramanayya T.V.
Title: Integrated virtual logistics network for quick responses
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on Traffic and Transportation Studies, ICTTS
Affiliations: ERP Center, Indian Institute of Management Bangalore, Bangalore, 560 076, India; Encore Software Limited, Bangalore, India; Indian Institute of Management Bangalore, Bangalore, 560 076, India
Authors with affiliations: Sundar, D.K., ERP Center, Indian Institute of Management Bangalore, Bangalore, 560 076, India; Garg, S., Encore Software Limited, Bangalore, India; Ramanayya, T.V., Indian Institute of Management Bangalore, Bangalore, 560 076, India
Abstract: Trucking is a vital segment of the transportation system that supports Indian Manufacturing. Trucking companies are attempting at providing such non-traditional trucking services as warehousing, distribution, inventory management, picking and packing - assembly operations and return goods management as part of their value added services thus making manufacturing (brick and mortar) activity competitive in the information (click) age. The major stakeholders in this exercise are (i) manufacturing industries (particularly Small and Medium scale enterprises - SMEs), (ii) logistics service providers (transportation, warehousing, clearing and forwarding agencies), and (iii) government and financial agencies (Central Excise and Customs, Regional Transport Organizations, Surface Transport Agencies and Banks etc). The present scenario warrants an integrated quick response mechanism to extend complete logistics solutions in a seamlessly integrated manner to reduce costs rather than extending the services in a disjointed way. In this context, this paper attempts at 1. Study of the present IT architecture, business processes of different agencies, involved in providing and using logistics industry's services in India, like Transportation sector, Customs & Central Excise of India internal processes and their external interactions with EDI partners, Manufacturing Companies' IT infrastructures and 2. Developing a framework for "Integrated virtual logistics network for Quick Responses" which would factor in the existing processes, systems and organizations' roles and the government's proposed investments in the e-commerce and e-governance infrastructure.
Index Keywords: Assembly operations; Business Processes; E commerces; E governances; Inventory managements; IT architectures; IT infrastructures; Logistics industries; Logistics service providers; Logistics solutions; Manufacturing industries; Non-traditional; Quick response; Transportation sectors; Transportation systems; Trucking companies; Value added services; Virtual logistics; Business Process; E-Commerce; E-governance; Inventory management; IT architecture; Logistics industry; Logistics service provider; Logistics solution; Manufacturing companies; Regional transport; Surface transport; Transportation sector; Transportation system; Value added service; Electric energy storage; Electronic commerce; Investments; Logistics; Manufacture; Telemedicine; Transportation; Trucks; Distribution of goods

Authors: Magusin S.
Title: ECS - Optimal power solutions in energy management
Source title: SEAISI Quarterly (South East Asia Iron and Steel Institute)
Affiliations: Magma Ltd., Distributors of ECS, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Magusin, S., Magma Ltd., Distributors of ECS, Australia
Abstract: For sometime, the importance of reducing energy consumption and the associated costs have been well recognised by both the steel and the other high energy consuming industries. Initially, the savings in energy were achieved through development of more energy efficient equipment and processes. However, once reaching the limits to these options, the focus of the cost and energy reduction efforts switched over to the possibilities of energy management and power peak control. Reduction of peak power demand has a significantly positive impacton environment, because in the most countries, the peak power is generated using fossil fuels. To assist customers in peak power demand control, the Swedish company MIC, which was a subsidiary of electricity generating company Sydkraft, developed an Energy Control System (ECS). The main feature of this system, approaching the energy optimization problem in several different ways, is control of peak power, which enables the customers to achieve stable, smooth power consumption and through that lower the fixed energy costs. The other important parts of the system are the capabilities for internal measuring, scheduling and alarm handling. Because the system is object oriented and modular in hardware, software as well as in handling and configuration, it provides the advantage of flexibility, enabling easy expansions and modification. As of today, the system, which is described in this paper, has been installed in approximately 150 industrial plants and facilities in Sweden and successfully marketed in USA, Germany and New Zealand. The customer base is wide, ranging from large pulp mills, steel plants to smaller energy consumers such as foundries, cool storages and commercial and residential buildings.
Index Keywords: Electricity; Iron and steel industry; Optimization; Power control; Problem solving; Alarm handling; Energy consumers; Energy control system (ECS); Energy utilization

Authors: Wiezel T.K., Satish M.G., Cruickshanks F.
Title: Modeling of thermal front movement at the Sussex Health Centre ATES site, Sussex, N.B.
Source title: Proceedings, Annual Conference - Canadian Society for Civil Engineering
Affiliations: Dalhousie University, Canada; Environment Canada, Dartmouth, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wiezel, T.K., Dalhousie University, Canada; Satish, M.G., Dalhousie University, Canada; Cruickshanks, F., Environment Canada, Dartmouth, Canada
Abstract: The Sussex Health Centre in Sussex, N.B. has been operating an aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) system since 1994. The system is experiencing operational problems, such as an imbalance between the heating and cooling loads causing thermal breakthrough. The purpose of this research is to perform numerical modeling of the subsurface portion of this ATES system in an effort to study the problems experienced by the system. The modeling will be performed using both a commercial software package and a model developed in the course of this research. The results from both models will be used for a comparative analysis. This research is intended to provide a viable pumping and injection strategy for an ATES system to function more efficiently and more fully achieve its energy and environmental benefits. The results from the study will be presented.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Computer software; Environmental impact; Health care; Mathematical models; Numerical methods; Aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) system; Cooling loads; Software package; Heat storage

Authors: Wilson C., Gair S., Cruden A., McDonald J., Armstrong B.
Title: The Scottish Fuel Cell Consortium - A review of the first year of operation
Affiliations: Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Scottish Entperprise, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, C., Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Gair, S., Napier University, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Cruden, A., University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom; McDonald, J., University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, United Kingdom; Armstrong, B., Scottish Entperprise, Glasgow, United Kingdom
Abstract: In December 2000, the Scottish Fuel Cell Consortium (SFCC) was established with funding from the Energy Section of Scottish Enterprise, together with industrial, commercial and business partner inputs. The aim of the consortium was to establish an alliance of interested parties willing to explore and promote the use of fuel cell technology across a broad range of activities. The Consortium is initially focussed on road transport issues, where fuel cells are seen to offer an alternative form of clean energy, and which can also make use of Scotland's abundant availability of renewable energy, (wind, wave, hydro-electricity). During its first year of operation the project activities have encompassed (i) system integration of a commercially available fuel cell stack to operate on hydrogen, (ii) packaging of the fuel cell system into a 2.5 seat test vehicle and (iii) the study of a range of infrastructure issues relating to the production, transport and storage of hydrogen, vehicle maintenance costs and servicing, and legislative issues relating to the introduction of this new form of transport.

Authors: Elmer K.-H.
Title: A parallel algorithm with time dependent mesh refinement for wave propagation problems
Affiliations: Curt-Risch-Inst. Dynam., A./M.T., University of Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Elmer, K.-H., Curt-Risch-Inst. Dynam., A./M.T., University of Hannover, Germany
Abstract: The realistic complex behavior of mechanical wave propagation problems and acoustic problems in transient dynamics with a broad frequency range requires very large systems and many time steps, to obtain reliable numerical solutions with sufficient high accuracy. This is a domain of todays high-performance computers. A fast three dimensional parallel Finite-Difference algorithm with time dependent mesh refinement is developed to analyse and visualise the complex behavior of traveling waves in transient dynamics and acoustics. The propagation of mechanical waves is characterized by the change and interaction of strain energy and kinetic energy in space and time. According to this, the presented algorithm is based on the solution of the three-dimensional wave equation as a first order formulation in terms of stresses and velocities or acoustic pressure and particle velocity, representing both forms of energy in a direct way. Using explicit time integration and lumped mass description the equations of all nodes of the FD-method are decoupled. This leads to a very efficient algorithm, inherent parallel, and best suited to all kinds of parallel computing. The parallel FD-program is implemented on a 16 processor CRAY T3E parallel computer with distributed memory. The parallel efficiency of the algorithm and the efficiency of the time dependent mesh refinement are examined. Because of the small storage required and the short computational time, numerical investigations of large systems with online graphic simulations are possible up to several million degrees of freedom.

Title: Operation analysis of heat pump in hybrid system

Nowoursynowska 166, 02-766 Warsaw, Poland; Chochowski, A., Mechanical Engineering Department, Warsaw Technical University, ul. Łukasiewicza 17, 09-400 Płock, Poland
Abstract: The co-operation between a heat pump and different sources of energy in hybrid systems is often connected with highly varying temperature of its lower source. The paper presents laboratory test results of the influence of source temperature level on a medium temperature distribution in its thermodynamic cycle, on heating power and on driving power of a heat pump. The evaluation of degree of perfection for the real thermodynamic cycle has been worked out. Operational tests have been carried out in a hybrid hot water system. Although, the distinct influence of source temperature on pump heating power has been observed, the cyclic variation of efficiency ratio during operation is relatively low.
Index Keywords: Hybrid systems; Operation analysis; Electric energy storage; Energy resources; Public utilities; Solar system; Thermal cycling; Thermodynamics; Heat pump systems

Abstract: Producers offer wind power plants, which are adapted for an electric power system. The owner has to plan the optimum connection method of a wind power plant or whole farms to the electric power system. The choice of voltage is very important. The criteria of choice between a cable line and an overhead line are essential too. Both of them have advantages and disadvantages. Authors: Chiu D.M.
Title: Solid state batteries using thin film technology [Under category: Electrochemical technologies:Batteries for terrestrial applications]
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Moon Laboratory, 71 Long Valley Way, Doncaster East, Vic. 3109, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Chiu, D.M., Moon Laboratory, 71 Long Valley Way, Doncaster East, Vic. 3109, Australia
Abstract: Solid state battery technology had been developed in a large explosion fashion in recent years. The main influence of this is related to economics and connected with energy production, storage and utilisation. Due to such industrial problems, international collaborative researches become necessary. From the point of electrodes consideration, materials must be light and give high cell voltage and capacity. Therefore, thin-film technology may be one of the best solutions. Thin-film technique reduces the internal resistance of solid state battery. Its application provides various advantages over other techniques using bulk materials. For example, thinning of layers to give lower electric resistance in the transverse direction, provide a clean surface for the compound, improve the electrode -electrolyte interface contact, make film deposition of alkali metals easier, give good adhesion between layers, etc. Establishment of a reliable process of thin-film microbatteries fabrication would make them available for their use as power sources in integrated circuits. Some important fast-ionic conductors (solid electrolytes) are the iron compounds such as PbF2, iodine compounds such as RbAg 4I5 and LiI. Using thin-film for solid state electrodes offers certain significant advantages over their crystalline counterpart, such as easy to synthesise, easy to implement, larger electrochemically active surface, high diffusion coefficient of the mobile ion, a large number of available sites for the intercalants, etc. Two systems of amorphous materials are currently used, the semiconducting oxide-based glasses such as V 2O5, WO3, MoO3, and the amorphous chalcogenides, such as MoS2, MoS3, V2S 5, NiPS3. © 2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric resistance; Electrodes; Electrolytes; Iron compounds; Thin films; Amorphous chalcogenides; Semiconducting oxide-based glasses; Thin film technology; Thin-film microbatteries fabrication; Solid state devices

Abstract: The NASA GSFC's Integrated Mission Design Center (IMDC) studies for Flywheel applications and the mass impact and enhanced capability of incorporating Flywheels, for year 1999 and 2001, are reviewed. Fly wheels can be used for energy storage and for attitude controls. The emergence of Flywheel technology with different wheel geometry, composite rotors, magnetic bearings and operation at higher speeds will provide deliberate power discharge on to the spacecraft power bus. This technology has many possible benefits such as improved power efficiency, longer life, enhanced agility and reduced weight. This technology also breaks down the subsystem engineering partitions by collateral combining EPS and ACS attributes into a single device.

Abstract: In 1990, rapid development in power electronics presented the opportunity of developing a bidirectional static link converter to replace the motor generator sets traditionally fitted in HM Submarines. This concept was proven in shore test facilities during the early 1990s. Since 1998 it has undergone extensive development, which has engineered an advanced, efficient, quiet and compact Main Static Converter (MSC) that utilises Integrated Gate Bipolar Transistors (IGBT) for the Royal Navy ASTUTE Class nuclear submarine programme. Abstract: In a joint project Paul Scherrer Institut PSI, ETH Zurich, FEV Motorentechnik, and Volks-wagen have developed the fuel cell hybrid vehicle "Hy. Power". Hy. Power is a technology platform for the demonstration of a powertrain combining a hydrogen fuel cell system designed for 40 kW peak net power output and a double-layer capacitor arrangement with a peak power of 60 kW net. The potential of innovative technologies such as new designed bipolar plates and double-layer capacitors as well as a new air supply and humidification concept are tested under real conditions. The performance of the Hy. Power technology demonstrator was successfully tested under extreme boundary conditions by passing the Simplon Pass in the wintry alps in January 2002. Results of the operation of the power train will be discussed.

Abstract: The zero-field phase transition from nearly uniform in-plane to out-of-plane magnetization state in soft magnetic disks was studied. The energies of the leaf state and of the perpendicularly magnetized state were compared to find the transition curve between these states.

Authors: Pedersen C., Ponce G., Wilkinson S.
Title: The road to efficiency through an integrated refinery information system
Affiliations: Suncor Energy Products Inc., Sarnia, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Pedersen, C., Suncor Energy Products Inc., Sarnia, Ont., Canada; Ponce, G., Suncor Energy Products Inc., Sarnia, Ont., Canada; Wilkinson, S., Suncor Energy Products Inc., Sarnia, Ont., Canada
Abstract: The collaborative benefits of consistent, timely, and integrated plant information are well known to refineries. However, achieving a truly integrated refinery information system continues to be a major challenge for refineries around the world. With support from Honeywell technology and services, Suncor Energy Inc has successfully deployed a highly integrated information system at its Sarnia refinery in Canada. Seamless integration of all plant information was achieved through automatic data gathering, data reconciled mass balances, LP production model updates, and integration with on-line closed loop advanced process control and real time optimization. A discussion covers the value and benefits of an integrated plant information system from several end-user perspectives, including Suncor Energy's management, operations, process control, and information technology functions; successful installation and use of solutions for yield accounting, production management, plant information, movements and storage, and laboratory information; and Suncor Energy's path forward for increasing employee collaboration through the use of web reports and visualization, replacement of custom software with standard, and integration with future technologies.

Authors: Berger K., Nakamura T., Bruch M.
Title: Toner Binder Resins with Improved Fusing Properties
Source title: International Conference on Digital Printing Technologies
Affiliations: Research Chemist, Ticona GmbH, Frankfurt, Germany; Ticona Japan Ltd., Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Berger, K., Research Chemist, Ticona GmbH, Frankfurt, Germany; Nakamura, T., Ticona Japan Ltd., Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Bruch, M., Research Chemist, Ticona GmbH, Frankfurt, Germany
Abstract: This study describes the latest progress in toner binder design to achieve low fusing temperatures as required for new energy regulations like the ZESM (Zero Energy Stand-by Mode). Conventionally low temperature fusing is realized by reducing the molar mass of the binder polymer. In parallel with a reduced melt viscosity the glass transitions temperature Tg decreases resulting in a poor storage ability. This phenomenon is reviewed for typical toner binder resins like styrene acrylics and polyester and compared to cyclo-olefin-copolymers COC derived from ethylene and norbonene (trade name: Topas® of Ticona, Germany). For these new materials the glass transition temperature is easily adjusted by incorporating different amounts of the cyclic olefin into the polymer meaning that the Tg of COC can be controlled independently of molar mass. Thus an optimum balance between low melt viscosity necessary for low temperature fusing and excellent anti blocking properties is obtained. In addition Topas® COC binder resins offer a unique combination of surface, electrical, mechanical and environmental friendly properties which is ideal for using these material as toner binder resins.
Index Keywords: Binders; Energy utilization; Glass transition; Low temperature effects; Photography; Resins; Molar mass; Toner binder resins; Printing

Authors: Dürr M., Cruden A., McDonald J.

Abstract: The aim of this work is to introduce the design of a domestic scale Fuel Cell (FC) system capable of co-generation of electrical and thermal power. The system built at Strathclyde University is a pilot system, which will demonstrate the feasibility of using low temperature FCs, especially Alkaline Fuel Cells (AFC), for domestic scale power generation with the combined use of heat and power (CHP). This paper presents detailed information about the unique design employing a liquid-to-liquid heat exchanger to allow coupling to an existing central heating system. The remainder of this paper concentrates on investigating the electrical control of the FC integration with a storage battery bank capable of supplying particular load demands. A study of the appropriate relative sizing of the FC and battery for a given load combination is also discussed. A control and monitoring system for the system has been developed and is briefly discussed. An outlook of the future work on this system is also presented.

Authors: Bouneb B., Cruden A., Grant D.M., McDonald J.R.
Title: Design and control of a MOSFET-based DC/DC booster
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Department of EEE, Institute of Environment, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; Electronic Engineering Dept., Institute of Energy and Environment, University of Strathclyde, 204 George Street, Glasgow G1 1XW, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bouneb, B., Department of EEE, Institute of Environment, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom, Electronic Engineering Dept., Institute of Energy and Environment, University of Strathclyde, 204 George Street, Glasgow G1 1XW, United Kingdom; Cruden, A., Department of EEE, Institute of Environment, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; Grant, D.M., Department of EEE, Institute of Environment, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; McDonald, J.R., Department of EEE, Institute of Environment, University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom
Abstract: The envisaged future shortage in conventional energy sources for electric power generation has encouraged research and development of alternative generation technologies based on sustainable, renewable energy sources. In order to be compatible with existing electricity supplies it is preferred that these alternative technologies should be interfaced with utility systems. This can mean, for some forms of renewable energy the use of a power electronic interface for power conditioning, e.g. photovoltaic or fuel cell systems. The objective of this paper is to consider the power electronic interface from a fuel cell system, as a low voltage dc source, to a higher voltage storage battery and associated load, which could include a dc/ac inverter for utility connection. The most important requirements for such a power electronic converter in a typical domestic power application are high efficiency and low cost. To meet these requirements, a dc/dc step-up converter has been designed, based on a conventional topology, using a p-channel power MOSFET of ultra-low on-state resistance. The design and performance of this converter are presented in detail.
Index Keywords: Conventional energy sources; Electric potential; Electric power generation; Electric resistance; Environmental impact; Fossil fuels; MOSFET devices; Renewable energy resources; Secondary batteries; Electric exciters

Authors: Hafiz Hamza A.S., Abdel-Gawad N.M., Salama M.M., Hegazy A., El-Debeiky S.
Title: Unified energy network in the Arab world-future expectations
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Shoubra Faculty of Engineering, Zagazig University, Cairo, Egypt; Egyptian Elec. Holding Co. (EEHC), Cairo, Egypt; Faculty of Engineering, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Hafiz Hamza, A.S., Shoubra Faculty of Engineering, Zagazig University, Cairo, Egypt; Abdel-Gawad, N.M., Shoubra Faculty of Engineering, Zagazig University, Cairo, Egypt; Salama, M.M., Shoubra Faculty of Engineering, Zagazig University, Cairo, Egypt; Hegazy, A., Egyptian Elec. Holding Co. (EEHC), Cairo, Egypt; El-Debeiky, S., Faculty of Engineering, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: The unified power system network is one of the main features of the world policy for serving the electrical energy. One example for such a system is the unified Egyptian Jordanian electrical power system network, which aims to secure the supply of electrical energy for the two countries. This unified network has already been established and exists in service, connecting both Egypt and Jordan since 1998. In the near future other countries will be connected to this network, starting from Morocco in the west, Saudi Arabia in the east, Syria in the north down to Sudan in the south. This network, in turn, will be connected to the unified European network through Turkey in the north. A precise load forecasting study is necessary required for this unified network This work concerns with the Egyptian Jordanian unified network, which is the first stage of the Unified Arab World Power System Network. The studies of this work are carried out using one of the econometric method techniques, which is called "Multiple Regression Curve Fit". Using this technique, the peak load, generation energy and energy sales are estimated for the coming years. For the cases of the study, actual data of the unified power system, through the last few years are used, then the output results are compared with the input data for testing the accuracy of the technique used. The study also concentrates and highlights on the accuracy and sensitivity of the applied model used for this study. The proposed technique for the interconnected networks can be applied to simple as well as practical and complicated power system networks.
Author Keywords: Econometric Method; Egyptian-Jordanian Unified network; Load Forecasting; Planning
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric load forecasting; Electric loads; Electric power system interconnection; Planning; Regression analysis; Sales; Econometric method; Egyptian-Jordanian unified network; Electrical energy; Load forecasting; Electric power systems

Authors: Drif M., Achaibou N.
Title: A new approach for the modeling of lead acid batteries in stand alone photovoltaic system using Pspice
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Renewable Ener. Development Centre, Algiers, Algeria
Authors with affiliations: Drif, M., Renewable Ener. Development Centre, Algiers, Algeria; Achaibou, N., Renewable Ener. Development Centre, Algiers, Algeria
Abstract: The study of a photovoltaic system behavior by means of an electronic simulator such Pspice, requires in a first time, equivalent models (or circuits) of the main components such as photovoltaic generator model, storage element (batteries). The knowledge of their electrical characteristics remains a key factor in the simulation analysis. The aim of the present paper is to develop a lead acid battery model using the Analog Behavioral Modeling (ABM) option available with MicroSim's PSpice simulation software, in order to enrich the famous library of Pspice. For this end a general battery model for PV system proposed by J. Copetti et al was selected to be implemented. In this paper the validation of the Pspice model of lead acid battery is also presented.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Computer software; Electric discharges; Electric generators; Electric resistance; Energy conversion; Lead acid batteries; Analog behavioral modeling (ABM); Pspice models; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Toishi M., Okamoto A., Sato K.
Title: Dynamic Dropout Data Restoring Technique in All-optical Fault Tolerant Holographic Memory
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Graduate School of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Hokkaido, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Toishi, M., Graduate School of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Hokkaido, Japan; Okamoto, A., Graduate School of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Hokkaido, Japan; Sato, K.
Abstract: We have proposed the all-optical fault-tolerant holographic memory (FTHM) that automatically restores the dropout data by the constant rewriting method. In this method, the constant rewriting is conducted in the normal state or dropout state, so this data restoring is inefficient in terms of the restoring speed and the energy consumption. In this paper, we propose a dynamic dropout data restoring technique in the FTHM. In this dynamic technique, the strength of the rewriting effect change in proportion to dropout level, i.e. if dropout level becomes large, the strength of the rewriting effect also becomes large automatically. Therefore, this dynamic technique can improve the restoring speed and reduce the energy consumption for restoring. First, we analyze the temporal response of the output efficiency and the hologram. Next we analyze the dependency of the output efficiency on the coupling strength in the two crystals and the incident condition of two beams, and estimate the coupling strength threshold and the ratio of the incident beams in order to maintain the stored data. Finally, we experiment on the dropout data restoring by using BaTiO3 as photorefractive crystal, and achieve the data restoring for 2-3 seconds and the over 25 minutes readout.
Author Keywords: Fault-tolerant; Four-wave mixing; Holographic memory; Photorefractive effect
Index Keywords: Barium titanate; Crystals; Fault tolerant computer systems; Four wave mixing; Holograms; Optical data storage; Optical recording; Photoreactivity; Photorefractive materials; Constant rewriting method; Holographic memory; Holography

Authors: Springis M., Brikmane L., Tale I., Kulis P.
Title: Electronic excitations and defects in Fluoroperovskite LiBaF3
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St, Riga, LV-1063, Latvia
Authors with affiliations: Springis, M., Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St, Riga, LV-1063, Latvia; Brikmane, L., Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St, Riga, LV-1063, Latvia; Tale, I., Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St, Riga, LV-1063, Latvia; Kulis, P., Institute of Solid State Physics, University of Latvia, 8 Kengaraga St, Riga, LV-1063, Latvia
Abstract: A survey of the present situation with respect to knowledge of lattice defects, electronic excitations, such as excitons and localized excitons, as well as energy storage and transfer phenomena in LiBaF3 crystals is given. Both phenomenological models and experimental interpretations of optical absorption bands, tentatively associated with F-type (electron) centres created by X-ray or electron irradiation , is reviewed. Interpretation of three radiative processes (super-fast core-valence transitions, slow trapped exciton luminescence and luminescence of structure defects) observed in undoped LiBaF3 crystals is analysed with respect to practical application. Attention is paid to the behaviour of ultraviolet emission so far ascribed to self-trapped exciton luminescence and also observed as a result of electron recombination with localized hole at various temperatures (even at room temperature), depending on crystal purity and growth conditions. Finally, some aspects of ionic processes in thermal relaxation of defects are pointed to.
Author Keywords: Absorption; Color centers; Excitons; LiBaF3 crystals; Luminescence
Index Keywords: Color; Electron irradiation; Excitons; Light absorption; Lithium compounds; Perovskite; Photolithography; Ultraviolet radiation; X rays; Electronic excitations; Fluorescence

Authors: Sharma S.K.
Title: Geothermal Energy Potential of India
Affiliations: 353 Sector 37, Noida 201301, India
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, S.K., 353 Sector 37, Noida 201301, India
Abstract: The survey and studies conducted by Geological Survey of India led to the identification of about 340 geothermal hot springs in nine different geothermal provinces in the country. Geothermal exploration carried out in India has generated valuable data through extensive scientific studies backed-up by drilling at selected geothermal locations such as Puga, Manikaran, Tatapani, etc. To investigate structural, geological, geo-chemical, hydrological and thermal parameters of geothermal systems. Initial estimates of promising geothermal manifestations suggest power generation potential of about 10000 MW. In india the use of geothermal energy has been demonstrated for small scale power generation, in a cold storage unit, in mushroom cultivation and poultry farming in the Manikaran area of Himachal Pradesh and the Laddakh region of Jammu & Kashmir. Keeping in view the potential and environmentally benign nature of geothermal power it is felt necessary to develop some of the geothermal sites in the country for power generation on commercial basis.
Author Keywords: Geothermal; Heat flow; Hot springs; Power generation; Thermal wells
Index Keywords: Heat transfer; Hot springs; Power generation; Heat flow; Geothermal energy

Authors: Poranen J., Kataja M., Grön J., Niemistö A.
Title: Experimental study of nip dynamics in metered size press coating
Source title: TAPPI Coating and Graphic Arts Conference Trade Fair
Affiliations: VTT Processes, P.O.Box 1603, FIN-40101 Jyväskylä, Finland; Valmet Corporation, Wärtsilänkatu 100, FIN-04400 Järvenpää, Finland; Numerola Oy, Väinönkatu 11 A, FIN-40100 Jyväskylä, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Poranen, J., VTT Processes, P.O.Box 1603, FIN-40101 Jyväskylä, Finland; Kataja, M., VTT Processes, P.O.Box 1603, FIN-40101 Jyväskylä, Finland; Grön, J., Valmet Corporation, Wärtsilänkatu 100, FIN-04400 Järvenpää, Finland; Niemistö, A., Numerola Oy, Väinönkatu 11 A, FIN-40100 Jyväskylä, Finland
Abstract: The pressure distribution in both the metering nip and the film transfer nip was measured using handmade pressure sensors placed under the roll cover material. The influence of the roll speed, the linear load, and the coating suspension on the measured pressure profile was studied. The influence of the roll speed on the measured pressure profile was found to be minimal, whereas the effect of the linear load was evident. Even though the pressure profile was measured under the roll cover material the measured values were relatively high. This sets high requirements for the roll cover materials. Strain profiles of the roll cover material in the nip contacts and the heat build-up of the cover material during the coating process were measured with strain gauges and thermocouples installed inside the roll cover material. It was observed that the temperature of the roll cover material increased several tens of degrees depending on both the linear load and the machine speed. Such a temperature increase has a distinct effect on the dynamic mechanical properties of the roll cover material and thus probably on the whole coating process. The measured strain profiles of the roll cover material in the nip contacts were consistent and correlated realistically with the pressure profile and temperature measurements.
Index Keywords: Coatings; Dynamic mechanical analysis; Energy storage; Strain gages; Viscoelasticity; Roll covers; Paper; Coatings; Paper; Strain Gages; Viscoelasticity

Authors: Srivastava V.C.
Title: Technology: Water removal: A case study for removal of residual produced water
Authors with affiliations: Srivastava, V.C.
Abstract: Cairn Energy India Pty Ltd is producing oil and gas in Ravva Oil and Gas Field located in the East Coast of India in the Bay of Bengal. The present oil production is ∼ 50,000 bpd oil and 0.8 million cu m/day gas. During the year 2010-2011, the oil production rate is expected to reduce to 15,000 bpd and water production rate will increase to 49,000 bpd oil. The process of draining water will expose oil storage tank bottoms to produced water, leading to severe corrosion. The case was studied by John Brown Technologies India (JBTI) and used the existing crude oil tank T-102C as a wash tank to remove water from crude before it went to the crude storage tanks. This was a challenging task for JBTI into a wash tank acting as an intermediate processing vessel for water removal. The description of the problems faced, description of the solutions provided, and the major mechanical changes were discussed.

Authors: Imai T., Lizuka T., Makino Y., Horikoshi T.
Title: Development and testing of multifunctional operation system for various power sources (simulation result using analogue power system simulator)
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Affiliations: Engineering Center, Electric Power Development Co., Ltd., Tokyo 104-8145, Japan; Chigasaki R and D Center, Electric Power Development Co. Ltd., Kanagawa 253-0041, Japan; Kaihatsu Comp. Service Center, Ltd., Tokyo 135-8451, Japan

Abstract: Deregulation of electric power market is now in progress in Japan, and various kinds of power sources are emerging. Then, economical and efficient coordinating operation of existing and new facilities is needed. In this study, two types of new control software have been developed to meet variety of customers' needs. One is called "Optimum Economical Dispatching Program", which realizes optimum operation among various power sources, such as gas turbines, fuel cells, energy storage system and utility supply menu. The other is called "Load Following Program", which controls generators to follow the varying loads. Also, the "Control and Interface Unit", which sends and receives control and supervisory data of generators and loads, had been developed as a SCADA system. In this paper, newly developed controlling programs and control and interface unit will be introduced with the test results using analogue power system simulator.
Author Keywords: Deregulation; Distributed power; Economical dispatch; Load following; Power system simulator; SCADA
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Computer software; Deregulation; Electric energy storage; Electric load dispatching; Fuel cells; Gas turbines; SCADA systems; Software engineering; Power sources; Electric utilities

Abstract: A capacitor discharge joining technique used to fabricate alumina (Al2O3) tile - titanium foil - Al2O3 tile joint was investigated to optimize the energy injected into the foil. The large current was supplied to the foil sandwiched with Al2O3 tiles using storage capacitor which was charged up to several kVs. The Al2O3 tiles were successfully bonded when the charged voltage in the capacitor was same value with the energy required for vaporization of the titanium foils. The bonding strength increases with energy input to the foil. The bonding also increases from 600 to 1250 N shear strength with increasing compression stress on the A2O3 tiles from 1.1 to 4.2 MPa at use of 5 mm width titanium foil as the interlayer. An investigation of the interfacial structure of the joints using electron probe micro-analysis revealed that distinct reaction areas existed in the interlayers.
Index Keywords: Alumina; Bond strength (materials); Bonding; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric potential; Joints (structural components); Metal foil; Optimization; Surface structure; Tile; Titanium; Alumina tile; Capacitor discharge joining technique; Electron probe microanalysis; Explosive interlayer metal foil; Titanium foil; Capacitors

Title: Neutronic analysis of a liquid-4He source for ultra-cold neutron production and storage
Source title: Applied Physics A: Materials Science and Processing
Affiliations: Department of Nuclear Engineering, Kyoto University, Yoshida, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8501, Japan; Power and Indust. Syst. R and D Lab., Hitachi Ltd., 7-2-1 Ohmika, Hitachi 391-1221, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Abe, Y., Department of Nuclear Engineering, Kyoto University, Yoshida, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8501, Japan, Power and Indust. Syst. R and D Lab., Hitachi Ltd., 7-2-1 Ohmika, Hitachi 391-1221, Japan; Morishima, N., Department of Nuclear Engineering, Kyoto University, Yoshida, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8501, Japan
Abstract: Ultra-cold neutron (UCN) production and storage in a liquid-4He source are evaluated by means of multi-group neutron-transport analysis. Using the cross-section model developed by the authors, a set of group constants for liquid 4He at many different temperatures down to 0.1 K is generated. Major results thus obtained are as follows. As the temperature is decreased below about 0.5 K, the UCN density shows a saturation behavior because of no significant up-scattering and UCN loss by neutron β-decay only. Single down-scattering of a 1-meV neutron and also multiple scattering of a higher-energy neutron contribute largely to UCN production. A high UCN density of 1 × 105 cm-3 is possible with a high reflectivity of a storage vessel, say over 0.9999.
Index Keywords: Atoms; Density (specific gravity); Mathematical models; Neutron scattering; Phonons; Polynomials; Superfluid helium; Thermal effects; Neutronic transport analysis; Ultracold neutron; Ultracold neutron production and storage; Neutron sources

Authors: Brož M., Málek J., Růžek B., Horáček M.
Title: Seismic events at the underground gas storage Háje-Příbram (Czech Republic) (abstract)
Source title: Publications of the Institute of Geophysics, Polish Academy of Sciences, Series M: Miscellanea
Affiliations: Inst. of Rock Structure/Mech. AS CR, V Holesovičkách 41, Praha 8 182 09, Czech Republic; Geophysical Institute AS CR, Bočni II/1401, Praha 4 14131, Czech Republic; Plynoprojekt Praha a.s., Sokolská 44, Praha 2 120 00, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Brož, M., Inst. of Rock Structure/Mech. AS CR, V Holesovičkách 41, Praha 8 182 09, Czech Republic; Málek, J., Inst. of Rock Structure/Mech. AS CR, V Holesovičkách 41, Praha 8 182 09, Czech Republic; Růžek, B., Geophysical Institute AS CR, Bočni II/1401, Praha 4 14131, Czech Republic; Horáček, M., Plynoprojekt Praha a.s., Sokolská 44, Praha 2 120 00, Czech Republic
Abstract: The underground gas storage was built in 1998 near Příbram, Czech Republic, at a depth of 1000 m. A seismic network has been established in the area in order to monitor local seismic activity. 187 seismic events up to magnitude 1.7 have been registered since August 1998 (Fig. 1). The epicenters of the shocks form a narrow belt along the principal geological fault in the area. The depth of the hypocenters is from 0.3 to 1.9 km. Mechanisms of the strongest events were computed (Fig. 2). The nature of the shocks is not definitely clear yet. In our opinion, the primary reason for generation of seismic events is the tectonic stress affecting the geological fault near the gas storage, but the individual shocks are mainly accidental destruction of previously made cavities. Releasing of the seismic energy is triggered probably by the rising groundwater level.
Index Keywords: gas storage; induced seismicity; seismicity; underground storage; water level; Czech Republic

Title: Contribution of GEANT4 to the determination of sensitive volumes in case of high-integrated RAMs
Source title: Proceedings of the European Conference on Radiation and its Effects on Components and Systems, RADECS

Abstract: This paper deals with the use of short range beams in order to measure the sensitive thickness of devices. In the case of a Hitachi 4-Mbit SRAM, σ(E) measurements have been compared to GEANT 4 calculations, taking into account the effects of the overlayers. The analysis of the experimental data at two bias levels has pointed out that σ(E) is directly correlated with the energy deposited in SV for low ranges, on the other hand charge collection mechanisms have a strong impact for longer ranges.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: ETEF distortionary
Abstract: The Federal minister for industry, tourism and resource labeled the NSW Electricity Tariff equalisation Fund (ETEF) as the most distortionary mechanism in the marketplace. The minister cited various issues that included better governance, greater harmony of state regulatory arrangement, improvement of inter-connectability and security of supply, improved choice for retail customers and better private controls. The electricity prices were raised for business customers in NSW and for consumers in other states.

Authors: Karthaus W., Hordijk A.C., Van Driel C.A., Schoolderman C.
Title: Development, production and characterisation of LOVA gun propellants
Source title: Kayaku Gakkaishi/Journal of the Japan Explosives Society
Affiliations: TNO Prins Maurits Laboratory, P.O. Box 45, 2280 AA Rijswijk, Netherlands

Box 45, 2280 AA Rijswijk, Netherlands
Abstract: In developing gun propellants a number of aspects are of importance. Apart from the performance improvement, higher specific impulse and a lower flame temperature, requirements for safe production, storage and storage lifetime can be mentioned. At TNO-PML gun propellant compositions have been developed and investigated over the years. A number of compositions have been evaluated for their energy content and ballistic performance. A selected number have been produced on a small scale and tested. Some compositions have been produced with a twin screw extruder and underwent full scale testing. The paper describes process modelling and processing safety aspects of laboratory scale processing. Furthermore the internal ballistic and performance characterisation and safety properties of the LOVA propellants that are under development will be presented. The paper ends with a summary of future developments at TNO-PML with respect to gun propellants and concluding remarks.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Ballistics; Combustion; Cost effectiveness; Explosives; Flammability; Plastic bonded explosives (PBX); Propellants

Title: Electron cooling system for ITEP ion storage ring
Affiliations: Inst. for Theor./Exp. Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Inst. of Theor./Experimental Physics, 117259 Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Zenkevich, P.R., Inst. for Theor./Exp. Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation; Bykovsky, V.F., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Korotaev, Yu.V., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Meshkov, I.N., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Sidorin, A.O., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Smirnov, A.V., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Syresin, Ye.M., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Titkova, I.V., Joint Institute of Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation
Abstract: The main goal of the Tera Watt A Cumulator project (Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, Moscow) is accumulation in the storage ring of an intense ion beam, its longitudinal compression and the use of the extracted beam for plasma experiments. However, beam parameters at the target are decreased because of extreme transverse heating and growth of the beam momentum spread due to intrabeam scattering. These effects can be suppressed by application of the electron cooling system (ECS). Design study of ECS has been performed in the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research. The design project and characteristics of the system are described, as well as analysis of the accumulation kinetics in the presence of the cooling system. Design work has shown that because of the small length of the straight section (2.35 m), the effective length of the cooling system is small (about 55-60 cm). Nevertheless, for long accumulation times (>100 s), the system allows us to significantly improve the beam parameters at the target (specific energy, specific power, and so on) and to suppress the beam losses by an order of magnitude.
Author Keywords: Electron cooling systems; Intrabeam scattering; Ion accumulation; Nonlinear resonances
Index Keywords: Compaction; Cooling systems; Electromagnetic wave scattering; Electron resonance; Electrons; Heating; Plasmas; Reaction kinetics; Storage rings; Electron cooling systems; Ion beams

Authors: Stritih U., Studen S., Brenčič M., Lapanje A.
Title: The analysis of thermal energy storage in aquifers - The possibility of application in Slovenia [Analiza shranjevanja toplote v vodonosnikih - Možnost uporabe v Sloveniji]
Affiliations: University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Mechanical Eng., Aškerčeva 6, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Geological Survey of Slovenia, Dimičeva 14, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Stritih, U., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Mechanical Eng., Aškerčeva 6, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Studen, S., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Mechanical Eng., Aškerčeva 6, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Brenčič, M., Geological Survey of Slovenia, Dimičeva 14, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Lapanje, A., Geological Survey of Slovenia, Dimičeva 14, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: Tendencies towards rational energy use have been appearing for the last decades due to the fact of limited quantities of fossil fuels and increased ecological awareness. Also the rising prices of all fuels should be taken into account. Since energy consumption will increase in the future, the possibility of using renewable energy resources and rational energy use are investigated. The quality of energy exploitation can be increased by storing thermal energy in different types of storage. This is especially important for waste heat from industrial processes, which is usually thrown away. This heat can be efficiently used in low-temperature heating systems. The same holds true for heat from condensing units of air-conditioning systems. One of the solutions is thermal energy storage in seasonal storage, where aquifers are one of the possibilities. Since they are very large, the amount of heat that can be stored is very high. The paper gives a review of thermal energy storage methods in aquifers, describes such storage in the world with a basic mathematical description of the processes in aquifers, and presents the possibilities of use in Slovenia. © 2002 Journal of Mechanical Engineering. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Aquifers; Heat transfer; Mass transfer; Thermal storage
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy utilization; Fossil fuels; Heat transfer; Mass transfer; Renewable energy resources; Thermal energy storage; Energy storage

Abstract: The WG3 of IEC TC21 has made further progress in the establishment of an International Standard for Stationary Lead Acid Batteries of the VRLA type. The section specifying the test methods (IEC 60896-2-1) has progressed to the IEC CDV stage and all 21 test clauses have won the informal support of battery manufactures and battery users.
