Authors: Nakagawa M.
Title: Chaos associative memory model
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Intelligent Control - Proceedings
Affiliations: Nagaoka University of Technology, Kamitomioka 1603-1, Nagaoka, Niigata 940-2188, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakagawa, M., Nagaoka University of Technology, Kamitomioka 1603-1, Nagaoka, Niigata 940-2188, Japan
Abstract: In this paper we shall propose a chaos dynamic memory model applied to the chaotic autoassociation memory. The present artificial neuron model is properly characterized in terms of a time-dependent sinusoidal activation function to involve a transient chaotic dynamics as well as the energy steepest descent strategy. It is elucidated that the present neural network has a remarkable retrieval ability beyond the conventional models with such a monotonous activation function as sigmoidal one. This advantage is found to result from the property of the analogue periodic mapping accompanied with a chaotic behaviour of the neurons as well as the symmetry of the dynamic equation.
Author Keywords: Associative memory; Chaos neuron; Sinusoidal mapping
Index Keywords: Chaos theory; Dynamics; Functions; Mathematical models; Neural networks; Statistical methods; Activation function; Chaos associative memory; Energy steepest descent strategy; Sinusoidal mapping; Transient chaotic dynamics; Associative storage

Authors: Antropov V., Ivanov A., Korotaev Yu., Mamedov T., Meshkov I., Seleznev I., Sidorin A., Smirnov A., Syresin E., Trubnikov G., Yakovenko S.
Title: Development of the new method of positronium generation. Abilities and future trends
Affiliations: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Antropov, V., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Ivanov, A., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Korotaev, Yu., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Mamedov, T., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Meshkov, I., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Seleznev, I., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Sidorin, A., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Smirnov, A., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Syresin, E., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Trubnikov, G., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation; Yakovenko, S., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, Russian Federation
Abstract: Presently the positron ring dedicated to positronium generation and called the Low Energy Positron Toroidal Accumulator (LEPTA) is under construction at JINR (Dubna). The main application of this ring is the generation of a monoenergetic and directed flux of positronium atoms and its use in experiments. Positronium is generated in interactions of positrons, circulating inside a storage ring accumulator, with free electrons of the cooling electron beam that have velocities very close to the positron velocities. This allows us to obtain a high positronium flux with small angular and velocity spreads of the atoms and provides a significant advantage for the proposed arrangement of experiments, so-called positronium-in-flight setups, as compared with traditional approaches in which positronium was generated in targets. In particular, the precision in measuring positronium parameters (lifetime, the probability of decays with momentum conservation, charge invariant violation (CPT violation), fine structure of the positronium spectrum, and Lamb-shift measurements) can be enhanced by several orders of magnitude. Moreover, some experiments that are unrealistic within traditional schemes become feasible with the proposed facility.

Authors: Kale B.B., Gokarn A.N.
Title: Effect of particle size on thermal decomposition of lime shells: Suitability of calcined lime shell for pollution control and energy storage
Affiliations: Ctr. Mat. For Electronics Technol., Off Pashan Road, Pune 411 008, India; Chemical Engineering Division, National Chemical Laboratory, Pashan Road, Pune 411 008, India
Authors with affiliations: Kale, B.B., Ctr. Mat. For Electronics Technol., Off Pashan Road, Pune 411 008, India; Gokarn, A.N., Chemical Engineering Division, National Chemical Laboratory, Pashan Road, Pune 411 008, India
Abstract: Lime shells obtained from the lagoons of Kerala Coast have been decomposed with a view to study the effect of particle size. A modified TGA has been used to study the decomposition kinetics at various temperatures. Conversion time data obtained showed typical sigmoidal behaviour and the decomposition kinetics could be fitted to the Prout-Tompkins model at all temperatures and for all particle sizes studied. Arrhenius kinetic parameters showed normal type of compensation behaviour indicating an isokinetic temperature of 730°C. A theoretical explanation for these observed compensation behaviour and isokinetic temperature has been given. Further, the calcined lime shell has been tested for the capture of CO2 and SO2 using TGA. Effects of temperature of decomposition and particle size have been studied in this case. A theoretical, explanation based on pore size distribution of the calcined lime for this special behaviour has been given.
Index Keywords: calcium oxide; carbon dioxide; sulfur oxide; article; decomposition; model; particle size; pollution control; temperature sensitivity; thermogravimetry

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Market movement
Abstract: According to Stephen Smith, president and founder of Stephen Smith Energy Associates, continued drops in US natural gas production and drilling, and earlier draws of gas from storage because of colder fall weather, will tighten market fundamentals quickly. This surplus started in 2002 at 540 bcf over the weekly norm and peaked at over 700 bcf (in the first quarter of 2002). Smith had projected a draw of 63 bcf of gas from US underground storage during the week ended 11/8/2002, but EIA reported a draw of 48 bcf. Smith projected an addition of 27 bcf into storage for the week ended 11/15/2002. EIA reported 11/21/2002 a net decline of 1 bcf to < 3.1 tcf of gas in storage. US gas storage is down 124 bcf from 2001 levels but up 98 bcf from the 5-yr avg.

Authors: Köhler U.
Title: Variable-speed belt conveyors gaining in importance electrical engineering solutions have been consistently improved for the overburden belt conveyor in the Jänschwalde open-cast mine
Affiliations: Lausitzer Braunkohle Aktiengesellsc., Laubag, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Köhler, U., Lausitzer Braunkohle Aktiengesellsc., Laubag, Poland
Abstract: The described conveyor system of LAUBAG in the Jänschwalde open-cast mine is regarded as a pioneering, modern and innovative installation. The first-time use of controlled drives for overburden transport also enables load-dependent transport speeds. Sophisticated control concepts for the way in which the whole installation is operated have lead to better utilization of the installation. This is resulting in considerable improvements in the business figures [2], one of the reasons being the substantial energy savings. Noise emission levels of the conveyors have been significantly reduced. Modern diagnostic systems reduce downtime by assisting maintenance personnel diagnose and quickly rectify faults. Operational data collected by the system allow staff to analyze and optimize system performance. As a result, the operating costs are substantially reduced in comparison to conventional installations.
Author Keywords: LAUBAG; Mine conveyor systems; Technological optimization; Variable-speed drives
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Energy conservation; Installation; Operating costs; Variable speed drives; Conveyor systems; Diagnostic systems; LAUBAG; Maintenance personnel; Operational data; Substantial energy; Technological optimization; Transport speed; Belt conveyors

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Equipment/Software/Literature: Remote monitor notifies via fax, pager, email
Abstract: Instruwatch remote monitoring system from Siemens Energy & Automation checks inputs from equipment remotely and provides notification of alarm events by fax, pager, or email. There is no software to install and no annual maintenance is required. The unit monitors and controls cathodic equipment, storage tank levels, pump stations, gas compressors, and pipelines.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick takes: Trans-Northern Pipelines Inc.,...
Abstract: Trans-Northern Pipelines Inc (Ontario, Canada) has applied to Canada's National Energy Board to increase its petroleum products pipeline system capacity from Montreal (Quebec, Canada) to Farran's Point (Ontario, Canada), and to reverse the direction of flow from Farran's Point to Toronto, Canada. The project would include replacing four line segments totaling 45 mi of 10-in. pipeline with 16-in. pipeline between Montreal and Farran's Point, upgrading four existing pump stations at Montreal and Como in Quebec, and Lancaster and Ingleside in Ontario, and constructing storage tanks at the Farran's Point pump station. Trans-Northern also proposed to construct three pump stations along the existing 10-in. pipeline near Iroquois, Mallorytown, and Kingston in Ontario, to accommodate flow reversal. Capacity from Montreal to Farran's Point will increase to 741,000 from 371,000 cu ft/day upon completion of the expansion project. The project is estimated to cost $(Can)82.25 million and targeted completion date is in the middle of 2004.

Authors: Saito M., Shimizu T.
Title: A novel strategy for a high-power utility interactive inverter with a series active filter
Source title: Electrical Engineering in Japan (English translation of Denki Gakkai Ronbunshi)
Affiliations: Tokyo Metropolitan University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saito, M., Tokyo Metropolitan University, Japan; Shimizu, T., Tokyo Metropolitan University, Japan
Abstract: High-power utility interactive inverters used for large-capacity energy storage systems are composed of multiple connected inverters, in order to realize high efficiency and high performance of the harmonic elimination characteristic simultaneously. Some disadvantages of multiple connected inverters, such as harmonic current flowing from an inverter unit to the other one, and increase of the number of inverter units, cannot be overcome easily. This paper presents a novel strategy for a high-power utility interactive inverter, which is composed of a large power with low-switching-frequency PWM inverter (high-power PWM inverter), an LC passive filter, and a series active filter (series AF). Because harmonic components contained in the utility line current are absorbed by the series AF, the switching frequency of the PWM inverter can be selected to about 1 kHz. In addition because the power capacity and the output voltage of the series AF can be suppressed lower than 10% of the power capacity and the output voltage of PWM inverter, low-voltage and high-speed power devices can be applied to the series AF. Consequently, high power, high efficiency, and high harmonics elimination performance can be realized without increasing the number of inverter units. © 2002 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. Electr. Eng. Jpn., 141(2).
Author Keywords: High-power PWM inverter; Series active filter; Utility interactive inverter
Index Keywords: Active filters; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electric utilities; Passive filters; Pulse width modulation; Switching; Interactive inverters; Electric inverters

Authors: Kato Y., Yoshizawa Y., Cerkvenik B., Minakami A.
Title: The suitability of magnesium oxide and water for use in chemical heat storage [Primernost reakcije magnezijevega oksida z vodo za uporabo v kemičnem hralnilniku toplote]
Affiliations: Res. Laboratory for Nuclar Reactors, Tokyo Institute of Technology, O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8550, Japan; University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Mechanical Eng., Ǎskeřceva 6, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; NSK Ltd. 1-5-50, Fujisawa-shi 251-8501, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kato, Y., Res. Laboratory for Nuclar Reactors, Tokyo Institute of Technology, O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8550, Japan; Yoshizawa, Y., Res. Laboratory for Nuclar Reactors, Tokyo Institute of Technology, O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8550, Japan; Cerkvenik, B., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Mechanical Eng., Ǎskeřceva 6, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia; Minakami, A., NSK Ltd. 1-5-50, Fujisawa-shi 251-8501, Japan
Abstract: Because of their high energy density, chemical heat pumps are an interesting possibility for heat storage. With reversible chemical reactions the heat can be stored or released on demand by controlling the flow of the reactive fluid. If they prove to have satisfactory repeatability, the reversible reactions can also be used in a heat storage system for cogeneration systems. In this way it would be possible to even out the load of the cogeneration system: in a period of low heat demand the surplus heat is stored with the chemical reaction in the heat storage and during a peak load period it can be released with the reverse reaction. In this paper we discuss the operation of a chemical heat pump that uses the reaction between magnesium oxide and water. In this case the heat can be stored with a dehydration process at about 300-400 °C and released with a hydration process at about 100-200 °C. In order to test the potential of magnesium hydroxide as a reactive medium for heat pumps we performed reaction experiments over a range of operation pressures between 30 kPa and 203 kPa. For the experiment, a specially prepared reactant with good properties for repetitive operation was packed in a cylindrical reactor. The experimental cycle consisted of an endothermic dehydration of the magnesium hydroxide for the heat storage, and an exothermic hydration of the magnesium oxide for the heat release. The cycle is repeated under various operating conditions that are characteristic for a heat-]storage operation of a cogeneration system. Both directions of the reversible reaction were studied by measuring the reactor-bed temperature distribution and the reacted fraction changes. We conclude with a discussion of a practical application and the mean heat output rate of the reactor. © 2002 Journal of Mechanical Engineering. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Chemical heat pumps; Cogeneration; Heat storage; Magnesium oxide
Index Keywords: Dehydration; Flow of fluids; Heat pump systems; Magnesia; Water; Chemical heat storage; Heat storage

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Policy statement; Energy Information Administration Policy for revisions to the weekly natural gas storage report
Abstract: The EIA has established a policy for revisions to weekly estimates of working gas volumes held in underground storage facilities at the national and regional levels disseminated in EIA's Weekly Natural Gas Storage Report (WNGSR). Revisions shall be disseminated in the WNGSR according to the established schedule and shall occur when the effect of reported changes is at least 7 bcf at either a regional or national level. Revisions shall not be disseminated outside the established schedule. The agency is deferring temporarily further updates in estimation parameters, and is exploring ways of minimizing revisions. It will continue with the current estimation parameters and will resort revisions as a result of respondent changes only, until further change is announced in the WNGSR. This policy becomes effective on 11/12/2002.

Authors: Hsieh C.-C.
Title: Smoothness in frame reduction
Affiliations: Industrial Management Science, National Cheng Kung University, 1 University Road, Tainan 70101, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Hsieh, C.-C., Industrial Management Science, National Cheng Kung University, 1 University Road, Tainan 70101, Taiwan
Abstract: A general framework for smoothing a finite sequential set of two-dimensional frames is proposed in this paper. It is intuitive that the more the number of frames is, the smoother the frames will be. However, the storage space required for handling the frames will also be increased. Given the desired size of the frames, finding an optimal frame set is facilitated by the notion of smoothness. The smoothness of a frame set is measured in terms of the energy embedded in the frame set, on the analogy of measuring the smoothness of motion data. A frame set with lower energy value is considered to be smoother. Then, the problem of finding a frame set of given frame size which gives the smoothest measure is formulated as an optimization problem that seeks to minimize the weighted sum of the frame energy and the sum of the squared distance errors.
Author Keywords: Computer-aided design; Data smoothing; Virtual reality
Index Keywords: Computer aided manufacturing; Optimization; Frame reduction; Operations research; computer aided design; smoothing; virtual reality

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick takes: SGR Holdings LLC...
Abstract: SGR Holdings LLC's (Houston, TX) wholly-owned subsidiary, SG Resources Mississippi LLC (SGRM), received FERC approval to construct and operate the Southern Pines Energy Center, a new salt cavern natural gas storage facility to be developed in Greene County, MS. The storage center will be a high-deliverability, natural gas storage facility that will provide 12 bcf of natural gas storage in two caverns (each with 8 bcf) upon completion. It will be capable of supporting natural gas withdrawal rates of ≤ 1.2 bcf/day and injection rates of ≤ 0.6 bcf/day. The center, which is scheduled to be operational by early 2004, will initially have a bi-directional interconnect with the Destin pipeline that provides direct access to five major pipeline systems. Construction plans include a Phase II development, which SGRM plans to submit for regulatory approvals in early 2003. Phase II will include bi-directional, direct interconnects to three main pipelines. These interconnects will be operational by first quarter of 2004.

Authors with affiliations: Oliveira de Tello, C.C., CNEN, CDTN, Caixa Postal 941 - Pampulha, 30123-970 - Belo Horizonte - MG, Brazil; De Oliveira Barroso, A.C., CNEN, CDTN, Caixa Postal 941 - Pampulha, 30123-970 - Belo Horizonte - MG, Brazil
Abstract: Evolving differences, in Brazilian regulatory framework from the time Angra I was designed, in the beginning of the sixties, to the time of license evaluation, in the late seventies, resulted in the unacceptability of the original waste solidification system. The end products could not reach the necessary characteristics required for transport and storage and a redesign was necessary to improve the cementation process. In the case of Angra II, which uses a bituminisation system to solidify its low and intermediate level liquid wastes, some minor adjustments had to be done in the process and a new bitumen specification had to be developed to select a Brazilian material so that the system could perform adequately and meet the national requirements for safe transportation and storage.
Index Keywords: Angra power plant; Bituminization; Brazil; Cementation; Nuclear energy; Nuclear power plants; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Sustainable development; Uranium; Waste treatment; Radioactive wastes

Authors: Gerasimov A.S., Bergelson B.R., Zaritskaya T.S., Tikhomirov G.V.
Title: Comparison of decay heat power of uranium, plutonium, and thorium spent fuel at long-term storage
Source title: International Conference on Nuclear Engineering, Proceedings, ICONE
Affiliations: ITEP, 25, B. Cheremushkinskaya, 117259 Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Gerasimov, A.S., ITEP, 25, B. Cheremushkinskaya, 117259 Moscow, Russian Federation; Bergelson, B.R., ITEP, 25, B. Cheremushkinskaya, 117259 Moscow, Russian Federation; Zaritskaya, T.S., ITEP, 25, B. Cheremushkinskaya, 117259 Moscow, Russian Federation; Tikhomirov, G.V., ITEP, 25, B. Cheremushkinskaya, 117259 Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Accumulation and subsequent storage of actinides from uranium, plutonium, and thorium spent fuel of PWR type reactor is discussed in the paper. During period of accumulation 100 or 300 years, actinides are periodically introduced in the storage facility. Subsequent period of 300 000 years is long-term storage without introduction of new portions of spent fuel. This time includes both period of controllable storage and ultimate geological storage. Decay heat power of actinides was calculated. It affects heat removal system of the storage facility. Maximal decay heat power of actinides from plutonium spent fuel corresponding to the end of the period of accumulation of 100 years is 2.5 times higher than that of uranium spent fuel. Maximal decay heat power of actinides from uranium spent fuel is 1.2 times higher than that of thorium spent fuel.
Author Keywords: Decay heat power; Spent fuel; Storage
Index Keywords: Decay heat power; Heat removal system; Long-term storage; Nuclear energy; Plutonium; Pressurized water reactors; Radioactive waste storage; Thorium; Uranium; Spent fuels

Authors: Ko F.-K., Liang T.K.S., Yang C.-Y.
Title: Development of thermal analysis capability of dry storage cask for spent fuel interim storage
Source title: International Conference on Nuclear Engineering, Proceedings, ICONE
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, 1000, Wenhua Road, Chiaan Village, Lungtan, Taoyuan, 325, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Ko, F.-K., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, 1000, Wenhua Road, Chiaan Village, Lungtan, Taoyuan, 325, Taiwan; Liang, T.K.S., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, 1000, Wenhua Road, Chiaan Village, Lungtan, Taoyuan, 325, Taiwan; Yang, C.-Y., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, 1000, Wenhua Road, Chiaan Village, Lungtan, Taoyuan, 325, Taiwan
Abstract: As most of the nuclear power plants, on-site spent fuel pools (SFP) of Taiwan's plants were not originally designed with a storage capacity for all the spent fuel generated over the operating life by their reactors. For interim spent fuel storage, dry casks are one of the most reliable measures to on-site store over-filled assemblies from SFPs. The NUHOMS®-52B System consisting of a canister stored horizontally in a concrete module is selected for thermal evaluation in this paper. The performance of each cask in criticality, radioactive, material and thermal needs to be carefully addressed to ensure its enduring safety. Regarding the thermal features of dry storage casks, three different kinds of heat transfer mechanisms are involved, which include natural convection heat transfer outside and/or inside the canister, radiation heat transfer inside and outside the canister, and conduction heat transfer inside the canister. To analyze the thermal performance of dry storage casks, RELAP5-3D is adopted to calculate the natural air convection and radiation heat transfer outside the canister to the ambient environment, and ANSYS is applied to calculate the internal conduction and radiation heat transfer. During coupling iteration between codes, the heat energy across the canister wall needs to be conserved, and the inner wall temperature of the canister needs to be converged. By the coupling of RELAP5-3D and ANSYS, the temperature distribution within each fuel assembly inside canisters can be calculated and the peaking cladding temperature can be identified.
Index Keywords: Dry storage cask; Radiation heat transfer; Spent fuel interim storage; Thermal performance; Accident prevention; Computer simulation; Heat conduction; Radiation; Spent fuels; Temperature distribution; Thermoanalysis; Thermodynamic stability; Containment vessels

Authors: VanderSteen J.D.J., Birk A.M.
Title: The effect of pressure relief valve blowdown and fire conditions on the thermo-hydraulics within a pressure vessel
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Queen's University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kingston, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: VanderSteen, J.D.J., Queen's University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kingston, Ont., Canada; Birk, A.M., Queen's University, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Kingston, Ont., Canada
Abstract: If a pressure vessel containing a pressure liquefied gas (PLG) is exposed to a severe fire, there is a chance the tank will rupture and possibility even explode. It has been shown that the energy stored in the liquid phase is important in the outcome of such an accident. In order to better understand tank failure and energy storage, it is desired to understand the complex thermo-hydraulic response of the lading prior to a thermally induced rupture. In the summers of 2000 and 2001, a series of controlled fire tests were conducted on horizontal 1890 litre (500 US gallon) propane tanks. The test tanks were instrumented with pressure transducers, lading and wall thermocouples, and an instrumented flow nozzle in place of a pressure relief valve (PRV). A computer controlled PRV was used to control pressure, while high momentum, liquid propane utility torches were used to heat the tank. PRV blowdown and fire conditions were varied in this test series while all other input parameters were held constant. It was found that the lading response and energy storage varied according to the fire conditions and PRV operation. The location and quantity of the burners affected the thermal stratification within the liquid, and the swelling and frothing at the liquid/vapour interface. The blowdown of the PRV affected average tank pressure, average liquid temperature and time to destratify. PRV operation caused enhanced convective cooling on the vapour space wail. The degree of blowdown dictated the pressure drop, and thus the liquid flashing and subsequent swelling were affected. This paper will discuss these thermohydraulic responses and their role in the tank failure.
Index Keywords: Thermohydraulics; Computer control systems; Energy storage; Failure (mechanical); Flammability testing; Fuel tanks; Hydraulics; Liquefied gases; Pressure relief valves; Pressure transducers; Pressure vessels; Propane; Swelling; Thermocouples; Fluid structure interaction

Authors: Suzuki A.
Title: Japan's program for back-end of nuclear fuel cycle flexibility is the key
Affiliations: Department of Quantum Engineering and Systems Science, University of Tokyo, Japan

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Tech notes: Engineering services and expertise
Abstract: EN Engineering provides engineering services to Nicor, Kinder Morgan, Dominion, Peoples Energy, NiSource, BP, Lakehead Pipeline, ExxonMobil, Wisconsin Gas, Vector Pipeline, and other liquid and gas pipeline and distribution companies. Major projects to date include design, procurement, and construction coordination, for the Horizon Pipeline, compressor station engineering and operational review for a major interstate pipeline company, designing all public improvements, system improvements and main replacements for Nicor Gas as well as maintaining the corrosion control program for Nicor Gas' distribution, transmission, storage, and underground storage tank systems. The Horizon Pipeline project in Chicago is a joint venture of Natural Gas Pipeline Co of America (NPGL) and Nicor Inc. The pipeline connects two NGPL pipelines that move natural gas to the suburbs in the Chicago area to meet the growing customer demand of Nicor Gas serving the area. The project entailed installing 28 mi of new 36-in. OD high-pressure pipe, a 9700 HP compressor station, six gas measurement stations and related facilities. The route of the line traverses through DuPage, Kane, Cook, and McHenry counties in Illinois. ENE successfully completed their work on the Horizon Pipeline in the spring of 2002 and it is now fully operational.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Energy storage systems make DG more reliable, efficient, secure
Abstract: Various aspects of energy storage systems, which make distributed generation (DG) more reliable, efficient, and secure, are discussed. Large-scale storage facilities allow arbitrage of electricity into commodity markets and also providing low-cost ancillary services. Storage facilities afford utilities the opportunity to temporarily defer transmission-system upgrades to accommodate load growth by providing a pre-positioned energy source downstream of congestion points. Energy storage also play an important role in reducing the operating cost and improving the reliability of distribution and small transmission system in remote locations.
Index Keywords: Costs; Economic and social effects; Electric power systems; Marketing; Problem solving; Project management; Reliability; Societies and institutions; Congestion points; Distributed generation (DG); Energy storage systems; Uninterruptible power supply (UPS); Energy storage

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Small reactors return
Abstract: At present, there is a revival of interest in small and simpler nuclear units for generating electricity and process heat, driven by a desire to reduce capital costs and to provide off-grid power. An overview is given on the current state of development of modern small reactors.
Index Keywords: Costs; Nuclear energy; Reactor refueling; Spent fuels; Steam generators; High temperature gas-cooled reactors; Modular simplified boiling water reactor; Small reactors; Spent fuel storage; System-integrated modular advanced reactor; Nuclear reactors

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News digest: North Sea: Old oil fields put to use
Abstract: A project carried out by scientists at the British Geological Survey to examine a new method to look at the geological aspects of sequestering fluid CO2, which has been taking place under the North Sea, revealed that exhausted oil and gas fields could be safely used as underground storage facilities for industrial CO2 waste as an interim measure to combat global warming. Statoil has been injecting CO2 into porous sandstone 1 km beneath the seabed. Common practice is to release it into the atmosphere. The gas accumulates in an aquifer, which has a 600 bcf capacity. If just 1% of the capacity is utilized, the EU's CO2 output from energy production over 3 yr could be stored. This safe and technically feasible idea could play a role in reducing atmospheric emissions until alternatives to burning fossil fuels are found as part of the strategy towards meeting Kyoto Protocol targets.

Authors: Ou D.R., Zhu J., Zhao J.H.
Title: An innovative approach for antimony-type super-resolution near-field structure
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Ou, D.R., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Zhu, J., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Zhao, J.H., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: Mechanism of Sb-SR (Sb-type super-resolution near-field structure) was studied. Experimental results show that the super-resolution performance of amorphous Sb-SR is considerably better than crystal Sb-SR. Considering that Sb is a semiconductor with small energy gap, a three-order nonlinear response of surface plasmons is deduced to explain the performance of amorphous Sb-SR. Estimation is made and the calculated results are in agreement with the experimental results. Under the new approach, other semiconductors with small energy gap may possibly possess super-resolution performance. © 2002 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Doping CeO2 and Tb4O7 in KNSBN, the Ce:KNSBN crystal was grown. It is the first time that the crystal was grown by Czochalski. The phase conjugate reflectivity was measured to be the higher than 140% on transient state and to be higher than 90% on stable state. The out electric field can enhance the phase conjugate reflectivity on transient state. When Eo=4kv/cm2, the transient phase conjugate reflectivity R=168% and the stable transient phase conjugate reflectivity R=120%. Ce:Tb:KNSBN crystals pumping on self phase conjugate reflectivity goes up to 62%. Cu:KMSBN was used as recorder and Ce:Tb:KNSBN was used as self-pumped conjugate to realize holographic associative memory. © 2002 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Sipeng G., Lisong H.
Title: Crystallization behavior of oxygen-doped Ge-Sb-Te phase-change films
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Shanghai Institute of Optics and Fine Mechanics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, 201800, China
Authors with affiliations: Sipeng, G., Shanghai Institute of Optics and Fine Mechanics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, 201800, China; Lisong, H., Shanghai Institute of Optics and Fine Mechanics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai, 201800, China
Abstract: The use of Ge-Sb-Te films for rewritable optical storage is based on the reversible phase change between their amorphous and crystalline states. Study of the crystallization behavior of the films is very necessary to the optimization of film composition and dopants. This work dedicates our experimental investigation on the crystallization behavior of oxygen-doped Ge-Sb-Te phase change films, which were prepared by RF-sputtering. The crystallization behavior of the thin films was investigated using differential scanning calorimeter (DSC). XRD spectra of the films in the as-deposited and heat-treated states show that the films changed from amorphous to crystalline states due to heat-treatment. By measuring the peak temperature of crystallization at different heating rates we calculated the crystallization activation energies and frequency factors. It was found that the oxygen-doped Ge-Sb-Te sample has a higher value of crystallization activation energy than that without oxygen-doping, it is clear that oxygen-doping can improve the crystallization rate of Ge-Sb-Te phase-change material. © 2002 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Stell J.
Title: FERC actions change face of US energy pipelines
Authors with affiliations: Stell, J.
Abstract: In 1992, FERC issued Order 636 requiring pipeline firms to "provide open-access transportation and storage, and to separate sales from transportation services completely." The ruling sought to advance new downstream marketing venues and to produce favorable conditions for acquisitions, mergers, and joint ventures among pipeline firms. Subsequent FERC Orders 888 and 889 in 1997 promoted competition and established standards of conduct. These orders advanced changes in the industry, served to unbundle services, and motivated development of independent gas marketing firms. A discussion covers the effects of these orders on companies, e.g., venturing into large geographical combinations, diversification into non-core industries, etc.; growth of natural gas consumption between 1992 and 1997; and natural gas pipeline and marketing corporations created as a result of FERC filings in the 1990s; and major pipeline ownership changes.

Authors: Service R.F.
Title: American Chemical Society: Chemists search for solutions
Authors with affiliations: Service, R.F.
Abstract: From 18 to 22 August, nearly 15,000 chemists gathered here to discuss work on problems ranging from health to energy sources. Among the highlights: tailored immunosuppressants, a new understanding of the molecular miscues that trigger diabetes, and a novel way of storing hydrogen gas for fuel-cell vehicles.

Authors: Nomura S., Watanabe N., Ajikawa H., Tsutsui H., Tsuji-Iio S., Shimada R., Sato Y.
Title: Development of Helically Winding Machine for Force-Balanced Coil and Winding Technique
Affiliations: Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Toshiba Corporation, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nomura, S., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Watanabe, N., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Ajikawa, H., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Tsutsui, H., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Tsuji-Iio, S., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Shimada, R., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Sato, Y., Toshiba Corporation, Japan
Abstract: Strong electromagnetic force caused by high magnetic fields and coil current is a serious problem in Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) systems and magnetically confined fusion devices. In facing this problem, we proposed the concept of Force-Balanced Coil (FBC) applied to SMES and fusion devices. The FBC Is a helically wound toroidal coil which balances the centering force with the hoop force. The helical winding of the FBC is modulated in order to reduce the torsional force. However, the winding of the FBC is a three-dimensional complex shape so that it may be difficult to manufacture the modulated helical windings. To overcome this difficulty, we developed a helically winding machine. In this paper, we discuss the winding techniques by using the winding machine and improve the shape of the helical windings from the view point of the reduction of the time consumed in winding the coil. © 2002, The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Technical Information Center: Energy technologies
Abstract: ChevronTexaco uses gasification technology, which converts low-value materials, like refinery residue, into clean synthesis gas. The company develops and commercializes advanced energy technologies, including fuel cells, photovoltaics, advanced batteries, and hydrogen storage.

Authors: Keeping S.
Title: Eking out the power budget
Authors with affiliations: Keeping, S.
Abstract: The issue of maximizing power efficiency of microprocessor chips designed for wireless connectivity was discussed. Power management was also an important concern in the design of flash memories, programmable logic devices, voltage converters, power transistors and power supplies for battery powered devices. The use of high efficiency direct current (dc) converters in low power applications and fuel cells for portable computers was recommended. Reduced power consumption eliminated the need for cooling fans, heat sinks, enabled miniaturization and provided a good user experience.

Authors: Toporov A.Yu.
Title: Magnetization distribution in submicrometer iron-nickel antidot arrays patterned by a focused ion beam
Affiliations: Natural-Science Research Center, General Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 117991, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Toporov, A.Yu., Natural-Science Research Center, General Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow 117991, Russian Federation
Abstract: Antidots of size 0.5 μm are prepared by patterning iron-nickel films with a focused ion beam. The magnetization distribution in antidot arrays is examined with Lorentz transmission electron microscopy. It is shown that one side of the array makes an angle of about 20° with the easy magnetic axis of the film. Magnetization reversal in the direction close to the easy magnetic axis starts with domain nucleation at the antidot edges that are perpendicular to the applied field and adjacent to the unpatterned region of the film, and propagates as the domain walls move. Magnetization reversal in the direction close to the hard magnetic axis starts with magnetization rotation outside the patterned region at the antidot edges and propagates as the domain walls execute a complicated motion. It is demonstrated that some areas between the edges of adjacent antidots can carry information bits. Results obtained are explained in terms of competition between the demagnetizing energy, energy of internal anisotropy, and misorientation effect. The feasibility of such structures as high-density storage elements is discussed. © 2002 MAIK "Nauka/Interperiodica".

Authors: Boeyink G.
Title: The Bulkflow Heat Exchanger for cooling sugar crystals
Affiliations: Bulkflow Technologies Inc, Venemansweg 5, 7102 ET, Winterswijk, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Boeyink, G., Bulkflow Technologies Inc, Venemansweg 5, 7102 ET, Winterswijk, Netherlands
Abstract: The Bulkflow Heat Exchanger technology was introduced, over ten years ago, as an alternative method for cooling fertilizer granules and prills before storage. A heat exchanger for free flowing bulk solids was a new concept combining the engineering sciences of heat transfer and mass flow of bulk solids. With more than 40 coolers used in fertilizer plants and 110 coolers in various other applications such as plastics, detergents, various minerals and chemicals this paper describes the Bulkflow Heat Exchanger technology and its particualr advantages, namely, very low energy consumption, low air emissions and compact design, to cool sugar crystals.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick takes: SG Resources Louisiana LLC...
Abstract: SG Resources Louisiana LLC is moving forward with the development of a new salt cavern natural gas storage facility in Evangeline Parish, LA. To be called the Louisiana Energy Center, the facility will have the capacity to hold a total of 16 bcf of gas in two caverns and will function as a transportation and storage hub for nine major natural gas pipelines. The 60 acre site and acquired mineral rights would allow for two additional caverns to be constructed to support future growth in demand. The company plans to hold an open season for storage capacity beginning in the third quarter of 2002. The project is slated to start operation in the fourth quarter of 2004.

Title: Energy minimization under area and performance constraints for multimedia applications realized on embedded cores
Affiliations: VLSI Design Laboratory, Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, University of Patras, Rio 26500, Greece

Abstract: A systematic methodology for energy dissipation reduction of multimedia applications realized on architectures based on embedded cores and application specific data memory organization is proposed. Performance and area are explicitly taken into account. The proposed methodology includes two major steps: A high-level code transformation step that reorganizes the original description of the target application. The second major step includes the determination of the processor, memory and bus organization of the system and is briefly described. Experimental results from several real-life demonstrators prove the impact of the high level step of the proposed methodology.

Authors: Cai X.-Z., Gu J.-H., Guo W., Shen W.-Q.
Title: Compton back-scattering γ-ray source based on synchrotron radiation facility (I) numerical calculation of the produced MeV γ-ray
Source title: Kao Neng Wu Li Yu Ho Wu Li/High Energy Physics and Nuclear Physics
Affiliations: Shanghai Inst. of Nuclear Research, CAS, Shanghai 201800, China
Authors with affiliations: Cai, X.-Z., Shanghai Inst. of Nuclear Research, CAS, Shanghai 201800, China; Gu, J.-H., Shanghai Inst. of Nuclear Research, CAS, Shanghai 201800, China; Guo, W., Shanghai Inst. of Nuclear Research, CAS, Shanghai 201800, China; Shen, W.-Q., Shanghai Inst. of Nuclear Research, CAS, Shanghai 201800, China
Abstract: We propose a build to low-energy γ-ray beam line (SLEGS-I) at the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). By Compton back-scattering (BCS) of infrared or far-infrared laser lights from 3.5 GeV electrons circulating in the storage ring of SSRF, high intense quasi- monochromatic BCS γ-rays with high linear or circular polarization ranging 1-25MeV will be produced. It can be widely applied to fundamental researching fields of nuclear physics, nuclear astrophysics and related applications. In this paper, we briefly present the outline of BCS theory and the properties of BCS γ-ray with numerical compution based on the major parameters of SSRF storage ring.

Authors: Wood J.
Title: Pumped up power plans for Morocco
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Authors with affiliations: Wood, J.
Abstract: MOROCCO'S Afourir project has been developed to satisfy a portion of the peak electric energy demand on the Moroccan grid by using stored low-cost energy generated from a hydroelectric power plant. This will be accomplished through the use of a pumped-storage system, and, according to the Arab Fund, which is helping to fund the project, it will preclude the need for installing several gas turbines, with a total power rating of 450MW, to satisfy peak demand. The project will be located in the Azilal region, around 220km south of the capital city of Rabat. It includes the construction of upper and lower water reservoirs, connecting ducts and pipes, and two dual pumping and generating stations.

Title: Quick takes: El Paso energy partners LP...
Abstract: El Paso Energy Partners LP finished the expansion of its Petal natural gas salt dome storage facility and 60-mi takeaway pipeline near Hattiesburg, MS. These projects were completed in conjunction with a 20-yr contract with Southern Co of Atlanta, GA. The expanded Petal storage facility has working gas capacity of 8.65 bcf of natural gas. El Paso estimates that revenues generated by its new services to Southern will add $7 million in cash flow during the remainder of 2002 and $16 million annually thereafter.
Index Keywords: EL PASO ENERGY PARTNERS LP

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quick takes: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP...
Abstract: According to Kinder Morgan Interstate Gas Transmission LLC unit, the added 6 bcf of natural gas storage capacity to be created by its Cheyenne Market Center (CMC) service was fully subscribed under 10-yr contracts during a 2-wk open season. Bids totaled > 26 bcf. The additional infrastructure will have injection capability of 38.4 million cu ft/day and withdrawal deliverability of about 62.4 million cu ft/day. CMC will be in service during the summer of 2004.

Authors: Staedter T.
Title: Magnetic random-access memory
Authors with affiliations: Staedter, T.
Abstract: The recently developed magnetic random access memory (MRAM) has the potential to store as much data as dynamic random access memory (DRAM), write it faster and access it instantly, consuming less energy. MRAM stores data in the spin of electrons inside tiny magnetic sandwiches. The sandwiches don't lose their magnetism or memory, even if the power goes out. MRAM is made of thin insulating layer sandwiched between two magnets and the magnets can have fields depending on the way their electrons spin. An electrical sensor at the end of the top electrode reads the resistance and determines the binary state of the cell that was read.
Index Keywords: Binary state; Electron spin; Insulating layers; Magnetic random access memory (MRAM); Electric currents; Electric resistance; Electrodes; Energy utilization; Magnetic field effects; Magnetic storage; Magnetism; Storage allocation (computer); Dynamic random access storage; Goes

Authors: Topping D.
Title: Waste Not, Want Not
Authors with affiliations: Topping, D.
Abstract: The energy policy on the relative priority that should be given to developing new suppliers versus improving energy efficiency is discussed. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, the 104 million households in the U.S. annually consumes 125 billion kWh of electric energy. It is suggested that the use of waste heat productively could significantly reduce the energy needs at a resonable cost and with existing technology.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Energy conservation; Energy efficiency; Energy policy; Energy utilization; Heat transfer; Waste heat; Buffer storage tanks; Cost savings; Domestic appliances

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: CO2 capture gets another EU boost
Abstract: The EU's research directorate (DGRes) will pay the CO2 Capture Project (CCP) $1.8 million to study new technologies for reducing CO2 emissions. The project known as Grangemouth Advanced Capture started in 2002 and will run for 2 yr. The program will cost $2.8 million and involve research performed by several leading European universities and scientific institutions. CPP will address the development of chemical looping combustion technology and research novel materials for hydrogen membrane reactors. It has previously received $410,000 from the EU's transport directorate to study the reduction of CO2 emissions utilizing underground storage. The CPP is a research joint venture of BP, Eni, ChevronTexaco, Norsk Hydro, Shell, PanCanadian, Statoil, and Suncor Energy, which aims to research and develop technologies to reducing the cost of CO2 separation capture and underground storage.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Restoration at Harwell
Abstract: The site remediation project of the Southern Storage Area (SSA) was one of United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority's (UKAEA's) largest decommissioning tasks at Harwell, and was one of the most challenging land remediation programs in the UK. To determine the best practicable environmental option for restoration of the SSA, UKAEA worked with the environmental consultants Dames & Moore International and the National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB). The options were carefully considered using a public environmental impact assessment process.
Index Keywords: Environmental protection; Land reclamation; Radioactive wastes; Remediation; Restoration; Site remediation; Southern storage area; Decommissioning (nuclear reactors)

Authors: Leo A.
Title: Nanotechnology
Authors with affiliations: Leo, A.
Abstract: The developments and the investments made in the field of nanoelectronics are discussed. Molecular Electronics was one of the first nanotech company to seek to commercialize scientific breakthroughs in nanoelectronics. While Molecular Electronics plans to build computer memory using individual molecules to store bits of information, other companies are planing to build ultrasensitive biological sensors, or flat-panel displays, or nanoscopic lasers. Nanoelectronics will likely to effect various sectors of the economy, biotechnology and health care to energy. Researchers from Hewlett-Packard Laboratories are planning to build computers that doesn't just fit in the wristwatch, but also fit in the fibers of the shirt.

Title: Semiconductor UV sources and detectors: Some non-consumer applications
Source title: International Journal of High Speed Electronics and Systems

Authors with affiliations: Muñoz, E., ISOM-IEL, ETSI Telecomunicación, Ciudad Universitaria, 28040-Madrid, Spain
Abstract: UV emitters and photodetectors based on wide band-gap semiconductors are being investigated and may soon become commercially available. Solid state lighting and information storage are two main applications in the consumer area for these new semiconductor devices. Presently, III-nitrides seem to be the most promising materials for such near UV semiconductor devices. In this work some non-consumer applications are indicated. Biophotonics appears to be a very promising area for such devices.

Abstract: A discussion covers highlights of the 2002 Offshore Technology Conference, which was held 5/6-9/2002 in Houston, TX; emerging era of the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, with emphasis on the deepwater gulf's future potential and importance to US energy supply and the introduction of a system of floating production, storage, and offloading (FPSO) vessels in tandem with shuttle tankers to deliver that future deepwater supply to market; growth of deepwater projects; EL Paso's shipboard LNG regasification system; technology of deepwater oil and gas exploration and production; and issues concerning the use of FPSO in the gulf, e.g., offshore loading and concerns surrounding the actual FPSO development concept.

Authors: Manore M.M.
Title: Carbohydrate: Friend or Foe? Part II. Dietary Carbohydrate and Changes in Blood Glucose
Authors with affiliations: Manore, M.M.
Abstract: Carbohydrate is necessary to fuel the muscles and brain and provide energy during exercise. Dietary carbohydrate is a great source of vitamins, minerals and fiber and is the only substrate that can replace muscle and liver glycogen after exercise. Thus, active individuals need to have adequate levels of carbohydrate in their diet. Blood glucose and insulin rise when carbohydrate is eaten, but a healthy, trained individual can easily handle this carbohydrate load and will rapidly remove the carbohydrate for storage as glycogen. Overall, it is best to select carbohydrate foods that provide more than just calories (e.g. soda pop, candy, processed sweets). Begin by eating less processed foods and more whole fruits, grains, legumes, vegetables, and cereals that provide vitamins, minerals, phytonutrients, and fiber in addition to carbohydrate. These types of carbohydrates will provide less dramatic swings in blood glucose and insulin, especially if they are eaten in meals. The amount of carbohydrate recommended for different types of individuals will depend on the type and intensity of exercise performed and their dietary and weight goals - the topic of my next column.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: BP energy efficiency focus

It was also reported that, BP apart from expanding its solar business is also looking at potential energy sources including hydrogen, carbon capture and geological storage.

Title: Mechatronics for elevator installers and drive technicians part five
Authors with affiliations: Schwedt, H.; Benczek, G.
Abstract: The power requirement for the emergency rescue of the passengers trapped between floors in an elevator subsequent to a power failure was discussed. The minimum amount of electrical energy is required for the emergency illumination in the car, elevator controls, releasing and engaging the brakes, opening the doors, driving the car. The power could be supplied during a rescue operation through muscle power, emergency power supply to the system by way of a generator delivering three phase AC power, battery cabinet with recharable batteries, uninterruptable power source system using rechargable batteries for energy storage.

Authors: Hayes D.
Title: Philippine prospects
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Authors with affiliations: Hayes, D.
Abstract: The Philippine government plans to develop natural energy resources in the country will ensure that hydroelectric power remains an important energy source. The importance of hydropower varies in different parts of the country. The Philippines has a large untapped hydroelectric power development potential. Forty-nine projects are planned for completion in 2001-2011. These include the Kalayaan pumped storage scheme and the San Roque hydroelectric dam. Details are given of the projects at design or feasibility study stages. The National Power Corporation's use of build, operate and transfer (BOT) schemes in hydroelectric power development is described. The mini and micro hydro potential in the Philippines is outlined. The future organization and ownership of the Philippine hydropower sector is discussed.

Abstract: Collaboration via recent mergers enhances engineering and construction economics through shared resources, integrated data management, and increased purchasing power. A discussion covers several planned and under construction refinery projects, e.g., Petroleo Brasileiro SA's plan to revamp 8 of its 11 refineries in Brazil, ExxonMobil Corp's plan to take advantage of low-cost Mexican Maya crude at its Baytown, TX, refinery, and Valero Energy Corp's plan of a 45,000-bpd delayed coker in its Texas City refinery to facilitate processing of Maya crude; various engineering studies in the petrochemicals sector, which includes the completion of the Methanex project in 2005 that will produce ≤ 5 million ton/yr of methanol for export to Asia Pacific, and two NH3 plants; various GTL facilities in US that are under way, e.g., Rentech Inc's plan on a 2002 start-up for its 800 bpd facility in Commerce City, CO, and Conoco Inc's GTL pilot plant completion by February 2003; plans on various grassroots LNG facilities and regasification terminals, many of which are under construction; two new sulfur recovery units and additional sulfur storage in Saudi Arabia; and worldwide, planned multibillion dollar pipeline projects abound, including ExxonMobil Corp' Chad to Cameroon, China's West to East pipeline, and the Russia to China pipeline.

Authors: Oleinik S.G., Maksimov M.V., Maslov O.V.
Title: Determination of the burnup of spent nuclear fuel during reloading
Affiliations: All-Russia Sci.-Res. Inst. N.P.P., Russian Federation; Odessa Natl. Polytech. University, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Oleinik, S.G., All-Russia Sci.-Res. Inst. N.P.P., Russian Federation; Maksimov, M.V., Odessa Natl. Polytech. University, Ukraine; Maslov, O.V., Odessa Natl. Polytech. University, Ukraine
Abstract: A method is presented for determining the burnup of spent nuclear fuel during reloading. The method is based on an analysis of the results of γ spectrometric measurements performed at the Zaporozh'e nuclear power plant. This method differs from existing methods in that the initial enrichment of the nuclear fuel and the holding time of the nuclear fuel after irradiation are determined.

Natural gas was projected as a clean-burning fuel, making it a good energy source for reliable and affordable alternative fuel vehicles. It was expected that using an inherently clean fuel and the right vehicle and engine technology, it was possible to create a useful and commercially viable vehicle, that reduced the dependence on foreign petroleum and met upcoming emissions regulations.

Authors: McConnell V.P.
Title: Hybrid vehicle integrates carbon fibre composite structure
Authors with affiliations: McConnell, V.P.
Abstract: The rise of alternate fuel vehicles (AFVs), such as hybrid electric vehicles, are predicted to replace the traditional internal combustion engine powered vehicles. Honda and Toyota activities in this field are noted, and also Hypercar Inc's Revolution HEV (hybrid electric vehicle) which is more closely examined here. Safety considerations are reviewed with the Revolution's safety features listed. The design and structure of the passenger safety cell incorporating composites is described, with details of the aluminium sub-frame. Chassis components also use composites. Carbon fibre-epoxy storage tanks for the fuel cell's onboard gaseous hydrogen and carbon-carbon brakes are also included in the design. Manufacturing methods were carefully considered from the outset with the principal concepts outlined. The Revolution's environmental advantages are noted. The Hypercar concept is for a lightweight, fuel-efficient, aerodynamically enhanced higher-performance passenger vehicle using a high proportion of composites.
Index Keywords: Codes (standards); Composite structures; Internal combustion engines; Hybrid vehicles; Carbon fibers; aluminum; carbon fiber; epoxide; hydrogen; automobile industry; composite material; electric car; motor vehicle; traffic safety; aerodynamics; automotive textile; carbon fiber; energy conservation; fiber reinforced composite; safety

Authors: Owen D.
Title: Spin doctors
Authors with affiliations: Owen, D.
Abstract: The growing use of flywheel-based power systems is discussed. Flywheel battries help in solving the problem of smoothing out the effects of interruptions and fluctuations in essential power supplies for applications ranging from computer systems to complex industrial processes. These batteries are used to provide energy storage and attitude control in low earth-orbit space satellites. These systems are found to save 30 and 50% fuel consumption and resulting emissions from hybrid power. Flywheel systems can also be designed to interface with primary energy devices.

Authors: Agrawal S., Kumar N.
Title: Biomolecular computers - Next generation computers
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers (India): Chemical Engineering Division
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur 208016, India
Authors with affiliations: Agrawal, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur 208016, India; Kumar, N., Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur 208016, India
Abstract: Molecular computing is an emerging field which involves the encoding, manipulation and retrieval of information at a macro-molecular level in contrast to the current techniques which use IC miniaturization. Advantages of molecular computing include economic fabrication and design, more data storage capacity (up to 1011 - 1013 bits/cm3 in contrast to 108 bits/cm2 capacity of 2-D memory chip), a higher degree of integration, considerable lower switching energies, enhanced stability of circuits in the presence of radiation, inherent precision, high speed signal processing, etc. Three approaches of molecular computing are discussed in this article which include (i) Enzyme-based Logic Gates (ENLOGS), (ii) Surface DNA Computing, and (iii) Protein-based Optical Computing. The enzyme-based logic gates (ENLOGS) use enzymatic activity to perform recognition operations via lock and key paradigm. The Surface DNA Computing involves the immobilization and manipulation of combinatorial mixtures of DNA on a support to solve complex non-deterministic problems via a series of mark, destroy and unmark operations. The Protein-based Optical Computing provides high speed random access memories, based on bacteriorhodopsin (obtained from balobacterium halobium). This produces conformational changes when struck with different coloured laser beams thus acting as a basis for a molecular switch. Furthermore, it exhibits dectroehromism which is used to develop electronic ink for computer displays. Work is in progress at the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur on a model of an ENLOG. This model described in the article uses phenomena of release of NO from nitro-porphyrin through light and a pH gradient.
Author Keywords: Biomolecular computers; Enzyme-based logic gates; Protein-based optical computing; Surface DNA computing
Index Keywords: Computational complexity; Computers; DNA; Electrochromism; Enzyme immobilization; Logic gates; Optical data processing; Problem solving; Random access storage; Signal processing; Biomolecular computers; Molecular computing; Information retrieval systems

Authors: Asam H., Heiberger T.
Title: Optimising operations in Swaziland
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Affiliations: RMD Consult GmbH, Münchner Straße 12, Unterfoehring 85774, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Asam, H., RMD Consult GmbH, Münchner Straße 12, Unterfoehring 85774, Germany; Heiberger, T., RMD Consult GmbH, Münchner Straße 12, Unterfoehring 85774, Germany
Abstract: The Kingdom of Swaziland is one of the smallest countries in Africa and produces about 30% of its energy demand from its hydroelectric power plants and purchasing the remainder. An optimisation study of the country's hydro cascade has been conducted to improvesystem efficiency and prepare for new conditions in the developing open energy market in southern Africa. The hydroelectric power cascade consists two storage reservoirs, two buffer ponds and three hydro stations with a total capacity of 41MW. A major goal has been the development of an operating system that manages reservoir outflows and water levels throughout the year while optimising energy production and reducing energy purchase costs. Models have been developed for both annual water management and daily operation forecasting.
Index Keywords: Costs; Energy efficiency; Reservoirs (water); Water levels; Water management; Hydroelectric power plants; hydroelectric power plant; modeling; optimization; reservoir

Authors: Amber D.P., Jones W.D.
Title: Yucca mountain nuclear waste repository takes next step - [News]
Authors with affiliations: Amber, D.P.; Jones, W.D.
Abstract: Washington - U.S. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham announced on 10 January that he will recommend to President Bush that the United States build a permanent nuclear waste storage facility at Yucca Mountain in southern Nevada. The announcement is the latest salvo in a decades-long battle to find a permanent home for the 40 000 tons of nuclear waste now stored on-site at nuclear facilities in 36 states. The consolidation of that waste into a single location has perhaps become the most drawn-out and impassioned of all not in my backyard debates. © 1964-2012 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Geological repositories; Radioactive wastes; Not in my backyards; Nuclear facilities; Nuclear waste repositories; Nuclear waste-storage facilities; Single location; Washington; Yucca Mountain; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: In brief: ChevronTexaco, ECD to commercialize hydrogen technologies
Abstract: Chevron Energy Solutions, a subsidiary of Chevron Texaco, is collaborating with Energy Conversion Devices Inc (ECD) to broaden the commercial application of hydrogen storage systems and fuel cell technologies, as well as flexible solar electric roofing materials and high-performance NiMH batteries. Chevron Texaco holds a 20% equity interest in ECD as a result of investments by Texaco in 2000 and 2001, and maintains three 50:50 joint ventures with ECD. Two of the joint ventures (Chevron Texaco Ovonic Hydrogen Systems and Chevron Texaco Ovonic Fuel Cell Company LLC) are developing, respectively, advanced hydrogen systems to reversibly store hydrogen in stable solid metal hydrides, and regenerative fuel cells using non-noble metal catalysts.

Authors: Chang C.H., Wang Ch., Hwang C.S., Fan T.C., Luo G.H.
Title: Circular polarization with rotatable magnetic fields in crossed staggered undulator
Source title: Journal of Magnetism and Magnetic Materials
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, No. 1, RandD Road VI, Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, C.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, No. 1, RandD Road VI, Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan; Wang, Ch., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, No. 1, RandD Road VI, Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan; Hwang, C.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, No. 1, RandD Road VI, Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan; Fan, T.C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, No. 1, RandD Road VI, Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan; Luo, G.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, No. 1, RandD Road VI, Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan
Abstract: This work presents a novel crossed staggered undulator (CSU) capable of producing circular polarization photon with higher photon energies and higher brightness. The CSU includes two 1-m long staggered undulators with 20-mm periodic length, to achieve high vertical field strength of 0.9T and longitudinal field strength of 0.7T at a 5.5-mm gap width. During beam injection, the staggered magnetic arrays in vacuum can be rotated within ±45° to accommodate the horizontal aperture limitation. The identical crossed magnetic fields can also be orientated to create the ideally circular or linear polarized light in any direction. The optimal merit flux is pointed at higher harmonics that allow circular polarized light to be used over the 1.4-4KeV range in the SRRC 1.5GeV storage ring. This paper also proposes an outline for the design of an entire system. © 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Circular polarization; Crossed undulator; Staggered undulator
Index Keywords: Harmonic analysis; Light polarization; Magnetic flux; Photons; Vacuum applications; Crossed staggered undulators (CSU); Magnetic field effects

The company has completed engineering work and has acquired land and pipeline rights-of-way for the Southern Pines Energy Center. The high-deliverability storage facility will have two caverns, each with 8 bcf of capacity. The project could serve nine major pipelines. Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Contracts: Kvaerner: Into the Panyu
Abstract: Kvaerner's Asia Pacific operations was awarded a total of $12 million contracts for the Panyu Field in the South China Sea. The main contract was awarded by China Offshore Oil Nanhai West Corp for a newly built floating production storage and offloading (FPSO) facility operating at the Panyu field, owned by Devon Energy China. The FPSO will feature production facilities capable of processing 70,000 bbl of oil and 220,000 bbl of total liquid, and 600,000 bbl of heated storage capacity. Other facilities will include a power plant to drive submersible pumps, crude transfer, and offloading systems, and utility and safety system. Kvaerner's scope in the project includes engineering design, detailed engineering support, project management support, and supply of process equipment. The company was also awarded a contract by Devon Energy for the detailed design of the Panyu 4-2 and Panyu 5-1 platforms, which will provide production for the nearby FPSO.
