Title: Contracts: Brotherhood secures supply contracts
Abstract: Peter Brotherhood secured two contracts. The first, worth > $1.5 million, is to supply a power generator for a new waste-to-energy plant being constructed by Earth Tech to convert municipal waste into electric power. Brotherhood is supplying an alternator set driven by a condensing steam turbine which will produce 3.45 Mw of power for an adjacent chemical firm by processing 56,000 ton/yr of municipal waste. The second contract is for equipment destined for the Woollybutt oil field off the North West Shelf of Australia. The firm will supply Four Vanguard with a complete steam turbo alternator set for installation on a floating production, storage, and offloading facility. The alternator set is capable of delivering 4.5 Mw of power from steam raised by a central boiler plant.
Index Keywords: WOOLLYBUTT OIL FIELD, AUSTRALIA

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Duke Energy also plans to develop...
Abstract: Duke Energy plans to develop a natural gas storage facility in an underground dome in Copiah County, MS. The facility, which should become operational in 2004, will have an initial storage capacity of 3.3 bcf, a withdrawal capacity of about 300,000 dekatherms/day and about 150,000 dekatherms/day of injection capability. Its storage capacity can ultimately be expanded by an additional 6 bcf.
Index Keywords: DUKE ENERGY

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Sumitomo, Proton Energy for joint development
Abstract: Proton Energy Systems signed a joint development and marketing agreement with Sumitomo Corp to develop, sell, and service PEM-based regenerative fuel cell and hydrogen generation systems, including Proton's Hogen®,Unigen®, and FuelGen™ products, in Japan. The markets include back-up power, hydrogen generation, load leveling/peak shaving, and renewable energy storage. Proton plans to design, assemble, and carry out initial testing on development units to be shipped to Sumitomo. It will deliver the units and provide support and training essential for system installation and maintenance.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: SG Resources Mississippi plans...
Abstract: SG Resources Mississippi plans to build the Southern Pines Energy Center, a gas storage facility in Greene County, MS. The salt cavern will provide 12 bcf of storage in two caverns and will be capable of supporting withdrawal rates of ≤ 1.2 bcf/day and injection rates of ≤ 0.6 bcf/day. It is scheduled to be operational by early 2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Environment: BP beats emissions target
Abstract: BP has achieved its goal, 8 yr ago, of reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by over 9 million ton. In addition, it plans to peg net future emissions at the new, lower level, despite increasing oil and gas production by 5.5%/yr to 2005. According to BP's chief executive, John Browne, the company's target is now to "contain net emissions at current levels through the next decade". If no further action was made, the emissions from BP's operations will increase by something like 50 million ton (from 80 million ton in 2002 to 130 million ton by 2012). BP will also continue to expand its solar business, which is set to grow by 40% in 2002. BP is also looking at developing other potential energy sources, including hydrogen, and at carbon capture and geological storage.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Projects: Salt dome gas storage facility wins preliminary approval
Abstract: A Duke Energy business unit has received approval from the FERC to develop a natural gas storage facility in an underground salt dome in Copiah County, MS. Assuming Duke Energy Gas Transmission (DEGT) accepts the FERC-issued Certificate of Public Convenience and Necessity, work will begin immediately. The company's development plans calls for an initial natural gas storage capacity of 3.3 bcf, about 300 million cu ft/day of withdrawal capacity and ≈ 150 million cu ft/day of injection capacity. Storage capacity at the facility can ultimately be expanded by an additional 5 to 9.9 bcf. To meet anticipated customer demand during that heating season, it is expected the project will be in service and operational in 2004. The Copiah facility complements the company's existing facilities at Egan, LA, and Moss Bluff, TX, and is strategically located to facilitate interconnection with several interstate and intrastate pipelines. Market Hub Partners' Copiah County Storage Co plans to leach a cavern in the naturally occurring salt formation to accommodate the storage of natural gas. Aboveground compression and leaching facilities related to cavern development will also be installed.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Newsreel: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners expanding
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP (KMP), which operates Plantation Pipe Line Co, will increase capacity on a 190-mi segment of the Plantation common carrier pipeline that transports refined petroleum products throughout the southeastern US. The proposed $116 million project, which is needed to meet the area's growing need for gasoline, diesel, and jet fuel, will entail replacing an existing 8-in. pipeline between Bremen, GA, and Knoxville, TN, with a new 20-in. pipeline. The project is being supported by long-term contracts with major oil companies. The proposed replacement pipeline, which will double capacity on the segment of the pipe between Bremen and Knoxville to ∼ 90,000 bpd, will generally follow the alignment of existing utility corridors and rights-of-way. Construction is expected to take place in 2004, with completion targeted for the fourth quarter of that year. KMP has announced over $300 million in additional expansion projects now under way in its four business segments, including construction to increase capacity of the CALNEV pipeline and to build additional tanks and infrastructure to meet growing customer demand for gasoline and jet fuel in Las Vegas. This expansion will increase transportation capacity on the pipeline by 16% to 128,000 bpd. KMP is also constructing a new 86-mi natural gas pipeline in Texas with a 325,000 million Btu/day capacity that will serve two large electric generating plants near Dallas. Development of 6 bcf of additional storage capacity at the company's new Cheyenne Market Center in Weld County, CO, will provide more services for growing natural gas supplies in Wyoming.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Newsreel: FERC Oks salt dome for gas storage
Abstract: A Duke Energy business unit has received approval from the FERC to develop a natural gas storage facility in an underground salt dome in Copiah County, MS. Duke anticipates an initial storage capacity of 3.3 bcf, about 300,000 dekatherms/day of withdrawal capability and ≈ 150,000 dekatherms/day of injection capability. Storage capacity at the facility can ultimately be expanded by an additional 6 bcf. The project is expected to be in service in 2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Black Hills Energy has...
Abstract: Black Hills Energy has acquired Equilon Pipeline's outstanding interests in Millennium Pipeline and Millennium Terminal, giving Black Hills 100% ownership of the companies. The Millennium Pipeline carries ≤ 65,000 bpd of crude from Beaumont to Longview, TX. Millennium Terminal has 1.1 million bbl of crude storage connected to the Millennium Pipeline in Beaumont.
Index Keywords: BLACK HILLS ENERGY

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Morgan Energy Partners plans to invest...
Abstract: Morgan Energy Partners plans to invest $50 million to increase storage capacity by 400,000 bbl at its Carteret Terminal at New York Harbor, add 300,000 bbl of storage capacity at its Pasadena, TX, terminal on the Houston ship channel, and upgrade its recently acquired Drayosburg Terminal in Pittsburgh, PA.
Index Keywords: MORGAN ENERGY PARTNERS

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: German Clean Energy Partnership to demo vehicles
Abstract: The Clean Energy Partnership Berlin (CEP), a major industry-government venture to develop a sustainable future transportation infrastructure, will study the practicality of using hydrogen, as well as alternatives, e.g., methanol and synthetic diesel, and mirrors the California Fuel Cell Partnership and work in Japan. CEP comprises Aral, BMW, DimlerChrysler, Ford Europe, Open, MAN Nutzfahrzeuge, Linde, GHW, and BVG. In Berlin, an Aral gas station will generate hydrogen from water by electrolysis, for storage and supply in both liquid and compressed gaseous form. The hydrogen will be available to refuel vehicles with either modified combustion engines or fuel cell technology. The automotive firms involved will operate a test fleet of about 30 vehicles from 2003.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Focus: LNG/Shell boosts US position
Abstract: In January 2002, Royal Dutch/Shell increased its presence in the US LNG market acquiring capacity rights at El Paso's Elba Island LNG gasification facility, near Savannah, GA. El Paso's subsidiary, Southern LNG, concluded an open season for bids from companies interested in expanding its Elba Island receiving plant. Shell was awarded the full additional capacity of 3.3 bcf of storage. The contract calls for output capacity of 360 million cu ft/day for a 30-yr term. The expansion should be completed by June 2005. The Elba Island LNG plant, which has been inactive since 1982, was authorized to receive LNG shipments again n December 2001. The planned expansion will increase the facility's storage capacity by about 80% to 7.3 bcf, and is send-out rate to around 800 million cu ft/day. The expansion would help meet growing demand for natural gas in the southeast US by providing the customers with access to diversified supplies from around the world. Shell's attempt to increase its presence in the US LNG market follows a similar strategy pursued by BG. In 2001, BG bought all available capacity at CMS Energy's 630 million cu ft/day import terminal at Lake Charles, LA. BG's contract began in January 2002 and runs for 22 yr.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Lurgi wins gas storage facility contract
Abstract: The Turkish Petroleum Co contracted Lurgi Oel Gas Chemie to build surface facilities for an underground gas storage project in Turkey. Lurgi is in charge of the complete detail engineering and the supply of turbines and compressors for the overall plant. The scope of the contract includes the surface facilities, e.g., all equipment and installations needed to inject and reclaim the gas. Lurgi will work in consortium with Fernas Insaat, which is responsible for the construction of the facilities. The storage system will be installed in two existing depleted natural gas fields in Kuzey Marmara and Degirmenkoy, west of Istanbul. Maximum storage capacity will be ∼ 1.6 billion cu m. The project will bring Turkey in line with the EU's expectations of its current and potential members that they provide storage capacities for oil and gas to reduce dependence on energy imports.
Index Keywords: DEGISMENKOY GASFIELD, TURKEY; KUZEY MARMARA GASFIELD, TURKEY; LURGI OEL GAS CHEMIE; TURKISH PETROLEUM CO

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Newsreel: Duke energy completes $8 billion acquisition of westcoast energy
Abstract: Duke Energy had closed on its acquisition of Westcoast Energy Inc. The transaction, valued at ∼ $8 billion based on cash, stock consideration and debt assumed, is expected to be accretive to Duke Energy's earnings. The transaction adds a network of mostly Canadian-based natural gas assets, featuring 6900 mi of transmission pipeline, 141 bcf of storage capacity, major processing plants, and > 1 million gas distribution customers to Duke Energy's growing portfolio. With the acquisition, Duke Energy's natural gas-related assets include about 18,900 mi of transmission pipeline; 241 bcf of natural gas storage; 58,700 mi of gathering pipeline; 84 processing facilities; and 16,500 mi of distribution pipe.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Newsreel: ANR Pipeline extends pacts with largest customer
Abstract: ANR Pipeline Co and We Energies have extended their relationship through 2010 by signing a number of natural gas service agreements, many of which were due to expire in 2003. Specifically, they renegotiated multiple firm transportation, storage, and related natural gas service contracts. In total, ANR will provide 866,500 dekatherms/day of service starting in 2003 under contracts of various terms extending to 2010. Key to the portfolio is ANR's ability to provide service both directly into We Energies' distribution system, and through the Guardian Pipeline via a new interconnection near Joliet, IL, a major pipeline hub. This arrangement will ship the gas through Guardian Pipeline to various interconnections with We Energies' system and will free up additional transportation capacity on ANR Pipeline to the benefit of Wisconsin energy users.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: United States/SGR Holdings is developing...
Abstract: SGR Holdings is developing the Louisiana Energy Center, a 16 million cu ft salt-cavern gas storage facility in Louisiana. The project is scheduled to begin operations in the fourth quarter of 2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: HARC, Sieco to collaborate
Abstract: The Houston Advanced Research Center in Texas and Sieco SA in Argentina have signed a cooperative agreement to work together to develop projects that promote new technologies related to fuel cells, power generation, and energy storage in South America. They are interested in determining how practical it is to produce power systems that use hydrogen for later use as fuel to generate electricity. If so, countries with large hydroelectric power infrastructure, such as Brazil and Argentina, could benefit enormously.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News in brief: United States/Duke Energy Gas Transmission...
Abstract: Duke Energy gas Transmission plans to develop a gas storage facility in an underground salt dome in Copiah County, MS. The facility will have an initial storage capacity of 3.3 bcf, which can be expanded by an additional 6-9 bcf, a withdrawal capacity of about 300 million cu ft/day, and an injection capacity of about 15 million cu ft/day. The facility is due to operate in February 2004.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: ASHRAE transactions
Abstract: The proceedings contains 116 papers from ASHRAE Transactions. The topics discussed include: a weather information-based intelligent ice storage control system; HVAC duct system design using dynamic programming method; flow of refrigerant 134a through orifice tubes; in-tube condensation of halogenated refrigerants; an experimental investigation of turbulent wall jets; and factors affecting the freezing of water flowing inside a circular tube.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Computer simulation; Diffusion; Dynamic programming; Energy conservation; Energy utilization; Freezing; Heat convection; Heat exchangers; Heating; Intelligent control; Office buildings; Temperature distribution; Thermal load; Ventilation; Waste heat utilization; Air conditioning loads; Air diffusion; Air distribution systems; Air volume systems; Building energy simulation programs; Duct system design; EiRev; Energy demands; Energy recovery; Ice storage; Air conditioning ducts

Authors: Purvis G.
Title: Nanotechnology, standards and tools benefit smart materials
Authors with affiliations: Purvis, G.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: Biotechnology; Electrodes; Energy storage; Intelligent materials; Surface engineering; Nanotechnology

Authors: Haga H., Ohta M., Tarmoom I.O.
Title: Development of high speed inspection system for cos tank bottom plate
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - Abu Dhabi International Petroleum Exhibition and Conference 2002, ADIPEC 2002
Affiliations: Asahi Engineering Co., Ltd. (AEC), Japan; Japan Oil Development Co., Ltd. (JODCO), Japan; Abu Dhabi National Oil Co.(ADNOC), United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Haga, H., Asahi Engineering Co., Ltd. (AEC), Japan; Ohta, M., Japan Oil Development Co., Ltd. (JODCO), Japan; Tarmoom, I.O., Abu Dhabi National Oil Co.(ADNOC), United Arab Emirates
Abstract: One of the major causes of leaks of storage tanks is thickness reduction of bottom plates due to unexpected corrosion of under surfaces of plates. And it is extremely difficult to detect such defects or analyze corrosive trend of the whole bottom plates by other inspection systems. On the other hand, it is asked for curtailment of maintenance expense. Such a background is taken into consideration. We were inquired about the method of grasping the status of the background of tank bottom plates quantitatively with high precision. We have succeeded in development of prototype inspection equipment and system. This development project was supported by Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) and New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (NEDO) in Japan. Developed inspection system (prototype) consisting of ultrasonic measuring unit having a 120mm of inspection width and data processing unit enables to identify such corroded condition accurately by continuous measurement of whole bottom plates of tanks. Especially, it was aimed at enabling measurement over GRP film (Maximum thickness of 6mm). This system will contribute to dedicated predictive maintenance to ensure safety operation of tanks. Copyright © 2002, Society of Petroleum Engineers Inc.
Index Keywords: Corrosion; Data handling; Digital storage; Gasoline; Inspection; Inspection equipment; Tanks (containers); Abu dhabi national oil companies; Continuous measurements; Data processing units; Development project; High-speed inspection; New energy and industrial technology development organizations; Predictive maintenance; Thickness reduction; Ultrasonic applications

Authors: Brinkman M.L., Herder J.L.
Title: Optimizing a balanced spring mechanism
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Design Engineering Technical Conference
Affiliations: Delft University of Technology, Department of Design, HuMan-Machine Systems Group, Mekelweg 2, 2628 CD Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Brinkman, M.L., Delft University of Technology, Department of Design, HuMan-Machine Systems Group, Mekelweg 2, 2628 CD Delft, Netherlands; Herder, J.L., Delft University of Technology, Department of Design, HuMan-Machine Systems Group, Mekelweg 2, 2628 CD Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: Static balancing may be used to reduce unwanted forces in a mechanism. A bottom-up methodology for designing balanced systems is described. The approach differs from the classical mechanism synthesis methods in that a simple already balanced mechanism is developed into a mechanism of the desired specifications, rather than that an adjustment mechanism is synthesized to match the required transfer function between the energy storage devices. The described methodology uses some idealizations to yield a coherent theoretical framework for designing systems that are perfectly balanced. When real world constraints are to be applied on a system conceived of in this way, numerical approximation may become necessary. This paper describes an approximation method using an ideal design as an initial estimate. Examples are given that illustrate the followed approach.
Index Keywords: Balancing; Dynamics; Force control; Motion compensation; Optimization; Systems analysis; Engineering design; Springs (components)

Authors: McNeely P.D.
Title: Staged pressure accumulation in a partitioned accumulator
Affiliations: QED Services, Inc.
Authors with affiliations: McNeely, P.D., QED Services, Inc.
Abstract: A pressure accumulator allows system designers to increase the potential energy of a trapped gas or fluid, and to release that stored energy as required by the working circuit. Pressure accumulators also serve as an important component in mobile and industrial hydraulic circuits, acting to suppress fluid surges generated by abrupt movement of the load. The design of pressure accumulators can be modified somewhat to provide additional functionality, however. A partitioned accumulator is described in this paper which can be used with a pilot operated valve to accumulate fluid in several pressure ranges, and can supply fluid in the pressure range required by the working circuit. This design provides for the storage of separate volumes of pressurized fluid, while allowing controlled pressure interaction between the fluid volumes. Copyright © 2002 SAE International and NFPA.
Index Keywords: Hydraulic equipment; Hydraulic machinery; Potential energy; Fluid volumes; Industrial hydraulics; Pilot operated valves; Pressure accumulators; Pressure interactions; Pressure ranges; Pressurized fluids; System designers; Hydraulic accumulators

Authors: Liffring M.
Title: Optimization of launch vehicle energy storage
Affiliations: Boeing Commercial Airplane Group
Authors with affiliations: Liffring, M., Boeing Commercial Airplane Group
Abstract: An innovative approach is presented to reduce the required energy storage mass for reusable launch vehicle (RLV) applications that plan to use electrically powered actuation of flight control surfaces. Results from trade studies are presented to show the benefits of new configurations to reduce mass and meet both reliability and fault tolerance requirements. Results will show how the optimum configuration can be determined. Extensions to this original work have demonstrated its practicality for aerospace applications. This includes reducing the complexity of the control required to manage the power system interconnects. The distribution system allows autonomous operation and better power quality during transient events and fault clearing. Additional control elements can be added to improve system efficiency during nominal operating conditions. Possible applications include RLV designs with high peak-power requirements such as electro-mechanical actuators (EMAs) and electro-hydraulic actuators (EHAs). The results presented will include data on how the system provides high reliability and yet also minimizes mass and thermal heat generation. Copyright © 2002 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Aerospace applications; Control surfaces; Digital storage; Electromechanical devices; Energy storage; Fault tolerance; Hydraulic actuators; Launch vehicles; Mechanical actuators; Reusability; Autonomous operations; Distribution systems; Electro-hydraulic actuator; Flight control surface; Innovative approaches; Optimum configurations; Re-usable launch vehicles (RLV); Tolerance requirement; Electromechanical actuators

Authors: Ahmed I.L.M., Leung P.S., Datta P.K.
Title: Coated rotor and slotted pad in a good interactions
Affiliations: School of Engineering, University of Northumbria, Newcastle, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ahmed, I.L.M., School of Engineering, University of Northumbria, Newcastle, United Kingdom; Leung, P.S., School of Engineering, University of Northumbria, Newcastle, United Kingdom; Datta, P.K., School of Engineering, University of Northumbria, Newcastle, United Kingdom
Abstract: Coating is very important in some applications particularly disc brakes that are most commonly used in the passenger cars. Slotted friction material also has a great effect on the behaviour of the disc brake friction. Mixing between the coated rotor and the slotted material is of importance to improve the frictional behaviour of the disc brake. Slotted material used in this work is divided into two parts; each part has leading and trailing edge to give the advantages of using two pads in a single braking action. Simulating the kinetic energy of a passenger car to measure the friction force between the disc and pad at different operating conditions have been designed in a test rig. The effect of thermal loading at the sliding interface between the different friction material and the rotor of Floating Calliper Disc Brake (FCDB) has been studied in this work. Initial disc surface temperature was measured and controlled through a high quality technique by using a thermal camera that was fixed at suitable place close to the rotor. The signal from the transducer was amplified and displayed on a digital storage oscilloscope and then fed to a computer for the final analysis. The results showed the different values of coefficient of friction depending on the different operating conditions. The maximum coefficient of friction was 0.58 that was recorded at initial disc surface temperature of 150°C while the braking pressure was 20 bar. The minimum value for the friction coefficient 0.30 was also recorded at initial disc surface temperature of 50°C at rotating speed 500 rpm while the braking pressure was 25 bar. Copyright © 2002 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Author Keywords: Coated Disc; Coating; Friction and coefficient of Friction; Keywords Disc Brake; Non-Slotted; Pad; Slotted; Titanium Nitride
Index Keywords: Atmospheric temperature; Automobiles; Brakes; Cathode ray oscilloscopes; Coatings; Digital storage; Friction; Interfaces (materials); Kinetic energy; Kinetics; Quality control; Surface properties; Titanium nitride; Tribology; Coated Disc; Coefficient of frictions; Disc brakes; Non-Slotted; Slotted; Friction materials

Authors: Bauer P., Rompelman O.
Title: The 'energy challenge' in electrical engineering education
Affiliations: Faculty Information Technology and Systems, Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Bauer, P., Faculty Information Technology and Systems, Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands; Rompelman, O., Faculty Information Technology and Systems, Delft University of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: Traditionally, the education in electrical engineering is roughly divided into two areas, viz. electronics and telecommunication on the one hand and electrical energy on the other. Though the borders between these two areas have become vague, this division is still clearly observable, in particular when it comes down to the student's perception of these areas as potential fields of study. Electrical energy has an old-fashioned image. Furthermore, over the last decades there has been a shift from laboratory experiments to computer simulations. In this paper a new approach is introduced, which is aimed at raising first-year students' awareness of the potential attractiveness of electrical energy as an area of study. The approach is project-oriented and based on teamwork. Projects are carried out that are aimed at the design, implementation and verification of small total energy systems. The problems involved are related to energy production, system design, energy storage and consumption. © 2002 Taylor & Francis Ltd.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: ChevronTexaco snaps up Dais-Analytic's fuel cell, processing expertise
Abstract: Certain assets of Dais-Analytic Corp's fuel processing and fuel cell group were acquired by ChevronTexaco Technology Ventures. The investment augments ChevronTexaco's existing capabilities in reforming technology, to provide comprehensive fuel processing and fuel cell system integration solutions through reliable, cost-effective systems that generate hydrogen from readily available hydrocarbons including natural gas, propane, gasoline and diesel. ChevronTexaco Technology Ventures is developing and commercializing new and emerging energy technologies including fuel cells, fuel processing systems, hydrogen storage, and hydrogen infrastructure. It already has stakes in SOFC developer Acumentarics and ChevronTexaco Ovonic Fuel Cell Co.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: US Army evaluating hydrogen storage
Abstract: Millennium Cell has sold two Hydrogen on Demand™ hydrogen storage and generation systems to the US Army Tank Automotive & Armaments Command's National Automotive Center (NAC). The technology stores the energy potential of hydrogen in the chemical bonds of environmentally friendly sodium borohydride. NAC evaluated these two units, one designed to work with fuel cells in the 1-5 kwe range and the other in the > 1 kwe range.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proton Energy completes Nasa contract
Abstract: Proton Energy Systems successfully completed the second stage of a two-part contract with Nasa for an advanced solid-state 1 kwe Unigen® Unitized Regenerative Fuel cell (URFC) system. Nasa selected Proton to demonstrate the URFC systems as an energy storage technology for zero- and micro-gravity environments. The fuel cell system incorporates features that eliminate rotating equipment, fans, compressors, and pumps. The Unigen URFC energy storage system uses a unique PEM cell that can operate as both a fuel cell and an electrolysis cell. It can make hydrogen at pressure by electrolysis of water, and reverse this process to generate electric power when needed from the stored hydrogen.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Stuart Energy provides hydrogen infrastructure to Chula Vista
Abstract: The City of Chula Vista in California, in cooperation with SunLine Transit Agency, has ordered a fast-fill, portable hydrogen fueling station from Stuart Energy Systems. Funded by a grant from the DOE and the California Energy Commission, the Stuart Energy CFP-1350 unit will provide clean hydrogen fuel for fuel cell buses and vehicles located at SunLine, then at Chula Vista. Stuart Energy's CFP-1350 is a unique portable hydrogen infrastructure solution which integrates hydrogen generation equipment, storage and dual-pressure dispensing. The system is mounted on a single trailer and packaged for easy transport, and can produce > 3 kg/hr hydrogen, enough to fuel up to three buses a day. The unit will enable the City of Chula Vista to test and demonstrate fuel cell buses and other hydrogen vehicles. The system could also be utilized to provide remote fueling services for hydrogen vehicle demonstrations.

Authors: Jones S., Stelbovics A.T.
Title: Efficient solution of three-body quantum collision problems: Application to the Temkin-Poet model
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Centre for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, School of Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Murdoch University, Perth, 6150, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Jones, S., Centre for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, School of Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Murdoch University, Perth, 6150, Australia; Stelbovics, A.T., Centre for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, School of Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Murdoch University, Perth, 6150, Australia
Abstract: We have developed a variable-spacing finite-difference algorithm that rapidly propagates the general solution of Schrödinger’s equation to large distances (whereupon it can be matched to asymptotic solutions, including the ionization channel, to extract the desired scattering quantities). The present algorithm, when compared to Poet’s corresponding fixed-spacing algorithm [R. Poet, J. Phys. B 13, 2995 (1980); S. Jones and A. T. Stelbovics, Phys. Rev. Lett. 84, 1878 (2000)], reduces storage by 98% and computation time by 99.98%. The method is applied to the Temkin-Poet electron-hydrogen model collision problem. Complete results (elastic, inelastic, and ionization) are obtained for low (17.6 eV), intermediate (27.2, 40.8, and 54.4 eV), and high (150 eV) impact energies. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Andersen J.U., Hvelplund P., Nielsen S.B., Pedersen U.V., Tomita S.
Title: Statistical electron emission after laser excitation of [Formula Presented] ions from an electrospray source
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Andersen, J.U., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Hvelplund, P., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Nielsen, S.B., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Pedersen, U.V., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Tomita, S., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark
Abstract: We have measured electron emission from [Formula Presented] ions in a storage ring. The ions were produced at room temperature and excited by absorption of photons with a total energy of 14 eV. The observed lifetime [Formula Presented] is consistent with detailed balance and a cross section of [Formula Presented] for electron attachment. The measurements also determine the thermal radiation intensity [Formula Presented] at a well-defined internal temperature T, [Formula Presented] at [Formula Presented] The results are consistent with the scaling law [Formula Presented] and with the intensity, [Formula Presented] at 1400 K, inferred from previous measurements of cooling in a storage ring of [Formula Presented] ions injected from a hot source. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Greiff J., Koch I., Scobel W., Rohdjeß H., Dyring J., Fransson K., Gustafsson L., Häggström S., Höistad B., Johanson J., Johansson A., Johansson T., Khoukaz A., Kullander S., Ruber R.J.M.Y., Złomańczuk J., Dunin V., Morosov B., Sukhanov A., Zernov A., Stepaniak J., Bilger R., Brodowski W., Clement H., Wagner G.J., Calén H., Ekström C., Kupść A., Marciniewski P., Zabierowski J., Shwartz B., Sukhanov A., Oelert W., Sefzick T., Turowiecki A.
Title: Quasifree bremsstrahlung in the [Formula Presented] reaction above the pion production threshold
Affiliations: I. Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Hamburg, D-22761, Germany; Institut für Strahlen und Kernphysik, Universität Bonn, Bonn, D-53115, Germany; Department of Radiation Sciences, Uppsala University, Uppsala, S-75121, Sweden; Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, 101000, Russian Federation; Soltan Institute for Nuclear Studies, Warsaw, PL-00681, Poland; Physikalisches Institut, Universität Tübingen, Tübingen, D-72076, Germany; The Svedberg Laboratory, Uppsala, S-75121, Sweden; Soltan Institute for Nuclear Studies, Lódź, PL-90137, Poland; Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; IKP, Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH, Jülich, D-52425, Germany; Institute of Experimental Physics, Warsaw University, Warsaw, PL-0061, Poland

Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Hamburg, D-22761, Germany; Scobel, W., I. Sefzick, T., IKP, Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH, Jülich, D-52425, Germany; Turowiecki, A., Institute of Experimental Physics, Warsaw University, Warsaw, PL-0061, Poland
Abstract: Experimental results of the [Formula Presented] reaction are presented for several observables with deuteron projectile energies between 437 MeV and 559 MeV. The kinematically complete measurements were performed at the CELSIUS storage ring with the PROMICE/WASA setup. Angular and spectral distributions of the charged ejectiles are decomposed into fractions that can be attributed to a quasifree [Formula Presented] process with a spectator proton and to a process involving all three nucleons. Within the acceptance of the detector, about two thirds of the events are associated to the quasifree process; the remainder are characterized by substantial transverse momentum components transferred to a participating outgoing proton. © 2002 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Kawabata Y., Morine Y., Oka T., Kawabata T.
Title: New Variable Speed Constant Frequency Stand-Alone Power Generating System
Affiliations: Osaka Prefectural College of Technology, Japan; Ritsumeikan University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kawabata, Y., Osaka Prefectural College of Technology, Japan; Morine, Y., Ritsumeikan University, Japan; Oka, T., Ritsumeikan University, Japan; Kawabata, T., Ritsumeikan University, Japan
Abstract: Variable speed and constant frequency power generating systems using rotor excitation of the wound-rotor induction machines have been used for such applications as variable speed pump generators and flywheel energy storage systems. However, the stand-alone generating system of this type, has only been reported and has not yet been practically used. On the other hand, the stand-alone generating systems using diesel engines have been widely used for emergency supply of plants or isolated islands and so on. However, in these cases, the synchronous generators are usually used. If the output frequency is to be kept constant, there is the need to control the speed of the engine using a high performance governor. Even then, the output frequency changes in case of a sudden load change. This paper proposes a new stand-alone power generating system. In this system, the constant frequency output voltage can be obtained even though rotor speed changes by several percent. © 2002, The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Block T., Felser C., Windeln J.
Title: Spin polarized tunneling at room temperature in a Heusler compound - A non-oxide material with a large negative magnetoresistance effect in low magnetic fields
Source title: INTERMAG Europe 2002 - IEEE International Magnetics Conference
Affiliations: Institut für Anorganische Chemie und Analytische Chemie, Universität Mainz, Duesbergweg 10-14, Mainz, D-55099, Germany; IBM, Mainz, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Block, T., Institut für Anorganische Chemie und Analytische Chemie, Universität Mainz, Duesbergweg 10-14, Mainz, D-55099, Germany; Felser, C., Institut für Anorganische Chemie und Analytische Chemie, Universität Mainz, Duesbergweg 10-14, Mainz, D-55099, Germany; Windeln, J., IBM, Mainz, Germany
Abstract: Materials which display large changes in resistivity in response to an applied magnetic field (magnetoresistance) are currently of great interest due to their potential for applications in magnetic sensors, magnetic random access memories, and spintronics-a new kind of electronics based on spin instead of charge. Although ferromagnetic manganites show colossal magnetoresistance (CMR) effects around their Curie temperature, the low field and nearly temperature independent magnetoresistance properties important for spintronics are found only at low temperatures. Guided by striking features in the electronic structure of several magnetic compounds, we prepared the Heusler compound Co2Cr0.6Fe0.4Al. Based on our band structure calculations, we have chosen this composition in order to obtain a ferromagnetic half metal with a van Hove singularity in the vicinity of the Fermi energy in the majority spin channel and a gap in the minority spin channel. We find evidence for spin polarized transport at room temperature, showing up in a magnetoresistive effect of 35% in a small magnetic field of 0.1 Tesla. This demonstrates the feasibility of developing spintronics at room temperature based on intermetallic compounds. ©2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Cobalt compounds; Electronic structure; Ferromagnetic materials; Ferromagnetism; Intermetallics; Magnetic fields; Magnetic storage; Magnetism; Magnetoelectronics; Manganites; Random access storage; Spin polarization; Tunnelling magnetoresistance; Band structure calculation; Colossal magnetoresistance effect; Ferromagnetic manganites; Large negative magnetoresistance; Magnetic random access memory; Magneto-resistive effect; Magnetoresistance properties; Temperature independents; Colossal magnetoresistance

Authors: Buess M., Acremann Y., Back C.H., Dumm M., Bayreuther G., Pescia D.
Title: Ultrafast generation of magnetic fields in a Schottky diode
Source title: INTERMAG Europe 2002 - IEEE International Magnetics Conference
Affiliations: Laboratorium für Festkörperphysik, Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zürich, Zürich, CH-8093, Switzerland; Institut für Experimentelle und Angewandte Physik, Universität Regensburg, Universitätsstr. 31, Regensburg, 93040, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Buess, M., Laboratorium für Festkörperphysik, Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zürich, Zürich, CH-8093, Switzerland; Acremann, Y., Laboratorium für Festkörperphysik, Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zürich, Zürich, CH-8093, Switzerland; Back, C.H., Laboratorium für Festkörperphysik, Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zürich, Zürich, CH-8093, Switzerland; Dumm, M., Institut für Experimentelle und Angewandte Physik, Universität Regensburg, Universitätsstr. 31, Regensburg, 93040, Germany; Bayreuther, G., Institut für Experimentelle und Angewandte Physik, Universität Regensburg, Universitätsstr. 31, Regensburg, 93040, Germany; Pescia, D., Laboratorium für Festkörperphysik, Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zürich, Zürich, CH-8093, Switzerland
Abstract: For the development of future magnetic data storage technologies, the ultrafast generation of local magnetic fields is essential. Subnanosecond excitation of the magnetic state has so far been achieved by launching current pulses into micro-coils and micro-striplines and by using the high-energy electron beams. Local injection of a spin-polarized current through an all-metal junction has been proposed as an efficient method of switching magnetic elements, and experiments seem to confirm this. Here we introduce a different scheme for the ultrafast generation of local magnetic fields in such a hybrid structure. The basis of our approach is to optically pump a Schottky diode with a focused, ∼150-fs laser pulse. The laser generates a current across the semiconductor-metal junction, which in turn gives rise to an in-plane magnetic field. This scheme combines the localization of current injection techniques with the speed of current generation at a Schottky barrier. Specific advantages include the ability to rapidly create local fields along any in-plane direction anywhere on the sample, the ability to scan the field over many magnetic elements and the ability to tune the magnitude of the field with the diode bias voltage. ©2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Diodes; Excited states; Magnetic fields; Magnetism; Optical pumping; Pumping (laser); Schottky barrier diodes; Semiconductor diodes; Semiconductor junctions; Semiconductor lasers; Current generation; Current injections; High energy electron beams; In-plane direction; In-plane magnetic fields; Local magnetic field; Semiconductor metals; Spin polarized currents; Magnetic storage

Authors: Man Y., Liu B., Ma Y.
Title: Mapping of slider-disk interaction
Source title: INTERMAG Europe 2002 - IEEE International Magnetics Conference
Affiliations: Data Storage Institute, DSI Building, 5 Engineering Drive 1, Singapore, 117608, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Man, Y., Data Storage Institute, DSI Building, 5 Engineering Drive 1, Singapore, 117608, Singapore; Liu, B., Data Storage Institute, DSI Building, 5 Engineering Drive 1, Singapore, 117608, Singapore; Ma, Y., Data Storage Institute, DSI Building, 5 Engineering Drive 1, Singapore, 117608, Singapore
Abstract: In hard disk drives, the flying height of slider is reduced continuously to increase recording density. Low flying height results in an increased possibility of slider-disk interactions which cause serious reliability and stability problems. This work reports a novel method of mapping slider-disk and slider-particle-disk interactions. The test setup includes a specially prepared disk, a DC magnetic field generator and a temperature control unit by which the sensitivity of testing system to the level of energy disturbance is adjusted. The special disk is of the same structural design as the conventional magnetic disk except using a specially prepared magneto-optical (MO) layer of much lower Curie temperature and related supporting layers to replace the magnetic layer and related supporting layers of the magnetic disk media. Therefore, any interaction that generates a temperature above the Curie temperature of the MO layer will be recorded as a signature, mapped by optical and magnetic tools, and analyzed later. ©2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Curie temperature; Electric machine control; Hard disk storage; Mapping; Nonvolatile storage; DC magnetic field; Magnetic layers; Magneto-optical; Recording density; Reliability and stability; Slider-disk interactions; Temperature control unit; Testing systems; Magnetism

Authors: Gurovich B.A., Dolgii D.I., Meilikhov E.Z., Kuleshova E.A.
Title: New technique for producing patterned magnetic media
Source title: INTERMAG Europe 2002 - IEEE International Magnetics Conference
Affiliations: Russian Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Gurovich, B.A., Russian Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Dolgii, D.I., Russian Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Meilikhov, E.Z., Russian Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Kuleshova, E.A., Russian Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: One of the most perspective directions of preparing magnetic memory of ultra-high density relates to employing the patterned magnetic structure. The basis for suggested nonlithographic method of producing such a media is the new physical phenomena discovered by authors, whose the main point is the controllable selective removal of atoms (for instance, oxygen or nitrogen ones) from two- or poly-atomic compounds of metals under irradiation with accelerated protons of certain energies. Together with changing chemical composition, the general physical properties of irradiated material layers are also changed. Thereby, we succeeded to transform non-magnetic metal oxides into magnetic metals with characteristics similar to those of bulk metals. Employing masks one could produce regular structures comprising magnetic islands of the regular form in a non-magnetic thin-film matrix. In principle, the spatial pattern resolution of about 10 nm is attainable. ©2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Magnetic devices; Magnetic storage; Magnetic thin films; Metals; Nitrogen removal; Chemical compositions; Irradiated materials; Nonlithographic method; Patterned magnetic media; Patterned magnetic structure; Physical phenomena; Selective removal of atoms; Ultrahigh density; Magnetism

Authors: Lew W.S., Li S.P., Lopez-Diaz L., Vaz C.A.F., Bland J.A.C., Natali M., Chen Y.
Title: Modulated magnetic structures in chemically homogeneous films
Source title: INTERMAG Europe 2002 - IEEE International Magnetics Conference
Affiliations: Cavendish Laboratory, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 0HE, United Kingdom; L2M (CNRS), 196 Avenue Henri Ravera, Bagneux Cedex, 92225, France
Authors with affiliations: Lew, W.S., Cavendish Laboratory, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 0HE, United Kingdom; Li, S.P., Cavendish Laboratory, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 0HE, United Kingdom; Lopez-Diaz, L., Cavendish Laboratory, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 0HE, United Kingdom; Vaz, C.A.F., Cavendish Laboratory, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 0HE, United Kingdom; Bland, J.A.C., Cavendish Laboratory, Madingley Road, Cambridge, CB3 0HE, United Kingdom; Natali, M., L2M (CNRS), 196 Avenue Henri Ravera, Bagneux Cedex, 92225, France; Chen, Y., L2M (CNRS), 196 Avenue Henri Ravera, Bagneux Cedex, 92225, France
Abstract: Increasing storage density requirements in information technology have continued to motivate the exploration of new magnetic media. Several approaches are now being studied intensively, such as stabilizing nanoscale magnetic domains in continuous films and patterning magnetic films into isolated dots. In this work we introduce a new type of magnetic medium where the spin configurations are engineered in chemically homogenous magnetic films. Such a medium not only maintains the surface planarity but also the homogeneity of the magnetic materials. Substrates with laterally modulated single-crystal and polycrystalline surface regions were used to induce selective epitaxial growth of a ferromagnetic Ni film. The samples have a structure of GaAs/ Co(1.8nm)/Cu(70nm)/Ni(5nm)/Cu(5nm). Ultrathin NiO (1nm) patterns were used to modulate the GaAs substrate surface. The films that interfaced directly with GaAs grow epitaxially and the Ni magnetization is oriented out-of-plane. The films that interfaced with the NiO patterns have polycrystalline structures and the Ni magnetization is directed in the plane. The co-existence of the polycrystalline and epitaxial features are confirmed by in situ reflection high-energy electron diffraction analyses. Atomic force microscopy was used to examine the sample surface yielding statistical roughness parameters in the range similar to that of epitaxial continuous Cu/Ni/Cu films. The co-existence of the in-plane and out-of plane magnetization regions in the films was imaged by magnetic force microscopy, also further confirmed by magneto-optic Kerr effect and superconducting quantum-interference device measurements. The 90 degree transition between the in-plane and out-of-plane regions, which is due to the spatially varying anisotropy properties of the film, corresponds to a new type of magnetic wall (the 'anisotropy constrained magnetic wall'). Micromagnetic simulations show that the spin transition regions is asymmetric, has a small out-of-plane component and has no mobility under external perturbation. ©2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Anisotropy; Atomic force microscopy; Copper; Crystallography; Film growth; Gallium arsenide; Interfaces (materials); Magnetic anisotropy; Magnetic devices; Magnetic domains; Magnetic films; Magnetic materials; Magnetic storage; Magnetism; Magnetization; Nanomagnetics; Nickel; Quantum interference devices; Reflection high energy electron diffraction; Semiconducting gallium; Single crystals; SQUIDs; Substrates; Superconducting films; External perturbations; Magneto-optic Kerr effect; Micromagnetic simulations; Out-of-plane components; Polycrystalline structure; Polycrystalline surface; Selective epitaxial growth; Statistical roughness; Epitaxial growth

Authors: Timofeeva L.F., Filin V.M., Shishkov N.V., Bulkin V.I., Zhmak V.a., Krivova V.L., Semova E.A.
Title: Nuclear safe Pu - ceramics defects and behavior during self-irradiation
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Timofeeva, L.F., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation; Filin, V.M., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation; Shishkov, N.V., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation; Bulkin, V.I., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation; Zhmak, V.a., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation; Krivova, V.L., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation; Semova, E.A., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 123060, Russian Federation
Abstract: Methods of X-ray diffraction analysis and positron spectroscopy are used to study initial stages of self-irradiation of nuclear safe homogeneous and heterogeneous type ceramics (Hf, Pu) and (Hf, Pu, Y). Different character of the change in FCC lattice parameter of binary (Hf+4, Pu+4) and ternary (Hf+4, PU+4, y+3) oxide solid solutions during storage is shown. Three micro-defect types are detected with the method of positron lifetime. The effective positron lifetime (tf) individual for each sample depends on displacement dose (dpa during storage): it is increases 1.5 times faster in PuO2than in (Hf, Pu) and (Hf, Pu, Y) ceramics. Another positron annihilation spectrum characteristic, Le. spectrum half-width at half maximum, T1/2, depends on the displacement dose and is changes in different manner for different types ceramics. © 2002 Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All Rights Reserved.
Author Keywords: Ceramics; Neutron poison; Nuclear safe; Plutonium oxide; Positron spectroscopy; Self-irradiation; X-ray diffraction

Authors: Timofeeva L.F., Nadykto B.A., Baiburin G.G., Klepatskaya E.A., Molomin V.I.
Title: Preparation and study of nuclear safe porous ceramics comprised of neutron poisons (Hf, Gd) impregnated with plutonium sol-gel PuO2
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 23060, Russian Federation; RFNC-VNIIEF, Nizhni Novgorod region, 607190, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Timofeeva, L.F., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 23060, Russian Federation; Nadykto, B.A., RFNC-VNIIEF, Nizhni Novgorod region, 607190, Russian Federation; Baiburin, G.G., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 23060, Russian Federation; Klepatskaya, E.A., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 23060, Russian Federation; Molomin, V.I., FGUP VNIINM, Moscow, 23060, Russian Federation
Abstract: Heterogeneous type ceramics containing oxides of Pu and n° poisons designed for long-term storage of fissile materials and high-level radioactive wastes are studied. The critical-mass-free feature of the ceramics was achieved by a certain ratio of Pu and n° poisons given by the physical calculation. The ceramics were produced through impregnation with plutonium sol-gel of a porous matrix, a skeleton, fabricated from various neutron poisons (HfO2, Gd2O3, HfC, HfCxOy) using various methods. The skeleton of hamium oxide with open porosity of 30-35% was produced by activated sintering of hafnium oxide powders of a certain fractional composition using the hafnium oxide sol-gel as a binder and sintering activator. The matrix of gadolinium oxide, Gd2O3, had porosity 60%, was produced by sintering of mixed powders (Gd2O3+11.2 wt. % C(black)) at 1200C. The skeletons made of HfC and HfCxOy had open porosity of 45 - 47%, were produced in one stage through reaction sintering in vacuum of batch composed of mixed hafnium oxide and carbon. To impregnate the fabricated skeletons, the drop method was used allowing introduction to them of a given quantity of PuO2 sol with concentration from 330 to 490 g/l. On drying, heating, thermal destruction, and sintering the produced compositions were comprehensively studied. © 2002 Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All Rights Reserved.
Author Keywords: Ceramics; Gadolinium; Hafnium; Neutron poison; Nuclear safety; Plutonium oxide sol; Sintering; Skeleton

Authors: Hittner D.
Title: Industrial perspective on nuclear data
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Affiliations: Comité français des données nucléaires (CFDN), Tour Framatome, Framatome ANP, 92084, France
Authors with affiliations: Hittner, D., Comité français des données nucléaires (CFDN), Tour Framatome, Framatome ANP, 92084, France
Abstract: Even in the phase of maturity reached by nuclear industry, the industrial needs for nuclear data are numerous. For present plants, improving competitiveness, satisfying increasingly stringent safety requirements, increasing the fuel burnup, facing the ageing of plants, designing compact interim storage, reprocessing, etc. are sources of many needs for new or improved data. For the middle term, replacing the present industrial facilities may include some innovations, mature for industrialisation, like HTRs or inert matrix fuel in LWRs. Using new materials, aiming at ultra high burnups, burning different types of fuel (e.g. thorium cycle), induces new data requirements. For the long term, other innovative technologies must be available, for keeping the fast reactor option open, transmuting wastes, minimising waste production in integrated fuel cycles (e.g. with molten salt reactors), increasing the coolant temperature (> 900°C), etc. For such options, only the data needed for answering key feasibility issues are necessary now. The “Comité Français des Données Nucléaires” is working at a very restrictive high priority list of data needs selected following criteria of importance for industrial applications and feasibility. As advances in nuclear data are resulting from international efforts, such approach, which can guide the research priorities, must be internationalised. © 2014 Atomic Energy Society of Japan.
Author Keywords: Industrial needs; Innovation in nuclear energy; International co-operation; MICHELANGELO Network; Request list for nuclear data measurement and evaluation

Abstract: An overview of the thermal energy storage (TES) tanks installed at the Humble Independent School District (ISD) in Humble, TX, is presented. The multiple and smaller compressors used for the chiller systems resulted in maximizing the efficiency with significant cost savings.

Authors: Liu J.W., Choi S.S., Chen S.
Title: Design of Step Dynamic Voltage Regulator for Power Quality Enhancement
Affiliations: Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Liu, J.W., Nanyang Technological University, Singapore; Choi, S.S., Nanyang Technological University, Singapore; Chen, S., Nanyang Technological University, Singapore
Abstract: The design of a step dynamic voltage regulator is considered for the purpose of restoring load voltage without incurring excessive phase angle shift. As a type of custom-power device devoid of any significant energy-storage capability, the process of voltage restoration by the regulator has to depend on the power in-feed from external supply system. As a consequence, the analysis shows that there are inherent limits imposed on the device for achieving successful voltage restoration. Pertinent expressions are derived which relate the limits to the parametric values describing the supply system and loads. When the expressions are used in conjunction with a proposed computational procedure, a method to determine suitable regulator design for the purpose of power quality enhancement is obtained. © 2002, IEEE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Power quality enhancement; step-dynamic voltage regulator; voltage magnitude and phase angle shift

Abstract: A design model may be used from functional validation to design implementation. In this paper, a C model that has already been used to validate and estimate functional performance is used to explore data transfer and storage, aiming to reduce power consumption. Through this model, a systematic methodology for power management (DTSE) is applied to a block turbo-decoding algorithm. Estimations of power dissipation are conducted using a tool for counting memory accesses in an executable C code. Results show a decrease of 25% in power dissipation. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Hayashida N., Hirata H., Komaki T., Usami M., Ushida T., Inoue H., Kato T., Shingai H., Utsunomiya H.
Title: Functional hard-coat for cartridge-free DVR-blue
Source title: 2002 International Symposium on Optical Memory and Optical Data Storage Topical Meeting, ISOM/ODS 2002 - Joint International Symposium on Optical Memory and Optical Data Storage 2002, Technical Digest
Affiliations: Development Department, Recording Media and Solutions Business Group, TDK Corporation, TDK Chikumagawa the TC-1, 462-1, Otai, Saku-shi, Nagano  385-0009, Japan

Abstract: Optical discs with larger storage capacity and higher data recording rates are required for the coming digital network society, for example, to realize non-linear editing and long term data archiving on broadcasting tasks. We have been developing a new phase change optical disc, which has much higher data recording rate of up to 140 Mbps (T. Kato et al, Tech. Dig. ISOM2001, pp. 200-201, 2001), based on the DVR system (λ=405 nm, NA=0.85, cover layer thickness=100 μm) (Y. Kuroda et al, 1999; M.J. Dekker et al, 2000; Y. Kasami et al, 2000). As a general rule, the smaller the laser spot size on the disc surface, the more sensitive the disc becomes to scratches or fingerprints on it. In such a system, the distance between the disc surface and objective lens (i.e. working distance) is very narrow due to a high NA. Therefore it is also feared that the objective lens hits the disc surface due to an external impact. To avoid these problems when the disc is taken out of a cartridge, we have developed a new hard-coat. The cartridge-free DVR-blue disc was expected to be accomplished by the following properties: (1) abrasion resistance; (2) scratch resistance; (3) water and oil repellency (low surface free energy). Among these properties, the abrasion resistance is considered to be the most important. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Hwang E., Roh J., Kim K., Kang B., Park J., Jung H.
Title: Code-word complementing block modulation code for holographic data storage
Source title: 2002 International Symposium on Optical Memory and Optical Data Storage Topical Meeting, ISOM/ODS 2002 - Joint International Symposium on Optical Memory and Optical Data Storage 2002, Technical Digest
Affiliations: Digital Media Lab., Daewoo Electronics Co., 543, Danjeung-dong, Kunpo-shi, Kyonggi-do, 435-733, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Hwang, E., Digital Media Lab., Daewoo Electronics Co., 543, Danjeung-dong, Kunpo-shi, Kyonggi-do, 435-733, South Korea; Roh, J., Digital Media Lab., Daewoo Electronics Co., 543, Danjeung-dong, Kunpo-shi, Kyonggi-do, 435-733, South Korea; Kim, K., Digital Media Lab., Daewoo Electronics Co., 543, Danjeung-dong, Kunpo-shi, Kyonggi-do, 435-733, South Korea; Kang, B., Digital Media Lab., Daewoo Electronics Co., 543, Danjeung-dong, Kunpo-shi, Kyonggi-do, 435-733, South Korea; Park, J., Digital Media Lab., Daewoo Electronics Co., 543, Danjeung-dong, Kunpo-shi, Kyonggi-do, 435-733, South Korea; Jung, H., Digital Media Lab., Daewoo Electronics Co., 543, Danjeung-dong, Kunpo-shi, Kyonggi-do, 435-733, South Korea
Abstract: The holographic digital data storage (HDDS) system has been investigated for next generation digital storage due to its high storage density and high data transfer rates (J.F. Heanue et al., Science, pp. 749-752, 1994). Various modulation codes have been introduced to mitigate noise problems in HDDS systems (H.J. Coufal et al., Holographic Data Storage, Springer 2000). In this paper, a new 2D modulation scheme, or CCBM (code-word complementing block modulation), is proposed. The CCBM yields a pseudo-random array consisting of codewords with multiple weights (K. Kim et al., Proc. Satellite ISOM 2000, pp. 46-47, 2000; E. Hwang et al., Tech. Dig. ISOM 2001, pp. 142-143, 2001), and consequently gives spectral smoothing and constant energy in the modulated pages of data. This paper also covers a novel detection scheme in conjunction with the proposed CCBM. The results of numerical simulations and actual recording experiments are presented to verify the performances of CCBM. In a noisy HDDS channel, the results show that CCBM outperforms the guided scrambling (GS) method in terms of SNR and BER (bit error rate). © 2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Bit error rate; Codes (symbols); Data storage equipment; Data transfer; Data transfer rates; Digital storage; Holography; Modulation; Nonvolatile storage; Signal to noise ratio; BER (bit error rate); Guided scrambling; High data transfer rates; High storage density; Holographic data storage; Modulation codes; Modulation schemes; Spectral smoothing; Optical data storage

Abstract: The reflectivity and thermal properties are the main problems in GeSbTe phase-change disks that must be improved (N. Nobukuni et al., J. Appl. Phys. vol. 78, p. 6980, 1995; A. Hirotsune et al., Jpn. J. Appl. Phys. vol. 35, p. 346, 1996; C.M. Lee et al., J. Appl. Phys. vol. 89, p. 3290, 2001; S.Y. Kim et al., Jpn. J. Appl. Phys. vol. 38, p. 1713, 1997). We found that a small amount of Ag addition to the Ge2Sb2Te5 film can increase the reflectivity, crystalline temperature, and the fcc to hcp phase-transition temperature. In addition, the activity energy of the amorphous to fcc phase transition was decreased. © 2002 IEEE.

Abstract: The proceedings contain 55 papers. The topics discussed include: an architecture for self-healing digital systems; coding scheme for low energy consumption fault-tolerant bus; survivable discrete circuits design; fault tolerance evaluation using two software based fault injection methods; a system level approach in designing dual-duplex fault tolerant embedded systems; a new self-checking code-disjoint carry-skip adder; sequential circuits applicable for detecting different types of faults; a high speed encoder for recursive systematic convolutive codes; a hierarchical architecture for concurrent soft error detection based on current sensing; on-line error detection and correction in storage elements with cross-parity check; on-line monitor design of finite-state machines; and a statistical sampler for a new on-line analog test method.

Title: Embedded DRAM (eDRAM) power-energy estimation for system-on-a-chip (SoC) applications

Abstract: Embedded DRAM (eDRAM) power-energy estimation is presented for system-on-a-chip (SOC) applications. The main feature is the signal swing based analytic (SSBA) model, which improves the accuracy of the conventional SRAM power-energy models. The SSBA model combined with the high-level memory access statistics provides a fast and accurate system level power-energy estimation of eDRAM. The power-energy estimation using SSBA model shows 95% accuracy compared with the transistor level power simulation results for three fabricated eDRAMs. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Matsuo H., Kurokawa F., Yokoyama K., Watanabe H.
Title: Steady-state and dynamic characteristics of the Class-D power factor correction converter using magnetic coupling
Source title: Proceedings of the Power Conversion Conference-Osaka 2002, PCC-Osaka 2002

Co. Ltd., Hannou, 857-8585, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents the steady-state and dynamic characteristics of the proposed Class-D power factor correction converter. In the proposed converter, the power factor and line current distortion are improved by using the third winding of the energy-storage reactor of buck-boost converter, and the high power efficiency is achieved by the soft-switching operations of the main power switch and output rectifier diode. As a result, it is clarified that the proposed circuit satisfies the IEC 61000-3-2 Class-D against changes of load. The maximum power factor is 0.83, minimum THD is 68% and maximum power efficiency is 92% at rated condition. Furthermore, it is revealed that the superior dynamic characteristics can be obtained under this circuit condition, and that the most suitable circuit parameters are obtained in both steady-state and dynamic characteristics. © 2002 IEEE.

Abstract: The storage of excess superequilibrium energy occurs in final products of wire electrical explosion. This effect can be successfully used in different fields: in processes of combustion, sintering, and chemical reactions. In the present work, thermal analysis is suggested as a method for the determination of excess energy value. According to results of the thermal analysis, the excess energy for nanosized aluminum can reach a value equal 3-6 enthalpies of metal melting point. © 2002 IEEE.

Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Ion Implantation Technology
Affiliations: CEMES, CNRS, Toulouse, France; IMEL/Demokritos, Athens, Greece; STMicroelectronics, Agrate, Italy; Laboratorio MDM, INFM, Agrate, Italy

Abstract: Silicon nanocrystals buried in a thin oxide can be used as charge storage elements and be integrated in standard CMOS technology to fabricate new non-volatile memory devices. In this geometry, the control of the distances between the nanocrystals layer and the two electrodes, the channel and the gate, of the MOS determines the final characteristics of the device (write-erase and retention times). In this work, we report on a systematic study of the effect of varying the beam energy (0.65 - 2 keV) and the dose (1015-1016 cm-2) on the positioning of 2D-arrays of nanocrystals within 10 nm thick oxide after annealing at 950 and 1050°C. For this, different Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) methods have been used including High Resolution Electron Microscopy (HREM) for imaging isolated nanocrystals and Fresnel contrast imaging of populations of nanocrystals. Our results show that the injection distance" can be precisely tuned in the 5-8 nm range by varying the beam energy. Moreover, very large swelling of the SiO2 layer has been observed when increasing the implanted dose which could be the result of a partial oxidation of the Si ncs layer and/or of the SiO2/Si interface. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Carrada A., Ben Assayag G., Bonafos C., Claverie A., Normand P., Tsoukalas D.
Title: Accurate TEM measurements of the injection distances in nanocrystal based memories
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Ion Implantation Technology
Affiliations: Ion Implantation Group CEMES, CNRS, Toulouse, France; Institute of Microelectronics, NCSR 'Demokritos', Aghia Praskevi, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Carrada, A., Ion Implantation Group CEMES, CNRS, Toulouse, France; Ben Assayag, G., Ion Implantation Group CEMES, CNRS, Toulouse, France; Bonafos, C., Ion Implantation Group CEMES, CNRS, Toulouse, France; Claverie, A., Ion Implantation Group CEMES, CNRS, Toulouse, France; Normand, P., Institute of Microelectronics, NCSR 'Demokritos', Aghia Praskevi, Greece; Tsoukalas, D., Institute of Microelectronics, NCSR 'Demokritos', Aghia Praskevi, Greece
Abstract: Silicon nanocrystals buried in a thin oxide can be used as charge storage elements and be integrated in standard CMOS technology to fabricate new non-volatile memory devices. The control of the distances between the nanocrystals layer and the two electrodes of the MOS determines the final characteristics of the device (write-erase and retention times). This 2D arrays of ncs can be elaborated by ion implantation of Si at low energy. In this paper, we compare two transmission electron microscopy methods that can be used to extract such distances in 10 nm-thick SiO2 layers implanted with Si at low energy. We demonstrate by using image simulations that conventional electron microscopy under out-of-Bragg and strongly underfocussed conditions is the fastest and most efficient technique to be used for routine measurements at subnanometer resolution. Our results show that the injection distance in such devices can be precisely tuned from 5 to 8 nm by adjusting the Si implantation energy from 0.65 keV to 2 keV. © 2002 IEEE.

Title: Fabrication of open-top microchannel plate using deep x-ray exposure mask made with SOI substrate
Source title: 2002 International Microprocesses and Nanotechnology Conference, MNC 2002
Affiliations: Graduate School of Information Science and Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka-shi, Fukuoka  812-8581, Japan; Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Fujimura, T., Graduate School of Information Science and Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka-shi, Fukuoka  812-8581, Japan; Ikeda, A., Graduate School of Information Science and Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka-shi, Fukuoka  812-8581, Japan; Etoh, S., Graduate School of Information Science and Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka-shi, Fukuoka  812-8581, Japan; Hattori, R., Graduate School of Information Science and Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka-shi, Fukuoka  812-8581, Japan; Kuroki, Y., Graduate School of Information Science and Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, Hakozaki 6-10-1, Higashi-ku, Fukuoka-shi, Fukuoka  812-8581, Japan; Chang, S.S., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, POSTECH, South Korea
Abstract: Human genome project has now been completed. At the next stage, the analysis of the DNA diversity originated from each individual is a very important aspect. It requires a method that can determine the base-pair sequence quickly and easily for fast and effective analysis. Separating the biochemical samples by electrophoresis is one of the analysis processes. Recently, electrophoresis has been performed in the fine channel formed on various substrates. By utilizing a microchannel chip for electrophoresis, the dead volume of the reagent and detection apparatus, and energy are reduced. To improve the separation performance of microchannel chip, the width of the channel should be narrower. On the other hand, the volume of the sample that can be introduced is restricted. Then, the channel is filled with ionic solution, and the top of the substrate is covered with a plate for shallow channel, so as not to cause current leakage induced by applying high voltage during electrophoresis. But, it requires a high quality substrate-cover adhesion. technique. We propose a high-aspect-ratio open-top microchannel plate. The high-aspect-ratio structure increases the sample and reagent volume inside the channel without increasing the channel width, which results in an enhancement of the detection sensitivity. And the buffer solution is introduced only before the measurement and sequential supply from an external source is not needed. The chip is standalone. The deep channel leads to another advantage. Its deep depth prevents overflow of the solution to the uncovered channel. By avoiding the difficult sealing process, the fabrication process become easy and high-throughput is realized. © 2002 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Aspect ratio; Electrophoresis; Image storage tubes; Microchannels; Nanotechnology; Plates (structural components); Base pair sequences; Detection sensitivity; Effective analysis; Fabrication process; High aspect ratio structures; Human Genome Project; Micro channel plate; Separation performance; Substrates

Authors: Abramzon E., Yankelevich Y., Pokryvailo A.
Title: Study and development of a high-power, high-voltage nanosecond puiser
Source title: IEEE Convention of Electrical and Electronics Engineers in Israel, Proceedings
Affiliations: Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne, 81800, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Abramzon, E., Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne, 81800, Israel; Yankelevich, Y., Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne, 81800, Israel; Pokryvailo, A., Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne, 81800, Israel
Abstract: Energy compression techniques are analyzed. A most advanced method is a combination of magnetic and fast semiconductor switching. An equivalent circuit of an inductive storage Semiconductor Opening Switch (SOS)-based puiser [1] was developed and analyzed using a PSpice platform. It comprised a number of non-linear elements representing all-solid state switches and saturation inductors and transformers. An extensive experimental study of the described technique was performed using an SM-4N SOS-pulser yielding 50MW 20ns pulses. Electrical diagnostics means for monitoring nanosecond HV pulses was developed. It comprised specialty capacitive dividers, current shunts and transformers and Rogowski coils. The puiser was characterized both with an ohmic and gas discharge load. It was found that simulation and test results are in a fair agreement for a resistive load. The simulation model will be used for design of a high-power puiser intended for driving a pulsed corona discharge [3], [4].

Authors: Sato T., Arita I.
Title: Simplifying instruction issue logic in superscalar processors
Source title: Proceedings - Euromicro Symposium on Digital System Design: Architectures, Methods and Tools, DSD 2002
Affiliations: Department of Artificial Intelligence, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Japan; Centre for Microelectronic System, Kyushu Institute of Technology, 680-4 Kawazu, Lizuka, 820-8502, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, T., Department of Artificial Intelligence, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Japan, Centre for Microelectronic System, Kyushu Institute of Technology, 680-4 Kawazu, Lizuka, 820-8502, Japan; Arita, I., Department of Artificial Intelligence, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Japan
Abstract: Modern microprocessors schedule instructions dynamically in order to exploit instruction-level parallelism. It is necessary to increase instruction window size for improving instruction scheduling capability. However, it is difficult to increase the size without any serious impact on processor performance, since the instruction window is one of the dominant determiners of processor cycle time. The instruction window is critical because it is realized using content addressable memory (CAM). In general, RAMs are faster in access time and lower in power dissipation than CAMs. Therefore, it is desirable that the CAM instruction window is replaced by the RAM instruction window. This paper proposes such an instruction window, named the explicit data forwarding instruction window. The principle behind our proposal is to make result forwarding explicit. It is possible to dynamically construct explicit relationships between instructions, since it is expected that each execution result is forwarded to a limited number of dependent instructions. Simulation results show that the explicit data forwarding instruction window achieves a level of performance comparable to that of the conventional instruction window, while also providing benefit in terms of shorter cycle time. © 2002 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Associative memory; CADCAM; Computer aided manufacturing; Dynamic scheduling; Logic; Microprocessors; Power dissipation; Processor scheduling; Proposals; Read-write memory

Authors: Rullmann M., Bougard B., Brockineyer E., Giulietti A., Catthoor E.
Title: Power efficient architecture for high speed decoding of block turbo-codes with the Fang-Buda algorithm
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Systems, SiPS: Design and Implementation
Affiliations: IMEC, Leuven, Belgium; KUL/ESAT, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Rullmann, M., IMEC, Leuven, Belgium; Bougard, B., IMEC, Leuven, Belgium; Brockineyer, E., IMEC, Leuven, Belgium; Giulietti, A., IMEC, Leuven, Belgium; Catthoor, E., KUL/ESAT, Belgium
Abstract: Turbo-codes have become an attractive forward error correction scheme as well for wired as for wireless communication systems. They achieve quasi-optimal coding gain, enabling reliable transmission on very noisy channels. Among the different existing turbo-coding schemes, Block Turbo-Codes (BTC) present excellent performances when their constitutive codes are decoded with the Fang-Buda Algorithm (FBA). Their bit error rate (BER) performance does not present any significant error floor down to 10-9. However, the complexity of the FBA is such that currently available block turbo-decoders, even if they achieve throughput up to 155 Mbps, can only handle very simple codes, which do not reveal totally the power of BTC. In order to enable high performing BTC without sacrificing throughput or energy, we have systematically analyzed and optimized the FBA algorithm, applying a Data Transfer and Storage Exploration methodology. We describe in this paper the algorithm transformation steps and detail the resulting architecture. The latter, when mapped in a typical 0.18 μm CMOS technology and clocked at 200 MHz enables high performing block turbo-decoding with throughput ranging from 30 Mbps to 120 Mbps. The memory power consumption, which is dominant for such a data-dominated application, has been estimated to be 480 mW while the memory area estimation led to 3.5 mm2 per FBA module in the BTC pipeline. © 2002 IEEE.
