Authors: Chang Y.-J., Lai F.
Title: Paged cache: An efficient partition architecture for reducing power, area and access time
Source title: IEEE Asia-Pacific Conference on Circuits and Systems, Proceedings, APCCAS
Affiliations: Dept. of CSIE, National Taiwan University, No. 1, Sec. 4, Roosevelt Road, Taipei, Taiwan; Dept. of CSIE and EE, National Taiwan University, No. 1, Sec. 4, Roosevelt Road, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chang, Y.-J., Dept. of CSIE, National Taiwan University, No. 1, Sec. 4, Roosevelt Road, Taipei, Taiwan; Lai, F., Dept. of CSIE and EE, National Taiwan University, No. 1, Sec. 4, Roosevelt Road, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: Power consumption is an increasingly pressing problem in high performance processors, and the caches usually consume a significant amount of power. This paper presents a new cache partition architecture, called paged cache, which is beneficial for area, power and performance. In paged cache, we divide the entire cache into a set of partitions, and each partition is dedicated to only one page cached in the TLB (translation lookaside buffer). By restricting the range in which the cached block can be placed, we can eliminate the total or partial tag depending on the partition size. Furthermore, by accessing only a single partition, instead of accessing the entire cache, both the power consumption per cache access and the average access time can be reduced largely. We use SimpleScalar to simulate the SPEC2000 benchmarks and perform the HSPICE simulations (with 0.18 μm technology and 1.8 V voltage supply) to evaluate the proposed architecture. Experimental results show that the paged cache is very efficient in reducing both power consumption and tag area of the on-chip L1 caches, while the average access time of cache can be improved. © 2002 IEEE.

Authors: Eggers H.
Title: DRAM and NVM product visions
Source title: International Symposium on Plasma Process-Induced Damage, P2ID, Proceedings
Affiliations: Memory Products Division, Infineon Technologies AG, Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Eggers, H., Memory Products Division, Infineon Technologies AG, Munich, Germany
Abstract: As one of the major driving forces in the area of Si integrated circuits, memories (i.e. DRAM, SRAM & nonvolatile memories) have always been far less specialized in respect to their application areas than most logic circuits. Since they are commodity products, they can be found in different applications, as diverse as high-speed networking systems and standard entertainment products. Looking further out into the future, we can currently see three major trends in all of the three above-mentioned areas of memories. © 2002 American Vacuum Soc.

Authors: Koshkouei A.J., Zinober A.S.I.
Title: Adaptive feedback passivity of a class of nonlinear systems
Affiliations: Department of Applied Mathematics, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, S10 2TN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Koshkouei, A.J., Department of Applied Mathematics, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, S10 2TN, United Kingdom; Zinober, A.S.I., Department of Applied Mathematics, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, S10 2TN, United Kingdom
Abstract: Passivity is the property stating that any storage energy in a system is not larger than the energy supplied to it from external sources. This paper considers adaptive feedback passivation for a class of nonlinear systems. A nonlinear system with unknown constant parameters is transformed via feedback into a new system. An appropriate update law is designed so that the new transformed system is passive. In fact the system is passive via feedback if the unknown parameters are replaced with their suitable estimates. Authors: Khan K.H., Rasul M.G., Khan M.M.K.
Title: Building energy management: Co-generation coupling with thermal energy storage
Source title: ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, Proceedings
Affiliations: School of Advanced Technologies and Processes, Faculty of Engineering and Physical Systems, Central Queensland University, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia; Mayekawa Australia Pty Ltd., 2/44 McCouley Street, Matraville, NSW 2036, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Khan, K.H., Mayekawa Australia Pty Ltd., 2/44 McCouley Street, Matraville, NSW 2036, Australia; Rasul, M.G., School of Advanced Technologies and Processes, Faculty of Engineering and Physical Systems, Central Queensland University, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia; Khan, M.M.K., School of Advanced Technologies and Processes, Faculty of Engineering and Physical Systems, Central Queensland University, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia
Abstract: This paper is concerned with the feasibility study and evaluation of an energy savings opportunity in buildings energy management using co-generation coupling with thermal energy storage. Both the technical and economical feasibility is presented first for the co-generation and then compared with the co-generation using thermal energy storage. On-site co-generation with double effect absorption chiller provides a potential of at least 13% peak demand reduction and about 16% savings in energy consumption. It provides an internal rate of return (IRR) greater than 21% but saving potential is limited by the low demand of co-generated chilled water within the community of the institution. Thermal energy storage coupling with co-generation offers a simple and economically more attractive approach for maximizing the utilization of co-generated chilled water and shows 23% reduction in peak demand and 21% savings in energy consumption. It provides higher IRR, greater than 25%. Copyright © 2002 by ASME.

Authors: Kim I.W., Lee D.S., Kim J.S., Kim Y.H., Choi B.C., Jeong J.H., Yi S.S., Kim Y.S.
Title: Thermally activated low frequency dielectric dispersion of antiferro-electric Pb1.075la0.025Zr0.95Ti 0.05O3 thin film
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Ulsan, Ulsan 680-749, South Korea; Department of Physics, Pukyong National Univ., Busan 608-737, South Korea; Department of Photonics, Silla University, Busan 617-736, South Korea; School of Mechanical Engineering, Pukyong National Univ., Busan 608-737, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, I.W., Department of Physics, University of Ulsan, Ulsan 680-749, South Korea; Lee, D.S., Department of Physics, University of Ulsan, Ulsan 680-749, South Korea; Kim, J.S., Department of Physics, University of Ulsan, Ulsan 680-749, South Korea; Kim, Y.H., Department of Physics, Pukyong National Univ., Busan 608-737, South Korea; Choi, B.C., Department of Physics, Pukyong National Univ., Busan 608-737, South Korea; Jeong, J.H., Department of Physics, Pukyong National Univ., Busan 608-737, South Korea; Yi, S.S., Department of Photonics, Silla University, Busan 617-736, South Korea; Kim, Y.S., School of Mechanical Engineering, Pukyong National Univ., Busan 608-737, South Korea
Abstract: Antiferroelectric Pb1.075La0.025Zr 0.95Ti0.05O3 (PLZT) thin films on Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate have been fabricated by pulsed laser deposition technique. The temperature dependent dielectric constant and polarization-electric field (P-E) hysteresis loops of PLZT film demonstrate the phase transition from antiferroelectric to ferroelectric. The Curie temperature (Tc) and dielectric constant at Tc are 196°C and 2065, respectively. The maximum saturated polarization reaches nearly 50 μC/cm2, corresponding to a maximum induced charge of 12.5 nC The complex dielectric constants and ac conductivities of PLZT thin film are measured as a function of frequency (0.01Hz-1 MHz) and temperature (25-200°C) in order to investigate dielectric dispersions and conduction mechanisms. We also observe the strong low-frequency dielectric dispersion at high temperature above 125°C due to the migration of thermally activated oxygen vacancies. The estimated activation energy for conduction is 0.76 eV. The conduction mechanism seems more complicated than simple hopping model. Consequently, understanding of oxygen vacancy transfer in the antiferroelectric PLZT thin film is important for practical applications in high charge storage and actuator devices. © 2002 Taylor & Francis.

Authors: Whalen J.
Title: Energy efficient materials handling
Authors with affiliations: Whalen, J.
Abstract: Design enhancements of motors used in today's materials handling equipment enabled the units to achieve greater energy utilization while performing in a wider variety of applications. The electric motors account for 60% to 64% of an industrial company's electric bill on a yearly basis. The use of sensors and soft start capabilities were recommended for maximizing energy efficiency of materials handling equipment. It is stated that the softwares are also available to perform energy surveys for customers if needed.
Index Keywords: Conveyors; Costs; Electric motors; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Materials handling equipment; Warehouses; Automated storage systems; Motor loads; Servo motors; Shunt-wound motors; Materials handling

Authors: Forcales M., Bradley I.V., Wells J.-P.R., Gregorkiewicz T.
Title: Temporal characteristics of the optical storage effect in Si:Er
Affiliations: Van der Waals-Zeeman Institute, University of Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, NL-1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Forcales, M., Van der Waals-Zeeman Institute, University of Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, NL-1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands; Bradley, I.V., Van der Waals-Zeeman Institute, University of Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, NL-1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands; Wells, J.-P.R., Van der Waals-Zeeman Institute, University of Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, NL-1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands; Gregorkiewicz, T., Van der Waals-Zeeman Institute, University of Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, NL-1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: A detailed investigation into mid-infrared (MIR) emission enhancement of Er3+ embedded in silicon has been made using MIR pulses from a free electron laser. Based on time-resolved photoluminescence (PL) measurements, the enhancement effect has been linked to a slowly decaying component commonly appearing in the kinetics of the Si:Er PL signal. A model has been developed where the intensity enhancement is ascribed to the MIR-induced energy transfer from shallow traps to Er3+ ions. Taking into account saturation of the optically active erbium centers, the model can successfully describe the amplitude of the enhancement effect and its dependence on delay time of the MIR pulse with respect to the primary excitation in the visible pump pulse. The experimentally observed decrease of the enhancement effect at higher temperatures is ascribed to thermal ionization of nonequilibrium traps.
Author Keywords: Erbium; Free-electron laser; Photoluminescence; Silicon
Index Keywords: Electron traps; Erbium; Free electron lasers; Infrared radiation; Ionization; Laser pulses; Photoluminescence; Positive ions; Enhancement effect; Midinfrared emission enhancement; Midinfrared pulses; Optical storage effect; Thermal ionization; Semiconducting silicon

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: High energy: A milestone RE project in California
Abstract: University of California's White Mountain Research Station (WMRS) is planning to derive all of its energy needs from a hybrid renewable energy (RE) system. The RE system combines renewable sources with hydrogen production, storage and backup power, and is expected to be the first sizeable stand-alone installation of its kind in the world. The plan is to install a medium-size wind turbine and a photovoltaic array with similar capacity. Surplus electricity will electrolyze water, and the resulting hydrogen will be compressed, stored and used to generate power at peak times and when the wind is not blowing or sun not shining.

Affiliations: ISET e.V., Germany; ISET e.V., University Kassel, Königstor 59, D-34119 Kassel, Germany; SMA Regelsysteme GmbH, Hannoversche Str. 1-5, D-34266 Niestetal, Germany; PPC- Island Direction, 112 Sygrou Ave, 11741 Athens, Greece

Abstract: The Greek Island of Kythnos, has been running hybrid systems for the past 20 years. Recently, a project was finalized, which included addition of a 500 kW wind energy converter and large battery storage system for electricity supply in the island. A special challenge in the Kythnos project was the integration of a wind energy converter with a capacity of 500 kW into an island grid where often during the winter consumer power is only 300 kW. Intelligent power systems were used to control diesel power stations in combination with battery storage and wind energy converters. Combined with a 12-pulse battery converter the plant can provide power of more than 500 kW for short period of time.

Abstract: Computing and communications will change drastically over the next few years with the rapid advances being made in underlying technologies, such as wireless, portable power, memory storage and processing. Everyday objects will be 'connected' and intelligent as computing and communication technologies break out from their traditional moulds and become more pervasive. This article begins with a vision of the future and then goes on to outline some of the supporting technologies that may be used to bring it to reality.

Title: Interconnect Exploration for Future Wire Dominated Technologies
Source title: International Workshop on System Level Interconnect Prediction

Abstract: Storage "takes the centre stage" [4] in more and more information oriented systems because of the eternal push for more complex applications with especially larger and more complicated data types. In addition, the access speed, size and power consumption associated with this storage form a severe bottle-neck in these systems (especially in an embedded context). In this invited paper, we want to explore the interconnect related issues, both inside the storage components (intra-memory) and between the components (inter-memory). To achieve this we have performed several experiments with a storage organisation exploration tool set that has been applied to a real-life application from our target domain, namely a Digital Audio Broadcast (DAB) receiver. Several interesting conclusions can be based on these experiments and these will be briefly summarised below.

Lenina 2a, Tomsk 634050, Russian Federation
Abstract: The resonant compressor of microwave pulses contains an overmoded cavity with an overmoded output waveguide. The commutator is a bandpass filter formed of a chain of transmission-type (reentrant) cavities. The basic results of the experiments carried out at low and high power levels and a block diagram of the experimental setup are presented. The compressor has the following performance characteristics: (1) an operating radio frequency of 9.16 GHz, (2) a power gain of 16.3 dB, and (3) the duration of the output pulses is 2 ns. The latter figure ensures the minimum energy output time.

Authors: Chebeskov A.N., Oussanov V.I., Iougai S.V., Zavadsky M.I.

Abstract: Results of system analysis of the plutonium utilization alternatives carried out in Russia were presented. The multi-attribute utility (MAU) model was employed as the methodology for the analysis. The study showed that effective application of a quantitative model to the problem of plutonium utilization was possible provided that political and technical objectives were strictly defined.

Abstract: Development of testing laboratory for checking radioactive waste packages in the Czech republic was discussed. The development of main methodologies leading to the establishment of the laboratory was described. The methodologies developed in the laboratory were divided into three groups as radiological, short-term properties and long-term durability properties. A planned quality assurance (QA) system of the laboratory was also described.

Title: Strategy of management of the radioactive waste for an emerging country and international co-operation: Example of Tunisia
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM

Abstract: A strategy is proposed for the management of the radioactive waste for Tunisia taking account of the means of the country and the essential contribution of the co-operation. The strategy articulates on the definition of the proposed objectives and principles, the inventory of the radioactive waste and the planning of the formation. Long-term objectives such as the type of waste evacuation and safety level, choice of incineration for waste and moderate compaction of low activity and compressible waste are also proposed.

Authors: Turpin J.R.
Title: Thermal storage and perpetual savings
Authors with affiliations: Turpin, J.R.
Abstract: An overview on hospitals looking to thermal energy storage (TES) technology to reduce operating costs was presented. The TES technology helped hospitals to save significant amount of money in their utility costs. A study showed that a TES system could provide the necessary cooling for the additional square footage for about the same price as building a separate standalone plant.
Index Keywords: Costs; Electric load management; Energy utilization; Hospitals; Thermal effects; Thermal energy storage (TES); Energy storage

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: US collaboration on Brazilian fuel cell projects
Abstract: The Houston Advanced Research Center in Texas has signed a cooperative agreement with the Instituto de Tecnologia para o Desenvolvimento in Curitiba to develop projects in energy and the environment, with emphasis on promoting fuel cells for power generation and energy storage in Brazil. The institutes will collaborate on demonstration projects that use fuel cells to provide electricity in remote areas of northern Brazil, where people too often must use inefficient and polluting diesel oil generators to meet their energy needs.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: VW, PSI test hydrogen fuel-cell car
Abstract: Volkswagen (VW) has completed the first long-range test drive of its latest fuel cell car, based on its middle-size Bora saloon. In the middle of January 2002, the HyPower vehicle was driven over the demanding 6578 ft high Simplon Pass connecting Switzerland and Italy. The aim is to tune the fuel cell driveline so that its performance and road behavior matched a standard production Bora. VW, together with the Paul Scherrer Institute, has developed a low-cost hydrogen fuel cell with two high-performance supercaps or ultracapacitors, which can store a fuel cell's electrical energy for use during strenuous driving, such as uphill overtaking. The ultracapacitors eliminate the need for heavy energy storage batteries. These electrical energy storage devices can be used to supply the traction motor with up to an additional 30 kwe for short periods. VW also successfully tested a Bora Turbo Direct Injection diesel using a super-clean synthetic diesel called SunFuel®, which is a new low-sulfur that can be made from renewable sources such as plants, waste products, etc.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Collaboration to develop hydrogen storage with metal hydride alloys
Abstract: Japan Metals & Chemicals Co (JMC) and Air Products & Chemicals have agreed to pursue a joint development program for hydrogen storage systems that utilize metal hydride alloys, for fuel cell markets. This is an important step in facilitating development of a viable hydrogen infrastructure for the emerging hydrogen-based economy. Metal hydride alloys can absorb and store hydrogen at moderate pressures near room temperature. This stored hydrogen may be released as required to provide power for various fuel cell applications. Storage of hydrogen moderate pressure and ambient temperature is more energy-efficient and cost-effective for such applications than the present very high pressure or cryogenic techniques for storing hydrogen. JMC's research programs have developed metal hydride hydrogen storage systems for portable, stationary, and automotive applications, and a demonstration hydrogen fueling station in Japan.
Index Keywords: JAPAN METALS & CHEMICALS CO

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proton, Ford to jointly develop H2 fueling
Abstract: Ford's Th!nk Group agreed with Proton Energy Systems for a joint test and evaluation program to provide Ford with a fully qualified solution to support early deployment of hydrogen vehicles. Proton will deliver a FuelGen ™ high-pressure hydrogen refueling system to Th!nk, which will be used to provide fuel for Ford's hydrogen-fueled fuel cell and internal combustion vehicles. Proton's FuelGen system is a compact, on-site hydrogen supply system that includes generation, storage, and fast-fill dispensing of hydrogen at automobile storage pressures ≤ 5000 psi.

Authors: Prosini P.P., Carewska M., Lisi M., Passerini S., Scaccia S., Pasquali M.
Title: Energy storage materials based on iron phosphate
Affiliations: ENEA, C.R. Casaccia., Via Anguillarese 301, 00060 Roma, Italy; Dipartimento ICMMPM, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Univ. di Roma La Sapienza, Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Prosini, P.P., ENEA, C.R. Casaccia., Via Anguillarese 301, 00060 Roma, Italy; Carewska, M., ENEA, C.R. Casaccia., Via Anguillarese 301, 00060 Roma, Italy; Lisi, M., ENEA, C.R. Casaccia., Via Anguillarese 301, 00060 Roma, Italy; Passerini, S., ENEA, C.R. Casaccia., Via Anguillarese 301, 00060 Roma, Italy; Scaccia, S., ENEA, C.R. Casaccia., Via Anguillarese 301, 00060 Roma, Italy; Pasquali, M., ENEA, C.R. Casaccia., Via Anguillarese 301, 00060 Roma, Italy, Dipartimento ICMMPM, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Univ. di Roma La Sapienza, Roma, Italy
Abstract: Several iron phosphates were synthesized by solution-based techniques and tested as cathodes in non aqueous lithium cells. The addition of phosphate ions to a solution of iron (II) produced crystalline Fe3(PO4)2. This material is easily oxidized by air to form an amorphous phase that is able to reversibly intercalate lithium. The amorphous compound was identified to be a mixture of FePO4 and Fe2O3. A new synthetic route was developed to prepare pure amorphous FePO4. Amorphous LiFePO4 was obtained by chemical lithiation of FePO4. The material was heated at 500°C under reducing atmosphere to obtain nano-crystalline LiFePO4. This latter material showed excellent electrochemical performance when used as cathode of lithium cells.
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Intercalation compounds; Iron compounds; Lithium batteries; Mixtures; Nanostructured materials; Oxidation; Thermal effects; Chemical lithiation; Electric energy storage

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Palcan in integrated fuel cell/solar project, MEA funding
Abstract: Palcan Fuel Cells has been selected to supply the fuel cell power module and overall control system for a joint development project with Goodings Environmental Inc, to be funded by the federal Western Diversification Program through Fuel Cells Canada. The Western Diversification Program project is to design and demonstrate a grid-independent regenerative power system, integrating a photovoltaic (PV) collection array, electrolyzer, hydrogen storage, Palcan's PalPac™ fuel cell power system, and power and control electronics. Palcan's system will be based on its newest water-cooled stack and standard 2 kwe PalPac power module. The integration of renewable energies such as PV and wind power with a fuel cell-based system offers an independent, emission-free power system for small homes or commercial applications.

Authors: Stanner S.
Title: The 'third-helping' hormone
Affiliations: British Nutrition Foundation, 52-54 High Holborn, London WC1V 6RQ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stanner, S., British Nutrition Foundation, 52-54 High Holborn, London WC1V 6RQ, United Kingdom
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Composites and energy
Abstract: This is a comprehensive review of the use of composites in the energy generation and energy using industries. A list of the properties (related to the energy industry) of composites is given on page 17 and includes electrical insulation, fire resistance and transparency to electromagnetic waves. Composite usage in the automotive industry covers their use in engines and the vehicles of tomorrow. In aeronautics use of composites in engines, piping and composite structural elements is aired. A huge usage in electronics components is in printed circuit boards, while large diameter underground steel piping is now protected by composite inserts, isolating them from the often corrosive chemicals that the pipes convey. Composites now make appearances in oil pipelines, the generation of energy using wind turbines whose blades are all composite. Other uses are found in air-conditioning, high voltage and low voltage electricity components, and treatment and storage solutions.
Index Keywords: composite; end use; energy

Authors: Beck L., Habs D., Reiter P., Thirolf P., Sieber T., Bongers H., Emhofer S., Maier H.J.
Title: MAFF - The Munich accelerator for fission fragments
Affiliations: Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany; CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Beck, L., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland; Habs, D., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland; Reiter, P., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland; Thirolf, P., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland; Sieber, T., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland; Bongers, H., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland; Emhofer, S., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland; Maier, H.J., Ludwig-Maximilians-Univ. Munchen, Garching, Germany, CERN, Geneva, Genf, Switzerland
Abstract: At the new high flux reactor FRM-II in Munich the accelerator MAFF (Munich accelerator for fission fragments) is under design. In the high neutron flux of 1014 n/cm2 s up to 1014 neutron-rich fission fragments per second are produced in the 1 g U-235 target. Ions with an energy of 30 kev are extracted from the ion source. In the mass seperator two isotopes can be selected. One of the beams is used for low energy experiments, the other one is injected into an ECRIS (or EBIS) for charge breeding to a q/A ≥ 0.16. A gas filled RFQ cooler is used for emittance improvement. The subsequent LINAC delivers beams with an energy ranging from 3.7 MeV/u to 5.9 MeV/u. New IH structures are being developed at the Munich tandem laboratory. A small storage ring is planned in a further stage to recycle the fission fragments. A thin target foil can be placed into this ring, e.g., for synthesis of super-heavy elements. The through-going beam tube has been installed in the heavy water tank of the reactor. Tests of the target ion source in a special oven to test long term stability and safety tests were in progress.
Author Keywords: Beam transport; Ion sources; Linear accelerator; Particle sources and targets; Research reactors
Index Keywords: High energy physics; Ion bombardment; Isotopes; Laboratories; Linear accelerators; Radioactivity; Research reactors; Stability; Radioactive ion beams (RIB); Ion beams

Authors: Keeping S.
Title: Memory in a spin
Authors with affiliations: Keeping, S.
Abstract: The developments in the non-volatile random access memory (RAM) devices which comes under two categories namely ferroelectric RAM (FRAM) and magnetoresistive RAM (MRAM) are discussed. FRAM and MRAM rely on the manipulation of individual atoms by using applied electric fields within the atomic crystal lattices for FRAM and and magnetic strips to control electricity flow through a lattice for MRAM. MRAM uses miniscule magnets to store binary data which decreases the power consumption.
Index Keywords: Atomic physics; Crystal lattices; Data acquisition; Electric field effects; Energy utilization; Ferroelectric devices; Magnetoresistance; Magnets; Miniscule magnets; Random access storage

Authors: Schimmoller B.K.
Title: Flexibility of emerging energy storage technologies offers commercial promise
Authors with affiliations: Schimmoller, B.K.
Abstract: Since power generation and power consumption are inseparable partners in a never-ending dance to balance supply with load, designing an effective real-time market is exceedingly complex. However, a number of energy storage technologies are building commercial momentum, angling to cut in on the supply/load dance and facilitate market operation. As such, the Energy Storage Council recently released a white paper outlining the case for energy storage. The white paper states that energy storage will create a far more responsive market by supplying power where and when needed, listing seven benefits.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power distribution; Electric power systems; Marketing; Reliability; Power consumption; Power quality; Electric power generation

Authors: Kimura H., Hanyu T., Kameyama M.
Title: Implementation of a DRAM-cell-based multiple-valued logic-in-memory circuit
Affiliations: Dept. of Comp./Mathematical Sciences, Grad. School of Information Sciences, Tohoku University, Sendai-shi 980-8579, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kimura, H., Dept. of Comp./Mathematical Sciences, Grad. School of Information Sciences, Tohoku University, Sendai-shi 980-8579, Japan; Hanyu, T., Dept. of Comp./Mathematical Sciences, Grad. School of Information Sciences, Tohoku University, Sendai-shi 980-8579, Japan; Kameyama, M., Dept. of Comp./Mathematical Sciences, Grad. School of Information Sciences, Tohoku University, Sendai-shi 980-8579, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a multiple-valued logic-in-memory circuit with real-time programmability. The basic component, in which a dynamic storage function and a multiple-valued threshold function are merged, is implemented compactly by using charge storage and capacitive coupling with a DRAM-cell-based circuit structure under a 0.8-μm CMOS technology. The pass-transistor network using these basic components makes it possible to realize any multiple-valued-inputs binary-outputs logic circuits compactly. As a typical example, a fully parallel multiple-valued magnitude comparator is also implemented by using the proposed DRAM-cell-based pass-transistor network. Its execution time and power dissipation are reduced to about 11 percent and 29 percent, respectively, in comparison with those of a corresponding binary implementation. A prototype chip is also fabricated to confirm the basic operation of the proposed DRAM-cell-based logic-in-memory circuit.
Author Keywords: Content-addressable memory; Functional pass-gate; Interconnection problem; Multiple-valued logic; Pass-transistor network
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Energy dissipation; Logic circuits; Real time systems; Multiple-valued logic-in-Memory circuit; Dynamic random access storage

Authors: Liu B., Man Y.-J., Zhang W., Ma Y.-S.
Title: Visualization of tribologically induced energy disturbance to the stability of high density magnetic recording
Affiliations: Data Storage Institute, 5 Engineer Drive 1, Singapore 117 608, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Liu, B., Data Storage Institute, 5 Engineer Drive 1, Singapore 117 608, Singapore; Man, Y.-J., Data Storage Institute, 5 Engineer Drive 1, Singapore 117 608, Singapore; Zhang, W., Data Storage Institute, 5 Engineer Drive 1, Singapore 117 608, Singapore; Ma, Y.-S., Data Storage Institute, 5 Engineer Drive 1, Singapore 117 608, Singapore
Abstract: As technology moves to 600-1000Gb/sq-in areal densities and deep sub-10nm head-disk spacing, it is of crucial importance to prevent both the conventionally defined thermal decay and the tribologically induced decay of recorded magnetic signal. This paper reports a novel method for recording and visualizing the signature of the potential tribological decay. The details of the methodology, its working principles, and typical results obtained are presented in this work. The method is based on the introduction of a type of visualizing disks which use a layer of magneto-optical material with low Curie temperature to replace the magnetic layer used in the conventional magnetic media. The method and corresponding setup were used successfully in the visualization of potential decay caused by slider-particle-disk contact, slider-disk contact during track seeking operations, and slider-disk impact during loading and unloading operations.
Author Keywords: High density magnetic recording; Magnetic disk drives; Thermal decay; Tribology
Index Keywords: Magnetic disk storage; Magnetooptical devices; Tribology; Magnetic disk drives; Magnetic recording

Authors: Papusoi C., Suzuki T.
Title: Thermal stability and magnetic anisotropy dispersion in high-density hard-disk media
Source title: Zeitschrift fuer Metallkunde/Materials Research and Advanced Techniques
Affiliations: Information Storage Materials Lab., Toyota Technological Institute, 2-12-1 Hisakata, Tempaku-ku, Nagoya, 468-8511, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Papusoi, C., Information Storage Materials Lab., Toyota Technological Institute, 2-12-1 Hisakata, Tempaku-ku, Nagoya, 468-8511, Japan; Suzuki, T., Information Storage Materials Lab., Toyota Technological Institute, 2-12-1 Hisakata, Tempaku-ku, Nagoya, 468-8511, Japan
Abstract: A method to correct the anisotropy field distribution for granular recording media, measured by switching methods (isothermal remanent magnetization (IRM) and direct-current demagnetisation (DCD) processes were used as an example) for the effects of thermal relaxation, that supposes an a priori knowledge of the grain size distribution, is presented. For a hard-disk medium, it is shown that the anisotropy field distribution is much narrower (about one order of magnitude) with respect to the grain size distribution. The anisotropy field value estimated from the dependence of the remanence coercivity on the field application time is found in agreement (to within less than 10%) with the most probable value of the anisotropy field distribution.
Author Keywords: Anisotropy field; Grain interactions; Magnetic recording media; Thermal relaxation
Index Keywords: Coercive force; Free energy; Grain size and shape; Hard disk storage; Magnetic anisotropy; Magnetic moments; Magnetization; Remanence; Signal to noise ratio; Thermodynamic stability; Direct-current demagnetisation; Grain interactions; Isothermal remanent magnetization; Thermal relaxations; Magnetic recording

Authors: Johnson M.A.
Title: Local knowledge pays dividends for pump manufacturers in the Middle East
Affiliations: Bran + Luebbe Ltd, Ironstone Way, Brixworth, NN6 9UD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, M.A., Bran + Luebbe Ltd, Ironstone Way, Brixworth, NN6 9UD, United Kingdom
Abstract: The challenges posed to pump manufacturers by conditions in the Middle East are outlined. Pump applications in the oil fields of the United Arab Emirates are described. The absence of a reliable power supply together with the need to minimize energy costs in remote locations have influenced the development of Bran + Luebbe's KK metering pump. The pump can use solar energy as its power supply. The first solar-powered pumps were used on chemical injection packages for development projects in the United Arab Emirates. The Abu Dhabi Company for Onshore Oil Operations has used the technology for its corrosion control and monitoring programme in the north east of Abu Dhabi. Bran + Luebbe is supplying Saudi Aramco with corrosion inhibitor storage and injection units as part of the Khuff Development project.
Index Keywords: Corrosion inhibitors; Electric power systems; Injection (oil wells); Solar energy; Solar equipment; Solar-powered pumps; Oil well pumps; oil industry; pump manufacture; Solar power; Temperature

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Slaying the Kyoto Dragon
Abstract: A discussion on the comments made by Premier Ralph Klein and Energy Minister Murray Smith regarding Alberta, Canada's opposition on the federal government's proposed ratification of the Kyoto Protocol that might have serious implications for the Canadian economy covers the trade implications of Kyoto Protocol, i.e., the potential negative impact to the economy wherein over $8 billion and thousands of job losses/yr could cost Alberta; recent examples of Alberta pipeline companies; increasing world energy demand and new pipeline development; Alberta natural gas center and proposed northern gas pipelines; oilsands expansion of northeastern Alberta as a big driver of new pipeline development; Alberta's energy pipeline advantage; a made-in-Canada solution, Alberta's Plan for Action that could be developed into an effective national alternative to Kyoto; and management of CO2 emissions initiatives by developing a commercial market for CO2 in EOR, by supporting these projects by developing the provincial geoscience base for CO2 storage, and further reduction of the energy intensity of oilsands production and upgrading.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: SatCon power conditioners for FCE, Siemens Westinghouse
Abstract: SatCon Technology has delivered a StarSine™ Power Conditioning System (PCS) to FuelCell Energy to provide the electrical balance of plant for its Direct FuelCell® (DFC) MW-class fuel cell system. SatCon has also shipped a next generation StarSine 250 kw PCS to Siemens Westinghouse for use with Siemens' solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) systems. The StarSine system for FCE was manufactured using MegaVerter™ power blocks and advanced digital controls specifically designed for alternative energy applications, including fuel cells, solar photovoltaic arrays, microturbines, and wind turbines. The StarSine PCS is also designed to combine alternative energy generators with advanced energy storage devices, including advanced batteries and flywheels, to provide uninterruptible power supply systems.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Quantum H2 storage for wind-power refueling, improved H2 capacity
Abstract: Quantum Fuel Systems Technologies Worldwide has been awarded a contract to provide the hydrogen fuel storage system for a wind-generated hydrogen refueling station being developed for the South Coast Air Quality Management District. Quantum has also demonstrated a hydrogen storage tank with a 13% hydrogen weight efficiency, considerably improving on-board energy storage in aircraft and spacecraft applications where weight is critical. The project aims to provide wind-generated hydrogen to fuel vehicles from the California Fuel Cell Partnership and SunLine Transit Agency. This will be the first hydrogen fuel facility powered by wind energy.

Authors: Cao Y., Yasuura H.
Title: Memory organization for low-energy processor-based application-specific systems
Affiliations: Dept. of Comp. Sci. Commun. Eng., Kyushu University, Kasuga-shi, 816-8580, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Cao, Y., Dept. of Comp. Sci. Commun. Eng., Kyushu University, Kasuga-shi, 816-8580, Japan; Yasuura, H., Dept. of Comp. Sci. Commun. Eng., Kyushu University, Kasuga-shi, 816-8580, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a novel low-energy memory design technique based on variable analysis for on-chip data memory (RAM) in application-specific systems, which called VAbM technique. It targets the exploitation of both data locality and effective data width of variables to reduce energy consumed by data transfer and storage. Variables with higher access frequency and smaller effective data width are assigned into a smaller low-energy memory with fewer bit lines and word lines, placed closer the processor. Under constraints of the number of memory banks, VAbM technique use variable analysis results to perform allocating and assigning on-chip RAM into multiple banks, which have different size with different number of word lines and different number of bit lines tailored to each application requirements. Experimental results with several real embedded applications demonstrate significant energy reduction up to 64.8% over monolithic memory, and 27.7% compared to memory designed by memory banking technique.
Author Keywords: Application-specific system; Low energy; Memory organization; Variable analysis
Index Keywords: Algorithms; C (programming language); CMOS integrated circuits; Computational complexity; Computer aided design; Computer simulation; Data transfer; Static random access storage; Application-specific systems; Exhaustive-search algorithm; Memory organization; Software Package SPICE; Variable analysis; Microprocessor chips

Authors: Park Y.-H., Kook J., Yoo H.-J.
Title: Embedded DRAM (eDRAM) power-energy estimation using signal swing-based analytical model
Affiliations: Department of EE, KAIST, 373-1, Kusung-dong Yusong-gu, Taejon, 305-701, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, Y.-H., Department of EE, KAIST, 373-1, Kusung-dong Yusong-gu, Taejon, 305-701, South Korea; Kook, J., Department of EE, KAIST, 373-1, Kusung-dong Yusong-gu, Taejon, 305-701, South Korea; Yoo, H.-J., Department of EE, KAIST, 373-1, Kusung-dong Yusong-gu, Taejon, 305-701, South Korea
Abstract: Embedded-DRAM (eDRAM) power-energy estimation model is proposed for system-on-a-chip (SOC) applications. The main feature is the signal swing based analytic (SSBA) model, which improves the accuracy of the conventional SRAM power-energy models. The power-energy estimation using SSBA model shows 95% accuracy compared with the transistor level power simulation for three fabricated eDRAMs. The SSBA model combined with the high-level simulator provides fast and accurate system level power-energy estimation of eDRAM.
Author Keywords: eDRAM; Power estimation
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Estimation; Mathematical models; Power electronics; Semiconductor device manufacture; Spurious signal noise; Power energy estimation; System on a chip; Dynamic random access storage

Authors: Gago A.M., Guzzo M.M., Nunokawa H., Teves W.J.C., Zukanovich Funchal R.
Title: Future tests of non-standard neutrino interactions
Affiliations: Instituto de Física, Universidade de São Paulo, C.P. 66.318, 05315-970 São Paulo, Brazil; Instituto de Fisica Gleb Wataghin, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, 13083-970 Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Gago, A.M., Instituto de Física, Universidade de São Paulo, C.P. 66.318, 05315-970 São Paulo, Brazil; Guzzo, M.M., Instituto de Fisica Gleb Wataghin, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, 13083-970 Campinas, Brazil; Nunokawa, H., Instituto de Fisica Gleb Wataghin, Universidade Estadual de Campinas, 13083-970 Campinas, Brazil; Teves, W.J.C., Instituto de Física, Universidade de São Paulo, C.P. 66.318, 05315-970 São Paulo, Brazil; Zukanovich Funchal, R., Instituto de Física, Universidade de São Paulo, C.P. 66.318, 05315-970 São Paulo, Brazil
Abstract: We explore non-standard neutrino matter interactions, working as sub-leading effects in the standard mass oscillation framework. Both mechanisms working together, induce a magnifying fake CP violating effect in the presence of matter, which can be studied in a neutrino factory which is based on a muon storage ring. Considering the three neutrino scheme, assuming a 10 kt detector with 5 years of operation, a stored muon energy Eμ ≥ 20 GeV, 2 × 1020 muon decays per year, and a baseline L ∼ 732 km, we show that it is possible to test non-standard flavor changing neutrino interactions down to the level of (10-3 - 10-2) GF, in both vμ → ντ/̄nμ → ̄nτ and νe → ντ/̄ne → ̄nτ modes.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: International pipeline news: USA Dynegy sells pipeline company
Abstract: Dynegy agreed to sell Northern Natural Gas Co (NNG) to MidAmerican Energy Holdings Co for $928 million in cash, subject to adjustment for working capital changes. Under the agreement, MidAmerican Energy will acquire all of the common and preferred stock of NNG and will assume $950 million in outstanding NNG debt. NNG's 26,500 km miles of pipelines extend from the Permian Basin in Texas to the upper Midwest in the USA. Its storage capacity is 2.1 billion cu m, and its market area capacity is about 150 million cu m/day.
Index Keywords: DYNEGY; MIDAMERICAN ENERGY HOLDINGS CO.; NORTHERN NATURAL GAS CO

Authors: Salam A.I.A., Ahmad M.H.M., Sapuan S.M., Adam N.M.
Title: Techno-economical aspects of encapsulated ice thermal energy storage applications for air-conditioning system
Affiliations: Dept. of Mech. and Manufac. Eng., Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Salam, A.I.A., Dept. of Mech. and Manufac. Eng., Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia; Ahmad, M.H.M., Dept. of Mech. and Manufac. Eng., Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia; Sapuan, S.M., Dept. of Mech. and Manufac. Eng., Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia; Adam, N.M., Dept. of Mech. and Manufac. Eng., Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia
Abstract: Thermal Energy Storage (TES) for air-conditioning applications has grown significantly in Malaysia in recent years. For encapsulated ice method, the difference in the amount of ice supplied to supplement the chilled water generated during peak hours plays a major role in ascertaining the result of electricity bill savings and therefore, payback period. Based on actual implementation, a simple simulation program of TES integrated system is created to study its impact on the electricity bill savings, electricity consumption and power shift as compared to the conventional system. Varying the percentage of ice supply, application to cooling capacity of 1000 RT with and without base load, this study finds that electricity bills are saved with the penalty of higher energy consumption for chillers' efficiency of 0.8 and 1.1 input kW per refrigerant tonnage (ikW/RT), respectively. However, reduction in maximum demand of up to 30% is possible.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Electricity; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Electricity consumption; Encapsulated ice thermal energy storage; Electric energy storage

Authors: Ge S., Ying S., Mingjing T., Xuejian L., Sheng W., Wenhua L., HongWei L., Yongjun S.
Title: A surface analytical study on poisoning of LaNi4.7Al0.3 by CO
Affiliations: China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China
Authors with affiliations: Ge, S., China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China; Ying, S., China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China; Mingjing, T., China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China; Xuejian, L., China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China; Sheng, W., China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China; Wenhua, L., China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China; HongWei, L., China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China; Yongjun, S., China Academy of Engineering Physics, Box 919, Mianyang, Sichuan 621900, China
Abstract: In this paper, studies have been made concerning the poisoning mechanism. The processes of poisoning of LaNi47Al0.3 alloy are analyzed in detail by means of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), second ion mass spectroscopy (SIMS), Auger-energy spectroscopy (AES) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The changes of the valence and the concentration distribution of the elements of the alloy LaNi4.7Al0.3 poisoned by CO are studied. The process and the mechanism of CO's poisoning of alloy LaNi4.7Al0.3 are proposed as follows: CO is absorbed on the surface of alloy, part of which reacts with La forming LaC2 and La2O3, or reacts with Ni forming NiO and C in the surface layer, the rest of the CO is decomposed into C and O, which diffuse into the bulk to react with La, Ni and Al. These results in phase-split reaction in surface layer of the particle, and enrichment of La and impoverishment Ni on the surface have taken place. The poisoning effect decreases with a increase of depth. The diffusion depth of C is within 600 Å in the surface layer, and that of O is within 1000 Å. The oxide film and carbonizing film prevent the H-storage alloys from further absorbing hydrogen, which leads to a deceleration of the H-storage capability. Moreover, The formation of a new phase with poor H-absorption capability is caused by the phase split reactions, which is one of reasons for the decrease of H-absorption property of the H-storage alloys.
Author Keywords: Analysis; Contamination; Hydriding; Mechanism
Index Keywords: Absorption; Auger electron spectroscopy; Carbon monoxide; Contamination; Decomposition; Diffusion; Metallic films; Secondary ion mass spectrometry; Surfaces; X ray diffraction analysis; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Carbonizing films; Lanthanum compounds

Authors: Ying S.
Title: The progress of tritium science & technology in China
Affiliations: China Academy of Engineering Physics, P.O. Box 919, Mianyang 621900, China
Authors with affiliations: Ying, S., China Academy of Engineering Physics, P.O. Box 919, Mianyang 621900, China
Abstract: As the largest developing country, China is always paying a great attention to the research and development of energy resources. With a lot of efforts spent in developing the nuclear power (fission energy), China also puts much emphasis on the study of clean fusion energy. The progresses of research on the fabrication of solid breeders, preparation of hydrogen storage materials and its performances, the interaction between hydrogen and some materials recently in China have been introduced.
Index Keywords: Breeder reactors; Energy resources; Fission reactions; Fusion reactions; Hydrogen; Nuclear energy; Hydrogen storage materials; Solid breeders; Tritium

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: News from Central Asia: GAIL ties up with GdeF
Abstract: Gas Authority of India Ltd (GAIL) reached an agreement with Gaz de France to jointly implement projects related to LNG imports, oil and gas exploration and production, and construction of gas pipelines infrastructure in India. The agreement, part of the bilateral energy sector cooperation between India and France, also covers joint trading of natural gas and building underground gas storage facilities.
Index Keywords: GAS AUTHORITY OF INDIA LTD; GAZ DE FRANCE

Authors: Moshnyaga V.
Title: Adaptive bitwidth compression for low power video memory design
Source title: IEICE Transactions on Fundamentals of Electronics, Communications and Computer Sciences
Affiliations: Dept. of Electron. Eng. Comp. Sci., Fukuoka University, Fukuoka-shi, 814-0180, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Moshnyaga, V., Dept. of Electron. Eng. Comp. Sci., Fukuoka University, Fukuoka-shi, 814-0180, Japan
Abstract: Due to large capacitance, high access ratio and wide access bitwidth, frame memory is one of the most energy consuming devices in modern video encoders. This paper proposes a new architectural technique to reduce energy dissipation of frame memory through adaptive bitwidth compression. Unlike related approaches, the technique utilizes the fixed order of memory accesses and data correlation of video sequences, by dynamically adjusting the memory bitwidth to the number of bits changed per pixel. Instead of treating the data bits independently, we group the most significant bits together, activating the corresponding group of bit-lines adaptively to data variation. The approach is not restricted to the specific bit-patterns nor depends on the storage phase. It works equally well on read and write accesses, as well as during precharging. Simulations show that using this method we can reduce the total energy consumption of the frame memory cell array by 20% without affecting the picture quality. The implementation scheme is simple yet compact.
Author Keywords: Adaptive technique; Bit-compression; Low power; Video memory
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Energy dissipation; Energy utilization; Image coding; Image compression; Image quality; Adaptive bitwidth compression; Picture quality; Video encoders; Video memory; Video sequences; Data storage equipment

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Italy: Eni sets an Italian record
Abstract: Hydrocarbon deposits in Val d'Agri and the Sauro Valley are the most important energy resource discovered in Italy. A discussion covers Eni's investment in the Italian oil industry; Eni's commitment to economic development and environmental protection; partnerships and joint ventures with other companies, e.g., ExxonMobil and Enterprise Oil; the Monte Alpi Oil Center expansion work and Monte Alpi-Taranto pipeline, which will transport Val d'Agri production from the Vigiano Oil Center to the Taranto refinery; and development activities that include the cosntruction of a 7-km pipeline from the Center to link with the Taranto pipeline and a storage deposit for LPG produced together with oil and methane.
Index Keywords: ENTERPRISE OIL

Authors: Austen M.
Title: Moulding technology for voice coil motor magnets
Authors with affiliations: Austen, M.
Abstract: Molded magnets are used in personal computers. The conventional process for developing such parts is labor-intensive and wasteful in terms of material and energy utilization. A new MIM process method provides an economic, simple, zero-waste and environmentally clean alternative to mass-produce the VCMs.
Index Keywords: Binders; Density (specific gravity); Forming; Hard disk storage; Ingots; Injection molding; Machining; Magnetization; Marketing; Neodymium alloys; Powder metallurgy; Sintering; Green compounds; Ingot sintering; Metal injection molding; Neo magnets; Powder pressing; Structural disk drive components; Voice coil motors; Permanent magnets

Authors: Enomoto T.
Title: Designs of building blocks for high-speed, low-power processors
Affiliations: Chuo University, Tokyo 112-8551, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Enomoto, T., Chuo University, Tokyo 112-8551, Japan
Abstract: A fast, low-power 16-bit adder, 32-word register file and 512-bit cache SRAM have been developed using 0.25-μm GaAs HEMT technology for future multi-GHz processors. The 16-bit adder, which uses a negative logic binary look-ahead carry structure based on NOR gates, operates at the maximum clock frequency of 1.67 GHz and consumes 134.4 mW at a supply voltage of 0.6 V. The active area is 1.6 mm2 and there are about 1,230 FETs. A new DC/DC level converter has been developed for use in high-speed, low-power storage circuits such as SRAMs and register files. The level converter can increase the DC voltage, which is supplied to an active-load circuit on request, or supply a minimal DC voltage to a load circuit in the stand-by mode. The power dissipation (P) of the 32-word register file with on-chip DC/DC level converters is 459 mW, a reduction to 25.2% of that of an equivalent conventional register file, while the operating frequency (fc) was 5.17 GHz that is 74.8% of fc for the conventional register file. P for the 512-bit cache SRAM with the new DC/DC level converters is 34.3 mW, 89.7% of the value for au equivalent conventional cache SRAM, with the read-access time of 455 psec, only 1.1% longer than that of the conventional cache SRAM.

Title: Omitting cache look-up for high-performance, low-power microprocessors
Affiliations: Department of Electonics and Computer Science, Fukuoka University, Japan; Department of Informatics, Kyushu University, Japan

Abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel architecture for low-power direct-mapped instruction caches, called "history-based tag-comparison (HBTC) cache". The cache attempts to reuse tag-comparison results for avoiding unnecessary tag checks. Execution footprints are recorded into an extended BTB (Branch Target Buffer). In our evaluation, it is observed that the energy for tag comparison can be reduced by more than 90% in many applications.

Title: Going green: Five steps to get you there
Authors with affiliations: Madsen, J.J.
Abstract: A checklist included in the US Green Building Council's LEEDTM Rating system 2.0 for effective waste management is discussed. Waste reduction and recycling activities include identifying the types of wastes generated in a facility; provision of a central location for storage of recycled materials; diversion of construction and debris wastes from landfills. Facilities are also expected to invest in sustainable products that are not harmful to the environment.

Abstract: Gas-well drilling slowed from the frantic early-2001 surge due to free-falling prices. But industrial-market prospects support continued development of ample resources. Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Abstract: Development of long-pulse discharge XeF- and KrF-lasers pumped by a generator with an inductive energy storage and semiconductor-opening switch is reported. It is shown that use of inductive storage element allows significantly improve discharge stability and expand laser pulse duration. Pulse duration (FWHM) of 60 ns was obtained both in Ne-Xe-NF3 and Ne-Kr-F2 gas mixtures. Laser specific output of 2,5 J/l and intrinsic efficiency over 1% have been obtained for KrF-laser.

Authors: Ma Y., Li J., Liang D., Lu X.
Title: The ns-pulse high peak power circle-focusing laser beam for the laser processing

Res., Department of Optical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, 310027, China
Abstract: A method and the device for obtaining a high peak output power laser with the ns-regime pulse are presented. A Q-switched laser with a novel configuration and a special Q-switched method for the resonator energy storage are proposed. We put a piece of glass with a small hole and special parameters into the resonator which is composed of two totally reflective mirrors in order to obtain the coupling output and realize the step alternation of Q value from "1" to "0" in the resonator. The photons emit out of the resonator after a transmission back and forth so as that the output laser pulses with a few ns lifetime are obtained. Simultaneously, the output laser distributes with a circle-axisymmetic pattern and demonstrates good space-transmission and focusing characteristics.

Authors: Ye L., Zhang J., Cui Y., Li Z., He A.
Title: Two-photon absorption and optical-limiting properties of a novel organic compound
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Electronic Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China; Dept. of Info. Physics and Eng., Nanjing Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China

Physics and Eng., Nanjing Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China; He, A., Dept. of Info. Physics and Eng., Nanjing Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China
Abstract: The two-photon absorption and applications become the hot points in the recent photoelectronic material research field. The two-photon absorption materials can be applied to many fields such as up-conversion lasing, optical limiting, optical stabilization, three-dimension optical storage, three-dimension micro-machining, et al. Especially, studies of optical power limiting have become more interesting to the research community because of the need for automatic protection of optical sensors against intense laser radiation. Here we report the observation of the TPA and optical power limiting property of a novel double conjugated molecule DSBDR1 in solution. The linear absorption spectral is observed using a scanning spectrophotometer. Using Nd:YAG laser pulse as exciting laser, the incident pulse energy and the transmitted pulse energy are respectively recorded by an energy meter. Then we obtain the nonlinear absorption coefficient of the novel double conjugated molecule in THF. Figures show that the molecule exhibits the large TPA cross-section and excellent optical limiting at 1064 nm. The nonlinear absorption mechanism of the novel organic compound is finally analyzed.
Author Keywords: Nonlinear optics; Optical limiting; Organic compound; Two-photon absorption (TPA)
Index Keywords: Laser pulses; Light absorption; Light propagation; Molecules; Nonlinear optics; Optical phase conjugation; Optical resolving power; Photons; Spectrophotometers; Spectrum analysis; Linear absorption spectral; Optical power limiting property; Scanning spectrophotometer; Two-photon absorption; Organic compounds

Abstract: Self-pumped phase conjugation in Ce-doped barium titanate crystal is investigated with 1-Hz-repetition-rate nanosecond pulses from a Q-switched frequency-doubled Nd:YAG laser (532 nm wavelength). Phase conjugate reflectivity as high as 21.5% are obtained at an incident angle of 50°. Dark storage time, defined as the time after which the phase conjugate reflectivity declines to 90% of steady-state value when photorefractive crystal is in dark condition, is more than 20 minutes. Furthermore, self-pulsation of SPPC energy is studied.

Title: Charge-discharge processes of misch metal-based hydrogen storage alloys at relatively low temperatures
Affiliations: Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1 Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 599-8531, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Senoh, H., Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1 Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 599-8531, Japan; Kuriyama, N., Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1 Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 599-8531, Japan; Morimoto, K., Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1 Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 599-8531, Japan; Hara, Y., Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1 Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 599-8531, Japan; Inoue, H., Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1 Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 599-8531, Japan; Iwakura, C., Department of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka Prefecture University, 1-1 Gakuen-cho, Sakai, Osaka 599-8531, Japan
Abstract: For the purpose of clarifying the reason caused a drastic decrease of discharge capacity for MmNi3.6Mn0.4Al0.3Co0.7 electrode at relatively low temperatures, various factors influencing the charge-discharge processes were investigated in the temperamre range of 25°C to -40°C. The charge efficiency obviously decreased at low temperatures less than 0°C due to a decrease in the rate of the charge-transfer reaction on the electrode surface. Moreover, both the rate of the hydrogen diffusion from the alloy bulk to surface and the rate of the charge-transfer reaction significantly influenced the high-rate dischargeability. The addition of Mo to MmNi3.6Mn0.4Al0.3Co0.7 alloy was found to be effective for improving the electrocatalytic activity, leading to the improvements of the charge efficiency and the high-rate dischargeability at relatively low temperatures.
Index Keywords: Catalysis; Charge transfer; Charging (batteries); Diffusion; Electric field effects; Electrodes; Energy storage; Nickel compounds; Thermal effects; Charge-discharge processes; Hydrogen

Authors: Chen J., Kuriyama N., Kiyobayashi T., Takeshita H.T., Tanaka H., Takeichi N., Sakai T.
Title: Titanium catalyzed mechanism of lithium aluminum hydrides as hydrogen storage materials
Affiliations: Special Div. of Green Life Technol., National Institute of AIST, Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, J., Special Div. of Green Life Technol., National Institute of AIST, Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan; Kuriyama, N., Special Div. of Green Life Technol., National Institute of AIST, Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan; Kiyobayashi, T., Special Div. of Green Life Technol., National Institute of AIST, Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan; Takeshita, H.T., Special Div. of Green Life Technol., National Institute of AIST, Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan; Tanaka, H., Special Div. of Green Life Technol., National Institute of AIST, Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan; Takeichi, N., Special Div. of Green Life Technol., National Institute of AIST, Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan; Sakai, T., Special Div. of Green Life Technol., National Institute of AIST, Ikeda, Osaka 563-8577, Japan
Abstract: One method to store hydrogen effectively involves the use of metal complexes such as the alkali-element aluminum hydrides. The hydriding/dehydriding properties of these materials depend on how to prepare them with different structures and microstructures. The present work focused on a high-energy ball milling technique to produce Ti-doped lithium tetrahydridoaluminate (LiAlH4) and lithium hexahydroalanate (Li3AlH6) powders with nanocrystallites. The phase structures and dehydriding/rehydriding characteristics were investigated by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller measurement, thermogravimetry, and differential scanning calorimetry. The mechanism of dehydrogenation and rehydrogenation was also examined by means of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The results on the relation between the reversible hydrogen storage and catalysis function of the Ti-doped complex hydride indicate that both the homogenous distribution of Ti+Al nanoclusters and the Ti-catalyst with Ti0 ⇔ Ti3+ (Ti0/Ti2+/Ti3+) defect sites play important roles in optimizing the reversible hydrogen storage.
Index Keywords: Ball milling; Catalysis; Catalysts; Dehydrogenation; Differential scanning calorimetry; Doping (additives); Hydrides; Lithium compounds; Microstructure; Scanning electron microscopy; Thermogravimetric analysis; Transmission electron microscopy; X ray diffraction analysis; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Hydriding; Gas fuel storage

Authors: Tobishima S., Ogino Y., Kuryu T., Saito Y., Sugawara R., Oura M.
Title: Storage characteristics of lithium ion cells
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjincho, Kiryu, Gunma 376-8515, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tobishima, S., Faculty of Engineering, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjincho, Kiryu, Gunma 376-8515, Japan; Ogino, Y., Faculty of Engineering, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjincho, Kiryu, Gunma 376-8515, Japan; Kuryu, T., Faculty of Engineering, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjincho, Kiryu, Gunma 376-8515, Japan; Saito, Y., Faculty of Engineering, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjincho, Kiryu, Gunma 376-8515, Japan; Sugawara, R., Faculty of Engineering, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjincho, Kiryu, Gunma 376-8515, Japan; Oura, M., Faculty of Engineering, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjincho, Kiryu, Gunma 376-8515, Japan
Abstract: This report provides the results of simple preliminary tests on the storage characteristics of lithium ion cells in relation to their use for uninterrupted power supplies (UPS). Cylindrical 18650 size cells were used in the experiments. Cells were stored for 1 to 6 months and then their capacity was measured after constant voltage charging at 4.1 or 4.2 V and 21 or 60 °C. After measuring the capacity, the cells were crashed with a round bar as a fundamental abuse test. The residual cell capacity after 10 years of 4.2 V constant charging at 20 °C was predicted to be approximately 67 %. This exceeds our tentative target of 50 %.
Author Keywords: Lithium Ion Cell; Safety; Uninterrupted Power Supply
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Electric energy storage; Electric potential; Ions; Uninterruptible power systems; Carbon anodes; Lithium batteries

Authors: Kremer G.
Title: Compact plant for economical and flexible metered feeding of secondary fuels [Kompaktanlage zur wirtschaftlichen und flexiblen dosierung von sekundärbrennstoffen]
Authors with affiliations: Kremer, G.
Abstract: The use of secondary fuels in the cement industry has increased significantly in the last ten years. The utilization of secondary fuels plays an important role not only from the industrial economic aspect but also as a result of the political requirement for CO2 abatement through conservation of primary energy sources and the need for reliable and practical energy utilization of industrial product residues. These secondary fuels, which range from shredded plastics and carpet scraps to animal meal, exhibit differing material and handling properties. A semi-mobile package plant, which can be set up quickly in a cement works close to the burner, has been developed so supply all these different secondary fuels to the burner system of a cement works in the required quantities. Thanks to the semi-mobile design it is possible to dispense with expensive structural measures involving storage silos and unloading and conveying equipment. This semi-mobile package plant has already been installed and used successfully in numerous cement works.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Energy resources; Energy utilization; Fuel burners; Industrial economics; Plastics; Secondary fuels; Cement industry

Abstract: The breaker based on -vacuum interrupter (VI) and plasma erosion opening switch (PEOS), combined in single construction in vacuum gap is offered for consideration. This combination allows to transfer the energy from inductance store to a load in 30-100nsec for the storage time 0.5-1sec. and power ∼1012W and higher. The influence of microparticles appearing in gap the breaker efficiency is considered in this paper.

Abstract: The energy storage system for electric trains was discussed and the research in the development of the electrical double-layer capacitor (EDLC) designed to compensate voltage drop in overhead lines was described. As the purpose of installing EDLC is to compensate the voltage drop in overhead lines, the system is installed between substations, where the drop in the voltage is largest. In the applications of the energy storage system, the scale and the function are different according to the purpose.

Authors: Havard P.
Title: Reduction of radioactive waste production: Where is the optimum?
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Authors with affiliations: Havard, P.
Abstract: Low and medium level waste management means reducing the amount of waste generated during maintenance and operation of the plant, in accordance with the ALARA concept, while keeping not only the quality of the product but also the associated costs under control. All this waste is managed by ONDRAF/NIRAS, the Belgian Federal Agency responsible for waste management, including conditioning, intermediate storage and final disposal. Unfortunately, the actions taken by ONDRAF/NIRAS and the producers in order to reduce waste production have had a negative impact on waste treatment tariffs. It has become necessary to re-examine the relationship between ONDRAF/NIRAS and the producers, in order to control the costs of waste management. This problem concerns not only the treatment costs but also the disposal costs. The volume of waste has fallen from 30M3/Thwh in 1985 to 4.m3/Twh in 2000, not by chance but as the result of a new site organisation geared towards achieving this aim. This paper presents firstly the history of Belgian waste management, taking into account the impact on the associated costs, and secondly the measures that have to be taken in order to be able to decide which new technologies are necessary to go further with the objective of waste volume reduction in a new environment, namely deregulation and consequently high pressure on production costs. Finally, it presents a few conclusions.
Index Keywords: Costs; Radioactive waste disposal; Waste management; Waste treatment; Cost effectiveness; Deregulation; Economic and social effects; Industrial management; Maintenance; Nuclear energy; Quality control; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste production; Intermediate storage; Profitability; Waste treatment tariffs; Radioactive wastes; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Piseri P., Barborini E., Bruzzi M., Miglio S., Bongiorno G., Milani P.
Title: Electrical characterization of nanostructured carbon films produced by supersonic cluster beam deposition
Affiliations: INFM - Univ. degli Studi di Milano, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Celoria 16, 20133 Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Piseri, P., INFM - Univ. degli Studi di Milano, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Celoria 16, 20133 Milano, Italy; Barborini, E., INFM - Univ. degli Studi di Milano, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Celoria 16, 20133 Milano, Italy; Bruzzi, M., INFM - Univ. degli Studi di Milano, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Celoria 16, 20133 Milano, Italy; Miglio, S., INFM - Univ. degli Studi di Milano, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Celoria 16, 20133 Milano, Italy; Bongiorno, G., INFM - Univ. degli Studi di Milano, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Celoria 16, 20133 Milano, Italy; Milani, P., INFM - Univ. degli Studi di Milano, Dipartimento di Fisica, Via Celoria 16, 20133 Milano, Italy
Abstract: Electrical conduction in nanostructured carbon (ns-C) films produced by deposition of a supersonic beam of neutral carbon clusters has been studied. The d.c. conduction properties of these films have been measured in-situ during the deposition process and ex-situ as a function of the temperature in vacuum and in ambient of different gases (H2, N2, CH4, He). The ns-C films exhibit an ohmic behavior with a room temperature resistivity in the range 10MΩcm-1GΩcm depending on the growth and storage conditions. Conductivity vs. temperature measured in vacuum in the range 300-400K is characterized by activation energies in the range 0.3-0.7eV, the current response does not differ significantly in gas atmosphere.

Authors with affiliations: Drobizhev, M., Lebedev Physics Institute, Leninsky pr., 53, 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation; Kruk, M., Lebedev Physics Institute, Leninsky pr., 53, 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation; Karotki, A., Lebedev Physics Institute, Leninsky pr., 53, 119991 Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Special optical properties of porphyrins make them attractive for various photonic applications such as holographic data storage, optical power limiting and photodynamic therapy. So far, however, there was only a limited number of communications on TPA measurements in porphyrins. This paper aims to present the TPA spectra in absolute cross section values (σ2) for a number of porphyrins with gradually varying optical properties, and show that the TPA efficiency of these molecules can be resonantly enhanced in near-IR region.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Energy absorption; Fluorescence; Laser pulses; Optical properties; Parametric amplifiers; Porphyrins; Resonance; Optical parametric amplifier; Two-photon absorption; Multiphoton processes

Authors: Egorov O.G.
Title: Transitional processes in combined opening switch (vacuum interrupter and PEOS)
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Troitsk Inst. Innov. and Fusion Res., Troitsk, Moscow reg. 142190, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Egorov, O.G., Troitsk Inst. Innov. and Fusion Res., Troitsk, Moscow reg. 142190, Russian Federation
Abstract: The opening switch combined of two opening switches - vacuum interrupter and plasma erosion opening switch is offered for consideration. Each of the interrupters has several physical and technical properties limits, which allow to integrate them in one construction [1,2]. Two designs of this combination are consider. The current breaking process in combined opening switch (COS) have three stages. The first one - stage of vacuum interrupter i.e. energy accumulation in inductance store, the second one - stage of current zero i.e. vacuum gap recovery, and the third one - stage of plasma erosion opening switch, magnetic self insulation and energy transmission to a load. The offered designs allow to realize relation between time of energy storage in IS and time of energy output from IS to a load ∼106÷107. Under it the power developed by COS on a load equals 1011÷1012W. Effect of different factors, in particular, presence of particles in vacuum gap to efficiency of energy transmission to a load is discussion in this paper.
Index Keywords: Electric circuit breakers; Electric currents; Electric insulation; Inductance; Magnetic materials; Physical properties; Plasma devices; Vacuum technology; Combined opening switch; Current breaking process; Magnetic self insulation; Plasma erosion opening switch; Vacuum interrupter; Electric switches

Authors: Hottenrott G., Mirschinka V.
Title: The current situation of waste management at German nuclear power plants
Affiliations: RWE Power AG, Head of Nuclear Fuel Department, Essen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hottenrott, G., RWE Power AG, Head of Nuclear Fuel Department, Essen, Germany; Mirschinka, V., RWE Power AG, Head of Nuclear Fuel Department, Essen, Germany
Abstract: An overview is given about the main points of the agreement between the four utility companies and the German government on June 11, 2001, concerning waste management and disposal. The current waste management situation is compared with the effects of the agreement on the future development of the German waste management concept. Major innovations are the discontinuation of reprocessing, the establishment of local intermediate storage facilities for fuel elements and the suspension of the exploration works conducted on the salt dome at Gorleben.
Index Keywords: Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuel elements; Nuclear power plants; Radioactive waste storage; Recycling; Irradiated fuel elements; Radioactive waste disposal
