Authors: Barré B.
Title: Radioactive waste management in France - With special emphasis on HLW
Affiliations: COGEMA, 2 rue Paul Dautier, 78141 Vélizy Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Barré, B., COGEMA, 2 rue Paul Dautier, 78141 Vélizy Cedex, France
Abstract: A result of a recent opinion poll about the acceptance of nuclear power published in the "Eurobarometer" indicates the great significance EU citizens attach to the management of radioactive waste. Two thirds of the interviewees regard nuclear power as an option for the future once the waste management problem has been solved safely. In France, as in other countries, strategies for handling and managing radioactive waste were developed at an early stage. Different waste management pathways have been established for different types of waste as function of their characteristics. Between 1969 and 1994, low-level waste was emplaced at the Centre de la Manche; since 1992, the Centre de l'Aube has become available with an aggregate capacity of one million cubic meters planned for the period until 2040. High-level waste and longlived waste from electricity generation by nuclear power arise in France in the reprocessing of nuclear fuel at the La Hague plant, and are held in interim storage in the same place. In France, preference is given to reprocessing because of resource conservation and the minimization of higher-level waste volumes. In 1991, the French parliament adopted legislation for a fifteen-year research and development program and, on the basis of its outcome, a decision about the waste management policy to be taken. Items to be studied within this program are the separation and transmutation of actinides and longlived radionuclides, studies of deep geologic repositories, and of conditioning and final storage. Once the results have become available, the necessary political decision about the waste management strategy and a repository site can be taken in 2006. Technically, there are no reasons for further delays even at the present time.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Geological repositories; Nuclear energy; Radioactive waste storage; Radioisotopes; Waste management; Radioactive waste management; Radioactive wastes

Authors: Fuertes A.B., Marbán G., Nevskaia D.M.
Title: Preparation and characterization of mesoporous hybrid particle-fiber carbon monoliths
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional del Carbón (CSIC), Apartado 73, 33080-Oviedo, Spain; Departamento de Química Inorgánica y Técnica, Facultad de Ciencias (UNED), c/ Senda del Rey, 9, 28040-Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Fuertes, A.B., Instituto Nacional del Carbón (CSIC), Apartado 73, 33080-Oviedo, Spain; Marbán, G., Instituto Nacional del Carbón (CSIC), Apartado 73, 33080-Oviedo, Spain; Nevskaia, D.M., Departamento de Química Inorgánica y Técnica, Facultad de Ciencias (UNED), c/ Senda del Rey, 9, 28040-Madrid, Spain
Abstract: Porous carbon materials are a subject of increasing attention in many areas of technology such as air purification, catalysis, refrigeration, gas and energy storage, and energy production. Super-activated carbons (SAC) are powdered activated carbons generally made from mesocarbon microbeads and have a very high adsorption capacity. They are highly appropriate for use in evaporative loss control devices (automobile canisters), catalytic supports, fuel-cell electrodes, and double-layer electrical capacitors. In all of these applications it is desirable that the carbon particles be immobilized in order to form rigid devices of high permeability. This communication describes a method to immobilize these fine particles in order to obtain rigid structures with a high internal porosity.
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Adsorption; Carbon fibers; Carbonization; Characterization; Composite materials; Compressive strength; Electric conductivity; Hybrid particles; Mesoporous materials

Authors: Gazzola C., Spiers W.G.
Title: Effects of the α2-adrenoceptor agonist, guanfacine, on growth rate, glucose, corticosterone, insulin and energy partitioning in rats
Affiliations: Agency for Food and Fibre Sciences, PO Box 5545, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia; CSIRO Livestock Industries, PO Box 5545, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia; 4 Ryan Street, Zilzie, QLD 4700, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Gazzola, C., Agency for Food and Fibre Sciences, PO Box 5545, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia; Spiers, W.G., Agency for Food and Fibre Sciences, PO Box 5545, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia, CSIRO Livestock Industries, PO Box 5545, Rockhampton, QLD 4702, Australia, 4 Ryan Street, Zilzie, QLD 4700, Australia
Abstract: In experiment 1, female Wistar rats (no. = 24) with free access to food were treated daily For 8 days with subcutaneous injections of saline or 0.5 mg/kg of the α2-adrenoceptor agonist, guanfacine hydrochloride. In experiment 2, female Wistar rats (no. = 24), restricted to 12 g food per day, were treated daily for 45 days with subcutaneous injections of 1 μl/g body weight saline containing 0, 0.001, 0.025 or 0.5 mg/kg guanfacine hydrochloride. In experiment 1, the control and treated groups consumed similar amounts of food but the guanfacine-treated animals gained less body weight (P < 0.05) and less muscle mass (P < 0.01). The treated animals had pronounced glucosuria (P < 0.05) during the whole treatment period. At slaughter, the treated group had higher blood glucose (P < 0.001) and serum corticosterone (P < 0.05) but insulin concentrations were not different. In experiment 2, only the 0.5 mg/kg dose of guanfacine had significant effects. Resting oxygen consumption on day 29 of treatment was proportionately 0.10 lower in this group compared with controls (P < 0.05). There was no effect of treatment on growth rate. After 46 days, the 0.5 mg/kg treatment group had proportionately 0.35 more body fat (P < 0.01) higher body fat content (P < 0.01), higher total body energy (P < 0.05) and higher total body energy content (P < 0.05). Experiment 1 linked reduced growth rate with increased corticosterone concentrations and experiment 2 suggested the mechanism may be a repartitioning of energy storage to lipid. However, it was not determined whether these consequences were a direct effect of guanfacine or a secondary effect due to corticosterone. In spite of reductions in energy expenditure, guanfacine retards growth in rats and mice, but not in cattle where growth is enhanced. Thus rodents may have a limited usefulness as models for studies of α2-adrenoceptor agonists in cattle.
Author Keywords: Corticosterone; Energy expenditure; Glucose; Growth; Guanfacine; Rats
Index Keywords: Animalia; Bos taurus; Rattus norvegicus; Rodentia

Authors: Lebl J.
Title: Differential diagnosis of childhood obesity
Affiliations: Klin. Dětí Dorostu 3, LF UK a FNKV, Vinohradská 159, 100 81 Praha 10, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Lebl, J., Klin. Dětí Dorostu 3, LF UK a FNKV, Vinohradská 159, 100 81 Praha 10, Czech Republic
Abstract: Physiological regulation of eating behaviour together with regular physical activity represents the natural prevention from pathological fat deposition and obesity in children. This regulation may be disrupted by hypothyroidism, cortisol excess, growth hormone deficiency, pseudohypoparathyroidism, hypothalamic lesions and in several genetic syndromes. The monogenic causes of obesity include disorders of leptin, leptin receptor and melanocortin-4 receptor. However, all these conditions are rare. A vast majority of cases of childhood obesity has is caused by environmental factors, which lead to abnormal eating patterns with excess intake of energy-rich food in connection with lacking physical exercise. The evaluation of an obese child consists of three steps. Firstly, the estimation of the severity of obesity, using weight-height ratio, body mass index or measurements of body composition; secondly, estimation of the causes of obesity with the aim to exclude severe endogenous disorders; and finally, estimation of complications of obesity in the more severe cases.
Author Keywords: Aetiology; Children; Complications; Diagnosis; Obesity

Authors: Alonso C., Estibals B., Ricart T., Vieu C., Carcenac F., Malaquin L., Dilhan M., Camon H., Martinez A.
Title: New design for magnetic storage elements of micro power supplies
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France
Authors with affiliations: Alonso, C., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France; Estibals, B., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France; Ricart, T., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France; Vieu, C., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France; Carcenac, F., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France; Malaquin, L., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France; Dilhan, M., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France; Camon, H., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France; Martinez, A., LAAS-CNRS, 7 avenue du Colonel Roche, 31077 Toulouse Cedex 04, France
Abstract: In a fast growth context of micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) applications, an important improvement of power supplies "power-to-weight" ratio can be obtained through the integration of magnetic storage elements with their associated electronic environment. These components are usually used to transfer and storage high energy densities with high magnetic flux. But since today, integrated devices with these inductive elements were mainly limited by low inductance and current values. To make optimised new designs and achieve realisation of such inductive elements, we propose a new complete methodology, illustrated through a micro-machined square planar inductor. Indeed, after defining specifications (power, inductance value, frequency, geometrical dimensions), a mathematical method is used to define a first geometrical parameters set. To achieve it, several simulations are conducted with CAD Tools dedicated to MEMS Technology. Our method is based on a new specific last nano-imprint technology we have developed in our laboratory and adapted to our application in parallel.
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Computer simulation; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Inductance; Magnetic flux; Magnetic storage; Mathematical models; Micromachining; Optimization; Specifications; Inductive; Magnetic storage elements; Micor power supplies; Micro machined square planar inductor; Microelectromechanical devices

Authors: Ericson H.
Title: Novel materials for fuel cells and batteries: Light scattering studies of the structure and dynamics of polymer electrolytes
Affiliations: Department of Experimental Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, Göteborg University, Goteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Ericson, H., Department of Experimental Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, Göteborg University, Goteborg, Sweden
Abstract: The development of new materials and technologies for electrochemical energy conversion and storage, such as fuel cells and batteries, is important for a future more efficient use of energy. Polymer electrolytes are key components in polymer electrolyte fuel cells and lithium-based batteries. A better understanding of the materials properties is needed to optimise materials for each application. This thesis includes reports of three types of polymer electrolytes. Micro-Raman spectroscopy was used to study the structure and composition of fuel cell membranes consisting of poly(styrene sulfonic acid) grafted onto a partially or completely fluorinated polymer matrix, mainly poly(vinylidene fluroide). In focus was the spatial distribution of functional groups controlling proton transport and influencing mechanical properties. Fuel cell tested membranes were studied to find the reasons for membrane failure and how the structure affects the membrane life-Time in a fuel cell. The effects of polymer end-groups on salt solvation in a polymer/salt complex was investigated with Raman spectroscopy. The interactions and charge carriers in novel acid doped gels were studied with vibrational spectroscopy and the dynamics of acid and salt doped gel electrolytes with a liquid electrolyte of ethylene carbonate/propylene carbonate and a poly methyl methacrylate polymer matrix were investigated with photon correlation spectroscopy.
Author Keywords: Fuel cell membrane; Gel electrolyte; Photon correlation spectroscopy; Polymer electrolyte; Proton conducting polymer; Raman spectroscopy
Index Keywords: Charge carriers; Doping (additives); Electrochemistry; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Gels; Grafting (chemical); Polycarbonates; Polymeric membranes; Polymethyl methacrylates; Polystyrenes; Raman spectroscopy; Fuel cell membranes; Functional groups; Photon correlation spectroscopy; Polyelectrolytes

Authors: Özyurt B., Karatas H., Inan C., Egrican N., Hocaoglu S., Cousins S.
Title: Defrost efficiency in a no-frost-type household refrigerator
Authors with affiliations: Özyurt, B.; Karatas, H.; Inan, C.; Egrican, N.; Hocaoglu, S.; Cousins, S.
Abstract: In this study, defrost efficiency and its effects on system performance in a top mount domestic freezer have been investigated. A dual evaporator system, where two separate evaporators are connected either serially or in parallel, is used to discuss advantages and disadvantages of defrosting methods. Evaporators are located in each individual freezer and fresh food compartment. Since the fresh food evaporator's inlet air temperature is normally higher than 5°C, it seems like a good idea to use this warm air for defrosting. The term "air defrosting" is used for this process, which is simply circulating the fresh food compartment air through the evaporator while the compressor is in the off position. In order to see the effects of air defrosting, three possible cases are investigated experimentally. These methods are 1) heater defrost on both evaporators, 2) heater on freezer evaporator and air defrosting on fresh food evaporator, 3) heater on freezer evaporator and a combination of heater and air defrosting on fresh food evaporator. The separate and combined defrosting of the evaporators is also studied. Defrost efficiency and effects of defrosting in refrigerator energy consumption are measured. In the experiments, the effect of door opening is also included.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric humidity; Defrosting; Energy utilization; Evaporators; Food storage; Freezing; Heat transfer; Heating; Surface properties; Dual-evaporator refrigeration cycles; No frost-type refrigerators; Refrigerators

Authors: De Vuyst P.
Title: Present situation of the nuclear power plants in Belgium
Affiliations: Electrabel, Doel, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: De Vuyst, P., Electrabel, Doel, Belgium
Abstract: In Belgium, nuclear energy represents 60% of the total electricity generation. All reactors are pressurized water reactors, with fuel cycle lengths varying from 12 to 18 months using high-enriched fuel, MOX-fuel is burned in two units. The steam generators of all 1000 MW units have been replaced. The reprocessing of the spent fuel from the first units is terminated and storage occurs now for medium term in new buildings erected at the respective sites. No new nuclear power plants are permitted at this time. The major challenge is now to continue the safe operation of the plants, to reach at least their expected service life of 40 years, and to maintain the present satisfactory public acceptance while effectively reducing costs. The plants show very good availability factors with short outages for refuelling.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Electric power generation; Outages; Pressurized water reactors; Reactor refueling; Spent fuels; Steam generators; High enriched fuels; Nuclear power plants

Authors: Haas H.
Title: Hydro-power - Strategic position of electricity generation in the competitive market
Affiliations: E.ON Wasserkraft GmbH, Landshut, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Haas, H., E.ON Wasserkraft GmbH, Landshut, Germany
Abstract: In Germany, hydro-power still ranks first among renewable sources of energy, although, due to its subsidization, the importance of wind power has significantly increased in the past years and will grow even further in the future. Due to high investment costs and lacking profitability, the construction of larger hydro-power stations in Germany can be excluded under current circumstances. However, those power stations already under construction will be completed. In view of the undisputed ecological advantages of hydro-power, the support and promotion of especially larger hydro-power stations should become an appropriate necessity.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Marketing; Technological forecasting; Wind power; Electricity market; Hydropower stations; Profitability; Pumped storage power plants

Authors: Majima M., Koyama K., Inazawa S., Yagasaki E.
Title: Development of a long-life lithium-ion battery for load leveling
Authors with affiliations: Majima, M.; Koyama, K.; Inazawa, S.; Yagasaki, E.
Abstract: High-voltage, high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries are used extensively in portable electronic devices such as cellular phones and notebook PCs. This research is aimed at increasing the capacity of high-performance lithium-ion batteries for use in economically viable option for power storage, a lithium-ion battery must have an effective operating life of at least ten years. In direct terms, it needs to be a 4,000-cycle class long-life storage cell. Cycle deterioration in batteries in influenced by a number of factors. The authors have identified changes in the volume of the active electrode material during charging and discharging as a major causative factor in cycle deterioration, particularly in cases where increases in the battery capacity are achieved by layering large number of electrodes. We have also shown that Li4/3T5/3O4 is excellent as an active material in the anode. Furthermore, we have developed an accelerated testing method using high density, and used that method to test the cycle life of the battery. This research has led to successfully increasing the effective life of an LiCoO2/Li4/3Ti5/3O4 battery to 4,650 cycles.
Index Keywords: Anodes; Cathodes; Crystal lattices; Electrochemistry; Graphite; Intercalation compounds; Ions; Lithium compounds; X ray diffraction analysis; Electrochemical extraction; Electrochemical insertion; Intercalation reaction; Lithium ion battery; Lithium batteries

Authors: Ye S., Ye Z., Zhu H., Feng T., Zhang Z., Yuan H., Hu S.-B.
Title: Experimental study and analysis of the application of ice-storage capsules in an air conditioning system
Affiliations: Hangzhou Huayuan Company, China; Zhejiang University, China
Authors with affiliations: Ye, S., Hangzhou Huayuan Company, China; Ye, Z., Hangzhou Huayuan Company, China; Zhu, H., Zhejiang University, China; Feng, T., Hangzhou Huayuan Company, China; Zhang, Z., Hangzhou Huayuan Company, China; Yuan, H., Hangzhou Huayuan Company, China; Hu, S.-B., Hangzhou Huayuan Company, China
Abstract: Ice-storage capsules are used in an energy-efficient air conditioning system. Experiments and numerical simulations were conducted to investigate the effects of different structural configurations of the capsules on the freezing and melting processes of the refrigerant solution sealed inside the capsules. The predictions of the numerical simulation are in good agreement with the test results. The results show that the freezing speed of the capsules equipped with a metal core is 30% to 50% faster than for capsules without the metal core. In addition, it was found that the special refrigerant solution used in the experiment had a lower freezing point and a higher freezing speed than water. The effects of the size of the metal core, and the coolant temperatures are also investigated. © 2001 Scripta Technica, Heat Trans Asian Res, 31(1): 21-27, 2002.
Author Keywords: Air conditioning; Ice storage

Authors: Shakya M.R.
Title: Nepal studies hydropower storage projects
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: Nepal Electricity Authority, Durbar Marg, Kathmandu, Nepal
Authors with affiliations: Shakya, M.R., Nepal Electricity Authority, Durbar Marg, Kathmandu, Nepal
Abstract: Nepal is currently facing a power deficit during the dry season, when the electricity demand is high but the supply is limited. To meet the energy demand in an efficient manner in the long term, there is an urgent need for the development of storage schemes, as the existing Kulekhani scheme is not sufficient to meet the seasonal variation in load demand. A feasibility study is now under way by NEA, which has screened and ranked various feasible schemes from a total of 102 identified.

Authors: Van Den Hurk B.J.J.M., Jia L., Menenti M.
Title: Assimilation of land surface temperature data from ATSR in an NWP environment - case studies with ATSR data in Spain and The Netherlands
Source title: International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (IGARSS)
Affiliations: Alterra Green World Research, WUR, Droevendaalsesteeg 3, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Den Hurk, B.J.J.M., Alterra Green World Research, WUR, Droevendaalsesteeg 3, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands; Jia, L., Alterra Green World Research, WUR, Droevendaalsesteeg 3, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands; Menenti, M., Alterra Green World Research, WUR, Droevendaalsesteeg 3, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands
Abstract: Land surface parameterizations in Numerical Weather Prediction describe the exchange of energy and water at the land-atmosphere interface. They are generally based on a coupled energy-water budget equation, and the results depend critically on (prescribed) land surface characteristics, notably albedo, soil water storage capacity and aerodynamic roughness. In a recent case - study bi - angular (nadir and forward) observations provided by the ATSR instrument were used to estimate the component soil and foliage temperature. For two images overlying the Netherlands on 14 May 1998 and South-East Spain on 9 September 1998 vegetation and bare ground temperatures were derived from ATSR data, and aggregated to a grid of 25 × 25 km, compatible with a NWP model. This NWP model was equipped with a land surface parameterization scheme in which vegetation and bare ground temperature were calculated separately. In a variational assimilation scheme, the NWP model was forced to match the observed component temperatures by changing both the soil moisture content and the aerodynamic roughness for the heat exchange of the bare ground component. It appeared that the optimal solution differed significantly for the two regions. For The Netherlands, changing the aerodynamic roughness did not affect the correspondence to observations, and soil moisture had to be changed to increase the overall model performance. For the Spanish case, in contrast, aerodynamic roughness had to be changed significantly. The Spain case - study was extended by analyzing a time - series of ATSR - 1 and - 2 data. The evaluation of results focuses on the temporal variability of aerodynamic roughness for heat transport.
Index Keywords: Aerodynamics; Atmospheric temperature; Calculations; Data processing; Mathematical models; Moisture; Numerical methods; Radiometers; Soils; Time series analysis; Aerodynamic roughness; Land surface temperature; Land-atmosphere interface; Numerical Weather Prediction; Weather forecasting

Title: Muon storage rings for a beam-systematic-free measurement of neutrino and antineutrino cross-sections at low energy
Affiliations: Institut für Teilchenphysik, ETHZ, CH-8093 Zürich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Navas-Concha, S., Institut für Teilchenphysik, ETHZ, CH-8093 Zürich, Switzerland; Rubbia, A., Institut für Teilchenphysik, ETHZ, CH-8093 Zürich, Switzerland
Abstract: Precision neutrino cross-section measurements at low energies will be necessary to improve the results of the current and future big neutrino experiments. In order to achieve precision neutrino cross-sections, that will yield a comprehensive understand of the underlying physics, a rather extended program will be required: (1) measurement from kinematical thresholds up to a few GeV; (2) well known and controlled neutrino flux; (3) study of neutrinos and anti-neutrinos and possibly νe and νμ flavors; (4) on several nuclear target; (5) with detectors capable of exclusive final state reconstruction. While the "standard" choice advocated relies on currently existing or on future "traditional" neutrino beams, that will provide very high intensities at near sites, we advocate that neutrinos from muon storage rings provide a better choice to criterias (1)-(3). The currently available statistics from the CERN AD and the FNAL-Debuncher would provide statistical precisions better than 10% in typ. 200 MeV bins in the low energy range.

Authors: Sivanandam S.N., Sumathi S., Babu S.
Title: Development of new soft computing models for data mining
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers (India), Part CP: Computer Engineering Division
Affiliations: Dept. of Elec. and Electronics Eng., PSG College of Technology, Coimbatore 641 004, India
Authors with affiliations: Sivanandam, S.N., Dept. of Elec. and Electronics Eng., PSG College of Technology, Coimbatore 641 004, India; Sumathi, S., Dept. of Elec. and Electronics Eng., PSG College of Technology, Coimbatore 641 004, India; Babu, S., Dept. of Elec. and Electronics Eng., PSG College of Technology, Coimbatore 641 004, India
Abstract: Information and energy are at the core of everything around us. Our entire existence is a process of gathering, analyzing, understanding and acting on the information. For many applications dealing with large amounts of data, pattern classification is a key element in arriving at the solution. Engineering applications especially like medical diagnosis require the ability to accurately classify the recorded data for controlling, tracking and decision making. Although, modern technologies enable storage of large streams of data, there is no technology to help us to understand, analyze, or even visualize the hidden information in the data. Data mining is the emerging field that helps us to understand and analyze the hidden information from very large databases (VLDB). In this paper, two important data mining tools, ie, neural networks and genetic algorithm have been used for mining the database through pattern classification. The processing consists of three major phases, network construction and training, pruning; rule extraction and validation. The networks used are namely adaptive resonance theory 1.5, adaptive resonance theory 3 and multi channel ART(MART). These networks belong to the adaptive resonance theory (ART) family, which is a self organizing neural network capable of clustering arbitrary sequence of input patterns into stable recognition codes. The pruning phase aims at removing redundant links and units without increasing the classification error rate of the network. The pruning methods adopted are local pruning and threshold pruning. The final phase extracts the classification rules from the final weights of the pruned network in the form of IF THEN rules and rules are validated using validation algorithm. The genetic algorithm is also used to optimise the performance with regard to the various parameters used in the network. The performance analysis and comparision of all the networks have been done. The proposed networks have been tested on diabetes data application taken from UCI machine learning site. Simulation algorithms have been implemented using C++ language in the Pentium machine. The graphical results have been obtained using Microsoft Excel.
Author Keywords: Adaptive resonance theory; Data mining; Genetic algorithm; Neural network
